name: La Présidente. -
text: The agenda calls for debate on the statement of the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the European Union's annual report on human rights and democracy in the world (2014/2830 (RSP)).

name: Neven Mimica
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. - Madam President, on behalf of the High Representative, Catherine Ashton, I am honoured to address you today on the occasion of the presentation of the 2013 annual report on human rights and democracy. As you know, the annual report outlines the work done by the European Union on human rights and democracy across the whole range of our external relations during the past year. It tells the story of our enduring efforts to defend and promote human rights and to support democracy around the world. The European Union has put human rights at the very centre of its external action and is undoubtedly one of the main international actors in the field. One of the reasons for this is the leading role played by the European Parliament in influencing and shaping our democracy and human rights policy. I would like to praise the work of all those honourable Members who have played and are playing a crucial role in promoting human rights and reporting violations and abuses, in particular those who are active in the Subcommittee on Human Rights. Last December we had the opportunity for a broad debate in plenary on the excellent report on human rights and democracy in the world drafted by Mr Kukan. Many of the topics and concerns raised in the document are taken up in our annual report. This proves that in the protection and promotion of human rights and democracy we stand united. Since the adoption of the human rights package in June 2012, our annual reports give us an opportunity to assess our capacity to implement the ambitious 2012 action plan on human rights and democracy. We are happy to see that Parliament has appreciated this effort to provide transparency and accountability. Allow me a few words on the Strategic Framework and Action Plan on Human Rights and Democracy. The adoption of this package was a landmark decision. It provided us with a clear set of principles and objectives to guide our work in promoting human rights in the world. Thanks to these comprehensive documents, the EU’s delivery has become more tangible and more measurable. It has also made our endeavours part of a collective effort involving all EU institutions and Member States alike. I am pleased to say that, in two years, we have accomplished most of the nearly 100 actions set out, and we are working on completing the remaining ones. At a time when democratic values are increasingly being challenged in many parts of the world, the High Representative and her services, including EU delegations, have addressed human rights and democracy as a matter of priority. Those who are oppressed around the world, as well as civil society representatives and international partners, look up to the European Union and count on our contribution. The EU has not feared to go beyond traditional diplomacy and to express its concerns openly. Baroness Ashton did just that over the developments in Russia in relation to civil society. She spoke out on the harassment of civil society in Latin America and sub-Saharan Africa. She called for the release of political prisoners in Bahrain while attending the EU and Gulf Cooperation Council ministerial meeting. In Myanmar she joined Aung San Suu Kyi in attending a special civil society forum with more than 60 participants from all parts of the country. Civil society representatives were similarly involved in the EU-Myanmar/Burma Task Force and participated actively in its political session. The role of Stavros Lambrinidis as the EU’s Special Representative for Human Rights has also been crucial. Throughout these past two years he has shown incredible stamina and has spared no efforts in designing and projecting our human rights policy across the world and in advancing the universality of human rights. He has been, and is constantly, engaging with all our strategic partners and has consistently addressed human rights challenges with key countries in democratic transition. He has been, and still is, tirelessly reaching out to NGOs and civil society organisations. Stavros has proved to be the EU’s solid and loud voice on human rights. Our EU annual report sets out a number of our key achievements. We have moved forward with our human rights country strategies: we have now concluded more than 150 strategies, covering the globe and providing tailor-made approaches and strategic objectives for each individual country. This has been an important step in empowering our EU delegations in their new post-Lisbon role. In addition, we have established human rights focal points in all EU delegations and common security and defence policy missions and operations. We have stepped up efforts to train our staff on human rights and democracy issues, both in the delegations and at headquarters. Every year the Union holds human rights dialogues and consultations with more than 30 partner countries and regional groupings. In 2013, human rights dialogues with South Africa and Burma/Myanmar and consultations with the Republic of Korea were held for the first time. We have extended our toolkit by adopting new EU human rights guidelines. In 2013 we adopted guidelines to promote and protect the enjoyment of all human rights by lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender and intra-sex persons, as well as guidelines on freedom of expression freedom of belief, following the adoption by this House of a detailed recommendation on the topic. We have promptly condemned cases of religious hatred, intolerance and violence in the world: in Egypt, Nigeria, Iran, Libya, Mali, Pakistan and Tunisia and, more notably, following the tragic developments unfolding in Iraq and Syria. At the same time, all our instruments – political dialogues, démarches, technical assistance and support for NGOs – are used to address more systematic issues related to freedom of religion or belief in a bilateral context. Conscious of the increased incidence of intimidation and harassment of journalists and of restrictions on media freedom, we adopted a few months ago the first ever guidelines on freedom of expression online and offline, in consultation with civil society and under the inspiration of Parliament’s report on the freedom of press and media in the world. At the same time, the EU has loudly condemned attacks on journalists and bloggers, and has participated in all international efforts to promote and protect freedom of expression. The EU has used all its available tools of diplomacy and cooperation and assistance to work towards the abolition of the death penalty. We have issued hundreds of statements and carried out hundreds of démarches to condemn the use of capital punishment wherever and whenever it occurs. Thanks to our constant efforts and lobbying, the UN General Assembly 67th session adopted a resolution on a moratorium on executions, with unprecedented support. Thanks to our efforts, no European drugs are exported to states that use lethal injections to execute. As we approach the 30th anniversary of the adoption of the UN Convention Against Torture, the EU has stepped up its efforts to address this unacceptable practice, which still exists in so many countries around the world. The EU has shown an equally active commitment to combating discrimination, especially discrimination based on sexual orientation and gender identity. We have never refrained from stating our belief that all people are created equal and that no cultural, societal or religious traditions can be invoked to justify any form of discrimination. Gender has always been a top priority. The EU has taken an active stance on the elimination and prevention of all forms of violence against women and girls. Thanks to our outreach, we were able to contribute to the successful adoption of conclusions at the 57th session of the UN Commission on the Status of Women. Our strong engagement has also yielded results in the implementation of UN Security Council Resolution 1325 on women, peace and security. The protection and the promotion of children’s rights and the issue of children and armed conflict have been central to the EU human rights policy and funding instruments. The EU is proud to support the campaign, Children, Not Soldiers, jointly initiated in 2014 by the UN Special Representative for Children and Armed Conflict and UNICEF, aiming to end and prevent the recruitment and use of children in conflict by 2016. Supporting civil society has remained at the heart of our objectives. We continue to focus on protecting NGOs and human rights defenders and expanding the space in which they operate. We have called on numerous governments to make sure that new legislation is adopted and implemented in line with international standards. Human rights defenders play an important role at local, national, regional and international levels, and the promotion of human rights cannot exist without them. This year the EU celebrated the 10th anniversary of its Guidelines on Human Rights Defenders. Through various instruments, such as small grants and ‘sheltered cities’, the EU has actively illustrated its support for vulnerable and marginalised human rights defenders. EU and Member State diplomats on the ground have attended the trials of human rights defenders and made efforts to secure their release. A recent trial observation in Saudi Arabia is just one example. Over the years, the EU has supported electoral processes throughout the world. Since 2000 we have deployed 140 election observation missions. As in so many other fields, strong cooperation with Parliament is all the more apparent here. At a multilateral level the EU remained active and engaged with all major international and regional partners. In recent years we have stepped up our cooperation with the Council of Europe, the OSCE and other regional mechanisms working on human rights. We intensified and advanced our agenda in Geneva and New York. The EU’s role has been pivotal in key United Nations achievements such as mandates for special rapporteurs and country resolutions from Belarus, Iran, Burma/Myanmar, the Democratic People’s Republic of Korea and Syria. I am looking forward to the debate on this important report and I look forward to your further contribution to the promotion of human rights in the world.

name: Andrzej Grzyb
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I am very happy to say that, at my request, as coordinator of the European People's Party, it was possible to introduce this report for the first post-holiday session of the new legislature. I thank Commissioner Mimica for his presentation. It seems to me that this year 2013 was very important in the Union's work for human rights and democracy in the world. We are implementing the changes that result, on the one hand, from the Treaty of Lisbon and, on the other hand, we also have an example of how our response to the challenges of the Arab Spring materialises. We also have all these problems that are in the neighbourhood, with our neighbours in Europe – that is, what is happening behind the eastern border of the European Union. It is good that the report refers m.in. to the work of the European Union Special Representative for Human Rights, Stavros Lambrinidis, who is also present at today's debate.  I would like to emphasise that the European Parliament is involved in these changes through its reports, numerous recommendations or the work of the contact group set up in 2012.  2013 is also the approval of the Multiannual Financial Framework. I am pleased to note that the European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights has been significantly increased in financial terms. We also appreciate that almost 150 different human rights strategies were developed in 2013 for partner countries and that 123 of them were finally approved by the Political and Security Committee. However, we renew our calls for procedures for effective access by the European Parliament – even if not in its entirety, at least to the rapporteurs or shadow rapporteurs on the subjects – to these strategies.  The Council report notes that the European End for Democracy also started operating last year. This is an initiative of the Polish Presidency. By the end of 2013, almost half a thousand applications – only 5% of them could be implemented due to financial thinness , but this also demonstrates the legitimacy of the establishment of this instrument. It seems worth looking at the achievements, effectiveness of the approach and considering changes that will make greater use of the Union budget.  The european Parliament's numerous actions in the report have also been recognised. It is worth noting the second summit of ceasers of the European Union and the Eastern Partnership. What is happening behind the eastern border of the European Union is worth including the spokespersons from these countries in this process and showing good practices and their exchange, not just indicating what you should do. This is definitely a better instrument.  Efforts by the Union for corporate social responsibility and for human rights have also been noted. We have finished work on the report. This work, which was completed in 2014, resulted in m.in. amendments to the non-financial disclosure directives, and in both cases I can say that they must also take into account not only the interests of these large corporations, but above all the competitiveness of European companies.  Finally, I would like to appreciate the issues of freedom of religion and belief that have also been noted. What is happening about people of the Christian faith, the Yazyds, requires our special care. It must not be the case that people cannot express religious beliefs or have the right to freedom of religion.

name: Elena Valenciano Martínez-Orozco
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, we only have to read the morning papers to realize that human rights remain an outstanding subject in the European Union. The truth is, we can check it every day. But it is true that, for a few years now, we have improved our position, because we have tools to carry out our task. And this annual report is a good opportunity to assess what we have done. However, clear indicators and even clearer commitments remain, so that we know whether the European Union really succeeds in advancing its strategy of defending human rights in the world. We are about to draw up a new action plan in which this Parliament unfortunately does not have much voice, but we know that we will still be heard. And I would like to take this opportunity to congratulate Mr Lambrinidis on the task that the special representative has done over the years and I want him to continue to be able to advance all the work that is being done. Because there's almost everything left to do. In human rights I would say that, in order not to take a step back, many steps must be taken forward and that human rights cannot be just the friendly face of the European Union. It has to be a cross-cutting policy and a commitment from all of us and all of us. Human rights are universal. It seems a lie that this principle must be reiterated again. They're universal. And there is no cultural, religious, political or other relativism that should push us back on this principle, which we defend very strongly. Human rights are universal and have to reach all human beings, in every country on Earth. Human rights are universal and, therefore, the European Union has to work on them very cross-cuttingly, with a very clear commitment. You see, I believe that for the European Union to be respected in the world, without giving lessons, it should give some examples. Just a few days ago, a hundred children drowned on our shores of the Mediterranean. This is also the European Union's task in defence of human rights.

name: Karol Karski
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, with reference to the issue of respecting human rights in the world, I would like to touch on the issue of the persecution of Christians. It needs to be clearly and firmly emphasised that Christians remain the religious community which is persecuted on the largest scale in the world today. North Korea, Iran, Somalia, Afghanistan, Saudi Arabia, Libya, Syria, Iraq, Pakistan, the Central African Republic: these are only the most shameful examples in a group of about 50 countries in which persecution of the Christian religion is taking place on an unprecedented scale, including in some cases intimidation, refined acts of humiliation, abductions, rape, sophisticated torture, massacres and mass executions. According to the special report of the international agency Open Doors, more than 100 million Christians suffer from religious persecution. In addition, I would like to emphasise the fact that the European Union maintains diplomatic relations with most of the aforementioned countries, and has standing delegations there. I strongly recommend appealing to the heads of these delegations to submit special reports on acts taken with regard to protection of the rights of Christian minorities in the countries mentioned.

name: Charles Goerens
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Madam President, the European Union's annual report on human rights and democracy in the world leads me to make the following remarks: the worst violations are perpetrated where the State, deliberately or helplessly, does not or no longer fulfil its regal functions. This is particularly the case in the Middle East, where we must see with Brahimi the risk of this region becoming a warlord-dominated territory.  What are we doing about that? Very little, if we see the difficulties that refugees in this region have in finding a land of welcome. It was a statement of helplessness after the international community refused to intervene when the opposition to Assad implored us to do so.  State crisis or state crime, the hotbeds of crisis where populations are exposed defenceless to barbarism, alas, are becoming more and more numerous. Thus, in Africa and especially in the eastern part of Congo, where there is no longer even the appearance of public order, Dr. Mukwege notes that the woman's body has become a battlefield.  All of this makes us approach the human rights situation with great modesty. It is easier to take stock of atrocities than to take stock of the conflicts prevented - to put it in the words of Bernard-Henri Levy. This should not discourage us as the European Union from persevering in the path set out in its strategy to promote human rights and democracy on a global scale. On the contrary, if the Union continues tirelessly to intensify dialogue with its partners around the world, it will no doubt be able, not dramatically but nevertheless substantially, to make improvements in this area.  Finally, I would like Europe, always inclined to teach the rest of the world, to ensure that it is exemplary within its own borders. We're still a long way off.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Madam President, Commissioner, for the last five years I have been working here on human rights issues, as a Member of Parliament, I have been mixing bewilderment, anger and helplessness. It is with that in mind that I read your fifth report. Yes, since 2009, there have been improvements, but overall we are still far from it, far from a document that simply allows us to have a comprehensive analysis, to judge objectively what the European Union is doing in this area. I will take two cartoonish examples, but which I think will show the efforts to be made.  When I read in the Union's assessment of the matter that Mrs Ashton participated in the 150th anniversary of the Red Cross, I say to myself: who is being mocked? When I read that the European Union has helped China and Poland to have a dialogue on good practices on youth unemployment, I am thinking the same way. More seriously, because I like to be constructive, yes, the contribution of the European Parliament is better taken into account, but in order to move forward, as I have already said, the contact group must really work. We're a long way off. We need to see our emergencies really being closely monitored. So thank you Mr Lambridinis for all your efforts. I kind of want to tell you: thank god you're here.  Very concretely still, yes, there are focal points everywhere, but their effectiveness is very variable. So let's take a real look at that and work on that. The same applies to state-by-state strategies, which would be more operational if they were transparent, including to NGOs working in the countries concerned. The country-by-country analysis remains marked by a certain "double standard" contrary to a universalist vision of human rights. And let us not feed ourselves cultural, religious relativism, as we have just heard. All this would be even more convincing if the subjects were really carried by the High Representative, by the Member States and the new composition of the Commission. The Commissioner's mission letters are contrary to the priorities you have just outlined to us. You are well aware, Commissioner, that this is not the case, but there is still a whole world between the speeches and the actions of the European Union in this area.

name: Barbara Lochbihler
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her This report shows that there are many positive developments in the EU's human rights work, particularly as regards the structures and methods that have been created. However, it is an ongoing challenge to continue to work on policy coherence, as EU foreign policy is also an area of economic interest.  On the positive side, all EU delegations have now designated Focal Points for Human Rights. In addition, some have also created contact points specifically for human rights defenders. This has a real impact on the work of the activists on the ground, and the feedback to us in Parliament on this is consistently encouraging. Just over a week ago, we held a conference in Berlin on ten years of EU guidelines for the protection of human rights defenders. Here, too, we have heard that this is seen as very positive by activists on the ground. It has been noted that work should be extended, particularly in rural areas, and in particular support for female human rights defenders, and not least to help those who advocate self-determined female CVs. The report describes the work of the Special Representative, Mr Lambrinidis, in a positive light. I can only underline this. Both in exchanges with individual countries and in multilateral for a, his presence and commitment to the universality of human rights carry weight. I can only encourage you, Mr Lambrinidis, to continue this work in this sense in such a focused and targeted manner. However, if I look at the EU trade agreements and the task of applying criteria for the application of the human rights clause in them, my assessment is very sceptical. My question is therefore: how consistently will we apply this clause – especially when there is also a trade agreement with so-called strategic partners? I would also like to link this to the question: what does the Commission intend to do now? Will it change anything, including in its dealings with its strategic partner Russia? We also repeatedly address the results – or rather, the lack of results – of existing EU human rights dialogues. The report shows very specific suggestions for improvement. I hope that they will take effect. There is also talk of an impact assessment on individual human rights protection measures. I also see this as a positive thing, but we must, of course, see in concrete terms and in detail how these impact assessments are conducted. What is the practice, for example in China? However, I would also like to combine this with a specific criticism of an impact assessment – on the investment agreement with Burma, the so-called GSB+. This is because it completely disregards the human rights violations that still exist. Parliament has already called for the Commission to commit itself to complying with the GSB+ rules in the case of Burma. I also see a need for action for us here in Parliament in the implementation of the GSB+ rules. It would be very important for the Committee on Human Rights to be consulted with the Trade Committee when considering delegated acts in the CSB+ under the new rules. The report deals with the issue of business and human rights. There are sensible actions here, such as .B the human rights guidelines for three divisions. We will see that this is important later this morning, because it is about the work of human rights defenders in Azerbaijan and their threatening situation, because they are dealing with the oil and gas industry. The aim here, of course – and I believe that we very often have a disagreement between my group and the Commission – is that we should have binding human rights protection rules in the long term with regard to corporate activities. Volunteering is good, but it is not enough.  Then you will also see clearly, if you look at the action plan, that the measures listed on economic and cultural rights are much smaller than those in the area of civil and political rights. We also call on you to ensure a little more balance in this regard in the future. Finally, yesterday we discussed the resolution on the fight against the Terrorist Militia Islamic State. It is necessary here that the Commission should look at ensuring that the mistakes made in the so-called war on terror of recent years are not repeated and that it is always examined whether the measures are in line with international law and human rights standards.

name: Bill Etheridge
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, here we go again, with yet another good cause and good words hijacked and twisted for a battle cry for the liberal elite who run this place; a way to allow human rights to become no more than a charter for international human rights lawyers like the odious Cherie Blair to make a fortune. The EU tells us that we must let it regulate our emissions from our factories or the world will end. It tells us to join closer together or our external enemies will defeat us or, worse still, will fight each other. It now tells us that it must dictate human rights to the whole world. That is cultural imperialism. We should think more of justice, not of these so-called rights. Think of 1993: a 14-year-old girl called Jennifer Ertman and a 16-year-old called Elizabeth Peña were gang-raped and murdered in Texas. A gentleman called José Medellín was sentenced to death. In 2005 the EU intervened with a legal case. It used our money to defend a child raping murderous monster. That is not rights; that is not what we believe in, surely. Recently, Randy Ertman, the father of Jennifer, died after a lifetime spent supporting victims’ rights.  Human rights are not granted by this place and this is cultural imperialism. All human beings need the right to freedom of expression and the expression of their opinions, but most importantly the right to wield justice just like that which this place sought to deny Jennifer. It is time for Britain to leave the EU and to lead the way to true justice, as we always have. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Molly Scott Cato (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card question. – I am not sure that Mr Etheridge entirely has the point about what we are doing here when we defend human rights. What we are trying to do is support people who are fighting for democracy and in countries where their attempt to get the basic civil rights that he enjoys lands them up being tortured and in jail. That is what we are actually doing today. I would like to ask him: does he believe in democracy? Does he believe that others have the right to self-expression which he has himself just enjoyed in this place?

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: blue-card answer. – I passionately believe in those things: that is why I am a member of UKIP, in the EFDD Group. I believe in direct democracy, I believe in freedom of expression and I believe in the democracy that is denied to so many people under the auspices of this place and these institutions. I would remind you that, in the West Midlands, we won: UKIP won. And across the whole of England, UKIP won. We are representing the democratic views of the British people.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (NI). -
text: Madam President, we can only welcome the European Union's annual report on human rights and democracy in the world.  But for 2014, it would also be a matter of explaining, in the future, why the European Union has supported and continues to support Kosovo, whose profile of the leaders is criminal.  Why, in our culture of democracy and human rights, have we accepted in Ukraine the signing of agreements with the government of Mr Yanukovych, democratically elected in November 2013, while a Western-backed coup was being prepared? Is that the rule of law? Why didn't we reveal that pro-Maidan snipers were shooting at the pro-Maidan population? Were human rights preventing us from doing so? Why did we accept elections in a country in civil war, when we usually support a government of national unity and then we conduct elections? So did democracy fear elections in a peaceful Ukraine?  Why did we accept that the Kiev government would bomb its people? The result is three thousand deaths, ten thousand deaths according to other figures,

name: Teresa Jiménez-Becerril Barrio (PPE). -
text: Mr President, the european Union's work to advance its values and principles at the international level is undeniable. The Union's foreign relations policy has as one of its main objectives the universality of human rights throughout the world: the world looks to us to defend them and we cannot disappoint them. But there are many countries where fundamental rights are violated and where many people are not guaranteed. The lack of freedom to live their religion is a clear example of these human rights violations. Every day we find continuous massacres of minorities in Iraq and Syria, with particular effect on the Christian community, whose members are forced to renounce their religion; if not, they are exterminated. Christians in the East look to us with the despair of those who need to be protected. The Archbishop of Baghdad told us on his last visit to this Parliament: "We need help not because we are Christians, but because we are human beings." I welcome the fact that this report concerns the negative impact of terrorist acts that have been increasing in Iraq, but I miss a greater commitment to the consequences of terrorism in the world, including Europe.  This report abounds in the abuses committed in the fight against terrorism, and it is necessary to point them out when they exist, but I must say that the text should express a stronger condemnation of the global rise in terrorism and make clearer mentions about the victims of terrorism. In my opinion it is therefore un balanced.  Human rights have no meaning for terrorists: they feed on barbarism and utter contempt for human life. Examples include cases such as girls in Boko Haram, Nigeria; the case also of the abduction of girls from religious minorities in Iraq, who are used as sex slaves; or the heinous killings of journalists and co-operators doing humanitarian work. I call on the international community not to let its guard down in the face of the escalation of terrorism that we are experiencing, because only united can we say loud and clear to terrorists that we love freedom and life more than they love repression and death.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri (S&D). -
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we consider the annual report to be important because it is the instrument for informing the institutions and citizens about the policies implemented by the European Union. For us, it is also a way of assessing the state of implementation of the strategic framework of the European Union's action plan on human rights and democracy. There is, however, one thing that I believe needs to be resolved, and quickly. The report lacks precise indicators of progress or decline compared with the previous year, and without this type of indicator it is difficult to assess the effectiveness of European policies. To date, the European Union has developed human rights strategies for almost all countries. It would be appropriate for the observations, critical issues and objectives contained in these strategies to be made clear in the report. This is one of the particularly important aspects, because these country strategies are still classified as documents for internal and non-public use.  With regard to the strategic framework, our view is that we regard the adoption of the strategic framework of the action plan launched in 2012 as a milestone. The fact that this strategy has been complemented by the mandate of the EU Special Representative for Human Rights makes it all the more important. However, this strategy is essentially completed this year. We need to relaunch it very strongly, and the start of a new action plan scheduled for January 2015 must be a reason for having proper consultation with both Parliament and civil society. Finally, the European Union Special Representative has done a very good job, and that is why we would basically like the European Council to renew its mandate, giving the Special Representative, above all, greater powers to achieve the objectives of the European strategy, the action plans and to ensure that Article 21 of the Treaty is implemented through concrete policies.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR). -
text: The European Union is preparing a document on freedom of religion. I want to ask how the work on these texts has progressed and how freedom of religion is defined there. According to data from 2011, 76% of Europeans subscribe to Christianity, but the word Christian is not even mentioned there. There is general talk of freedom of religion, but the rights of religious groups, such as Muslims, are mentioned much more often. Also, in the report of the European Union Agency for Human Rights 'Fundamental rights: challenges and achievements for 2011', the word Christian is not even mentioned. I would ask the Commission to take the right to freedom of religion seriously when preparing these documents, taking into account how many citizens subscribe to Christianity. I would also like to call on the European Commission to take more serious citizens' views. I am disillusioned with the Commission's position on the most successful European initiative, called One of Us, which also concerned human rights, namely the unborn. Unfortunately, the fact that almost a million 800 000 citizens have expressed their opinion, which the Commission has literally swept off the table, is damaging the image of the European institutions ... (speaker ad interrupted)

name: Marietje Schaake (ALDE). -
text: Madam President, the number of people whose human rights are violated in one way or another is overwhelming. Many of them look to us for help and support and we must offer what we can. But underlying the many different forms of violation – from rape and torture to censorship and discrimination – is a wave that is swelling, an increasingly successful challenge to the very principles that define us and that we are defending globally. The universality of human rights itself has perhaps never been as threatened as it is today. The EU is in a great position to lead an unequivocal defence of the universality of human rights but we can only lead by example. It puts us to shame and weakens our credibility when, in Europe, Viktor Orban openly pushes illiberal democracy, when minorities face discrimination, when women do not have equal pay, treatment and opportunities, when technology is used for illegitimate surveillance and hacking in Europe or exported to dictators and terrorist organisations which are not curbed, or when the crisis is used as an excuse not to implement corporate social responsibility or trade conditionalities. We can see that the line between internal and external policies is not a sharp one and we are interconnected but if, together, we do not show leadership and strategically leverage our political and economic position, who will defend the universality of human rights?

name: Peter Lundgren (EFDD). -
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by congratul We are talking here today about human rights and democracy in the world. I wonder how democracy can be taught when democracy is not even understood in this House. It's just as bad when you go to our individual nations.  I can see in my own country, Sweden, where we have just had a national election. My party got 13 percent of the vote. The first thing that happens is that we are discussing how to exclude ourselves from having any influence whatsoever in politics. Do you call it respecting a democratic election when you exclude 13% of the country's voters? This circus continues when you come here to Parliament. When you do not get what you want, you try to exclude groups, just as we did here in the case of the Committee on Petitions, when you practically stole a chairmanship that was important to the EFDD Group. It's not democracy. You do not know what the word democracy means. This is not how it's supposed to work. You have to respect the rules that exist. That is democracy. In addition, we have a President, Mr Schulz, who completely lacks the most basic knowledge of democracy. It is to accept the views of others other than their own while maintaining respect. He doesn't know how to do that. We saw on Tuesday when we signed the agreement with Ukraine that lots of people on the left are standing up and shouting about getting the floor, and Schulz asks if anyone has anything to add. Then he denies the people on the left to the floor. It is directly embarrassing to be represented by such a President in this House.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI). -
text: The European Union does not lose the opportunity every time to play the 'sensitive' to the issues of democratic freedoms and so-called human rights. It has by no means empowered the peoples to intervene around the world and to express these 'concerns' which are increasing as dictated by the respective interests of the monopolies it serves. Its deliberately selective sensitivity obviously does not apply in the case of Mexico where, only in the last year, they have been murdered by gangs and mechanisms in interconnection with portions of the local bourgeoisie; Their action disturbs the mining monopolies that displace poor farmers from the land. The Federal Government of Mexico, as well as the State Government of Mexico, and the State Authorities, are not the only one who has the right to a ・ ; ・'・•I'm not going to be able to do anything about it, but I'm going to have to do it.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE). -
text: In recent times, not a day has passed without hearing of very serious human rights violations around the world. I am thinking here of the persecution of Christians in Iraq and Syria, which we debated yesterday afternoon, but there is terrible news in the media about the large number of children and child victims in these countries. And we also know that thousands of children and women are currently living overnight in refugee camps, where as the cold approachs, their situation becomes more difficult and it becomes more difficult to survive. We must therefore do everything we can to protect Christians from the atrocities that evoked the Dark Ages. Children and women deprived of their human rights must be protected from the horrors of a growing number of wars and armed conflicts anywhere in the world.  I would also like to speak here in particular about the protection of linguistic and national minorities. After all, very little is said about these communities. Yet we are talking about millions of people all over the world whose most basic human rights are being violated, and who are fighting every day for survival and survival in their homeland. We need a stand on the part of the European Parliament and on the part of the European Union. And I believe that there is a need not only for response, but also for prevention, and that this has a role to play and more roles for the Commissioner for Foreign Affairs, for the Commission, for the EU delegations. We also expect more consequences following the European Parliament's emergency human rights decisions, which in practice remain words that often cry out for wilderness.  At the same time, I would also like to say that I am very sorry that some colleagues are using this debate for their own political and political purposes, because there are a lot of problems in the world that should be talked about really seriously and something should be done, not only to wait for an ex-post response, but also to try to act before doing so.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D). -
text: Madam President! I believe that the European Parliament can be proud of its annual report on the situation of human rights and democracy in the world.  It allows us to take stock and improve our strategies and methods. This report also underlines, above all, the seriousness with which Europe is addressing human rights issues. They are an important criterion of European foreign policy, and it would be desirable for this to become even more visible, especially when the protection of human rights conflicts with other interests, economic or geopolitical. The world is watching very closely to see if we are really serious about our human rights policy.  The Union has created very good instruments to guarantee the sustainability and coherence of its human rights policy: the European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights and the Special Representative for Human Rights, whom I would like to congratulate most warmly on his positive work. I think it is a good thing that European human rights policy also sets the tone in terms of content and, in addition to traditional priorities, also highlights current aspects such as the protection of fundamental rights on the Internet. Here again, however, the question of credibility arises. Unfortunately, although we have dealt with this many times in this House, we have not drawn any conclusions from the NSA affair. It must also be thoughtful that, while we are holding our plenary session here, hundreds of people are dying trying to cross the Mediterranean. This has something to do with human rights.

name: Ryszard Czarnecki (ECR). -
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. This debate is very important because it is not suspended in a vacuum. It comes at a time when human rights, including religious rights, are being brutally violated in many countries. This debate comes at a time when, it is worth pointing out, thousands of Christians are dying not only in Iraq and Syria, but also in African countries. It seems to me that the voice of our Parliament should be very strong, very unequivocal, so that it is a loud voice, that these are not just words, that they follow this action, so that, for example, the European Union, whether the countries concerned respect human rights, make aid to these countries conditional, economic aid, and I think that this must finally start to apply.

name: António Marinho e Pinto (ALDE). -
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, poverty is now a qualified violation of human rights and democracy. It reaches its main victims at the source from which all personal rights emanashe: human dignity. The effective defence of human rights and the fight against its violations will be nothing more than rhetorical proclamations without a serious and consequential fight against poverty, which today affects millions of people around the world, including within the European Union itself. The eradication of poverty does not depend solely on economic measures, or on economic development itself. Its elimination depends mainly on policies, on political will. A serious fight against poverty will in itself be a factor in economic development and the enhancement of democracy. It is possible to eradicate poverty. It is mandatory to do so as soon as possible.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL). -
text: Madam President, I have heard a report full of good intentions. It's something I celebrate. What happens is that it could give multiple examples of European Union interests that are put above human rights. In this case, I'm going to talk about something that affects us in my country. It's the situation with Morocco. As I have seen, Morocco is the state that benefits most from its relationship with the European Union. It also has an advanced statute. And even though the Agreements of the European Union are subject to the fulfilment of human rights, Morocco commits serious violations of international law and human rights. For example, in the Sahara, of which it is an occupying power and in which it fails to comply with the mandate of the United Nations, delaying and hindering the process of decolonization. In addition, it commits very serious attacks on the people of the occupied territories. It's funny, before Tunisia there was an Arab spring in the Sahara and we didn't know anything. For example, prisoners in the Gdeim Izik group of the Camps of Dignity sentenced, in February 2013, by a Moroccan military court: twenty-five civilians tried; eight sentenced to life in prison; four, thirty-four, twenty-five years old. It's funny: When are we worried about citizen movements? Only when they are enemy countries. There is no talk of changing the Moroccan regime, but about cooperation to improve governance. They are not required to comply with human rights, but are made recommendations. I hope we take this into account in trade agreements.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI). -
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Sister Lucia Pulici, seventy-five years old, from Desio, Sister Olga Raschietti, eighty-three years old, from Montecchio Maggiore, Vicenza, Sister Bernadetta Boggian, seventy-nine years of Ospedaletto Euganeo, Padua. Three Italian nuns were killed on 7 September in their convent in Burundi, who defended human rights on the ground and to the full. My thoughts go out to them, to their families, to their communities, to the many missionaries who have fought and are fighting for human rights every day.  Is Europe aware that Christian countries peacefully tolerate the activities of other religious denominations on their territory, whereas the same principle does not apply in any way to Muslim countries? Every year about one hundred and five thousand Christians are killed at the hands of fundamentalists, that is, one every five minutes. It means that three Christians died during the Commissioner's speech. I asked Baroness Ashton for a European day against the persecution and oppression of Christians and was told no. It is a disgrace, I do not like this Europe.

name: Gabrielius Landsbergis (PPE). -
text: Madam President, first of all let me say a thank you for the considerable work that went into the preparation of the report, but let me also draw attention to the human rights situation right on the border of the European Union. The Tatar nation, which faced horrible persecution and sufferings during the Stalin era, is now facing the same situation again. As we speak, full-scale discriminatory action against Tatars is underway in Crimea. Their homes are being searched and their leader is not allowed to enter the country. People are being persecuted just for keeping religious literature in their homes. So I call upon the EU to show clear support and solidarity with Crimean Tatars, whose basic rights are being violated in their own homeland, which is under illegal occupation. Discrimination and human rights abuse in Russia has reached new heights as well, even when compared to the Soviet Union. As you may know, mothers of the Russian soldiers who are fighting in Ukraine have formed an association, but this association has now been called a ‘foreign agent’ and therefore could be banned, just because they announced that their children are dying in the war in Ukraine.  I think I can say that Mr Andrei Sakharov, whom we honour every year when we nominate the most important defenders of human rights, would himself be persecuted and named a foreign agent by Mr Putin and his regime.  Therefore, I call for the implementation of the EU Strategic Framework and Action Plan on human rights and democracy, this and the next year, to focus the necessary attention and resources in particular on the above-mentioned groups on the eastern border of the EU. If we cannot stop the violations in the countries that are closest to us, that not only weakens the position of the European Union but also sends a very bad signal to all countries that are seeking deeper cooperation with the EU. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Paul Rübig (PPE)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr Landsbergis, I would like to thank Mr Landsbergis for his work on this I would be interested to know how do you view the human rights situation in Kaliningrad – which is on the border with the European Union – and how do you see the developments here?

name: Gabrielius Landsbergis (PPE)
text: blue-card answer. – For the moment we do not see any real developments in Kaliningrad concerning human rights violations. The more important issues in Kaliningrad are increasing militarisation that threatens the region’s stability. That is what I would like to stress.

name: Francisco Assis (S&D). -
text: Madam President, the proclamation of the principle of universality of human rights is not cultural imperialism, it is a civilizational advance, and it is probably the main legacy of modern European and Western thought for the world, which greatly increases our obligations in this area.  We well know that a foreign policy cannot be reduced to a mere proclamation of human rights. It would perhaps be ineffective if it were to. But a foreign policy that does not include as a central concern also the issue of respect for human rights would be a foreign policy too cynical in the face of the values that should constantly inspire us. And so I want to welcome this report, because with all the shortcomings it can contain, and it will contain some, it means the achievement of one of the greatest commitments of our European project: the commitment to promoting the protection of human rights in all parts of the world.  And that is why we have to be attentive both to Christians, who are persecuted today in the Middle East, and to mexican communists, who, as mentioned here by a colleague of ours, will also have been persecuted in Mexico. That is why we have to be aware of all those who are the object of persecution because that is where the whole issue lies and that is why the principle of universality of human rights cannot contemporize any idea of cultural relativism or political relativism, which, if taken into account, would put them at issue at all.  I also acknowledge in my colleague who has just mentioned the importance of combating poverty, because poverty at global level is unequivocally one of the greatest attacks on the dignity of the human person.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR). -
text: Madam President! We are talking about European human rights policy, including European foreign and security policy.  We have a 'High Representative' for this, and I have three questions: how many people do they even know that we have an EU foreign minister? Who knows the name of this Foreign Minister? In Germany, 85% of people do not even know the name of Jean-Claude Juncker! Who knows the face of the High Representative? I bet she could sit down in the Chamber here, and some Members would not notice.  On 23 June, the Council stated that the EU's human rights policy was strengthened. There are guidelines for the defence of freedom of religion and belief. The EU even has a human rights envoy, and he is supposedly even here today.  In Syria and Iraq, Islamist mass murderers play football with the battered heads of Christians and other minorities. Children are crucified and I think there are women who wish to die.  Has the Secretary of State made her voice heard? What do we hear about the Human Rights Commissioner here in the world? Deafening silence in my ears. I propose that we delete both posts and send the millions saved to Christians and the other persecuted minorities in Iraq and Syria.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL). -
text: Madam President, there is simply not enough time to address all the necessary issues in this debate. We have little to celebrate this year. While the EU engages in geopolitical stalemate, many people within the EU like women, third country nationals and LGBTI individuals to name just three, still struggle to have their rights recognised. However, one issue I wish to briefly highlight is the ongoing shameful lack of action of the European Union on the situation in Palestine. The EU-Palestinian Authority’s European Neighbourhood Policy Action Plan, adopted by the Council in June, envisages a Palestinian state based on the rule of law, full respect for human rights, development of democratic values and the promotion of a vibrant civil society. Recent events show that this is far from happening and, by continuing trade relations with Israel, the EU condones their actions and plays a part in the oppression of the Palestinian people and the continuing denial of human rights. There are no human rights without freedom and peace. There is no point celebrating human rights defenders when the EU does not defend human rights itself and takes no action against Israel’s gross violation of human rights and allows it to act with impunity and carry out crimes against humanity under human rights and international law. So rather than boasting about what the EU does to uphold human rights, the EU stands accused, unfortunately, of being complicit in crimes against humanity.

name: Mariya Gabriel (PPE). -
text: Madam President, Commissioner, Mr Special Representative, I will keep repeating that the place given to human rights and democracy is the real added value of the Union's foreign policy. As such, the annual report is a valuable resource for improving the work of the Union.  I would like to highlight four points: first, the mandate of the Special Representative for Human Rights ends next year. We must be careful that this position is renewed but, once again, above all, that the Special Representative is given the means to really play his role, to give coherence, effectivity and visibility to the Union as a promoter of human rights. The second element of the report that I wish to focus on is women's rights and gender equality. It seems to me that 2013 was full of initiatives in this area. For example, the integration of a women's rights adviser into 70% of civilian and military operations, the "zero tolerance" initiative for female genital mutilation, the women's network of diplomatic service. I can only encourage the next High Representative to continue these efforts. Women's rights are part of human rights and we know how decisive the role of women is in countries in transition or pacification, so that sustainable solutions are put in place.  Thirdly, I will stress the missions of electoral monitoring to assess the implementation of the recommendations made by the Union's election observation missions. When the 2012 annual report was published, I remember calling for better follow-up. In 2013, three missions were deployed. In 2014, I myself led the mission to the Democratic Republic of Congo. This makes our support and messages to partners more effective, credible and consistent.  Finally, I will stress the coherence between, on the one hand, our different external policies and, on the other hand, between our internal and external policies. The cross-cutting of human rights must be ensured in trade policy with strategic partners, in our security policies, asylum or migration policies or the example of the fight against terrorism, and in the coherence between our external and internal policies, if necessary, to maintain our credibility as a defender of human rights and as a reliable partner.

name: Richard Howitt (S&D). -
text: Madam President, I worked on the human rights report this year and the achievements it reflects, in particular the creation of the new human rights dialogue with Burma to seek to contribute to the process of transition in that country, the agreement of new guidelines to respect the human rights of LGBTI people and for freedom of religion and belief, the agreement of the updated instrument on the European Initiative for Democracy and Human Rights in which this Parliament was a partner, and the conduct of successful election observation missions during the year, including in Pakistan where I was present myself and where our presence is proving to make such a real difference in defending democracy. To the EEAS and the Commission I stressed that the report presages moving to a new phase where the priority must be not drafting country human rights strategy papers but implementing them, not appointing human rights Focal Points but seeing them work, not in an action plan but in action, full stop. As Parliament is fully aware of my special interest in corporate responsibility, you will understand that it is right to recall that 2013 was the year of the tragic Rana Plaza factory collapse in Bangladesh, leaving more than 1000 people dead, people who stitched clothes for high street shops in the capitals across Europe, highlighting how progress in the EU on implementation of the UN guiding principles on business and human rights is both necessary and as yet insufficient.

name: Bas Belder (ECR). -
text: Freedom of faith is a great thing, especially in Cuba. Therefore, because of the evangelical churches there, with which I am in contact, I pass on to the Council and the Commission the following wishes, which must be a prerequisite in improving relations. First, freedom to print own Christian magazines. Secondly, the broadcasting of Christian programmes on television and radio. Third, the official recognition of evangelical churches, as well as ownership of churches and buildings. Fourthly, and certainly in view of the abject poverty, freedom for the Church to engage as a recognised institution social activity in childcare, elderly care and – certainly not insignificant in Cuba – meal facilities. Finally, freedom for the Cuban churches to receive direct spiritual and material assistance from churches in Europe, without interference from the Cuban state. Council and Commission, former colleague Lambrinidis, I have known you for a long time. I trust that, if you are in contact with the Cuban authorities, these are essential conditions. [The President interrupts the speaker here.]

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo (S&D). -
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen of the Commission, I believe in your work; I think what you do is important. We are not perfect; there are many contradictions, but that is the evolution of the world. I believe that you do an important job of making Europe a beacon of civilization in the world. And I want to give you two tips regarding Latin America which I think is important to cite in a special way. First, I think it is very important that European companies investing and working in this world that has globalized production, which invest and work in Latin America, do so in compliance with the labour rights and environmental rights of the communities where they operate. We have serious problems in Latin America because of the way many European companies operate. I would recommend that we look at the problems created in this area because, as Mr Howitt said, corporate social responsibility is a very important thing in the culture of human rights compliance around the world. And secondly, I believe that our eyes, our ears know about human rights violations by NGOs, by the thousands of volunteers, by the thousands of people working around the world, also in Latin America – European and Latin American – in the defense of human rights. They have to receive our help; they have to get our support. It seems to me that this is an important second point to make a second report, next year, even better.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE). -
text: Madam Vice-President, I welcome Commissioner Mimica, with whom we are now having a discussion in the second framework after the one on different sides of the European Parliament election campaign, but we are now on the same side of protecting human rights in the world and in particular taking into account that human rights are respected within the Member States of the European Union.  I also appreciate the efforts and work in the last two years that the Special Representative for Human Rights, Mr Lambrinidis, has undertaken in protecting human rights, their universality, multilateral cooperation especially with the Council of Europe which is here in Strasbourg and to whom human rights, i.e. the protection of them, are the main activity, as well as with the United Nations.  It seems to me that human rights and their protection must be a permanent and mandatory, continuous part of all foreign policy activities of the European Union, we must take care of this in all instruments, and we have provided sufficient resources to protect them over the next seven years. I also think we need to make a special effort to protect Christians in Iraq and Syria.

name: Renato Soru (S&D). -
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I agree that the work that has been done is an important work for which we must all thank, but I would like to remind you of what happened this weekend in the Strait of Sicily, that stretch of sea between Libya, Malta and Italy: about seven hundred people have died. More people have died in that stretch of sea since the beginning of the year than in Gaza. In that stretch of sea you live a war in peacetime. That stretch of sea is on europe's doorstep. A war that is not far from us, it is on Europe's doorstep, it concerns us, it concerns thousands of people who look to Europe as a promised land, who look to Europe as a place to finally arrive, spending their lives and talents fleeing war, extermination, racial persecution sometimes, persecution and the total absence of civil rights. I believe that Europe needs to look more closely. It is time to put caution aside and review the Dublin regulations and look at what is happening and it concerns us so closely. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Giulia Moi (EFDD)
text: Blue card question. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to address my colleague on human rights and on putting an end to this massacre that is taking place in our sea: how do you want to reconcile it with the fact that in Italy you have financed the purchase of thirty-five fighter-bombers at a cost of several billion each?

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: Answer to a blue card question. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it is very simple: I have never financed any purchase of fighter-bombers, I have never even fired a shot with a gun or a rifle, I am here doing my job, your question must be submitted to others.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE). -
text: Madam Chairman, I see this report positively, I see it optimistically and I think it is well placed, because Europe must definitely be the main promoter of human rights in the world. Objectively, apart from our continent, we can sort of say, there is no one else who truly truly, and in the way we do, fights for human rights everywhere in the world.  However, another fact should be stated. The human rights situation in the world has probably never been worse. We have really disgusting situations, terrible situations, but I wouldn't just talk about the most difficult situations. We will also talk about those situations that are so-called easy human rights violations, but for me there are no serious or easy human rights violations. There's a violation of human rights. And that is why I would like to remind those who are the loudest in this Parliament that I have won elections a dozen times with the slogan: diversity is our richness, tolerance is our strength. I hope others will.

name: Εμμανουήλ Γλέζος (GUE/NGL). -
text: I haven't started talking yet, and the timer counts. The right, "the water" that the ancient Greeks used to say, that is, the right to speak, I claim. I haven't started my speech yet! Why is the timer starting to count? Dear President, I haven't started talking yet, and the timer counts. I strongly protest because you are stealing my speaking time, you are strangling my right to expression. name: James Carver (EFDD). -
text: Madam President, there is an old saying that if you put something under your nose you do not see it. I would like to draw attention to a human rights issue here in the European Union, and that is the despicable treatment of Roma gypsies in some Eastern European countries, which has led to large numbers moving away to seek a better life in Western Europe. As has been well reported in the British media, we have huge social tensions and problems now in Sheffield and in London. I speak probably as the only Member of this Chamber who is from British Romany descent by virtue of my Nanna, Rose. The metropolitan elite in my country tend to treat travellers as one specific people, but there are Irish Travellers, British Romany, New Age travellers and Showmen. We are all very different people who need to be treated very differently. I say to the EU it should put its own house in order and deal with the problems of the Roma travellers in Eastern Europe before seeking to go elsewhere across the world.

name: Eduard Kukan (PPE). -
text: Today's debate also shows that the situation in Ukraine and the Islamic State's progress in the Middle East are the two most important crises. They are also closely linked to our efforts to defend the values on which the EU is built: the democratic political establishment and respect for civil liberties. Last year, we called for the themes of human rights and democracy to play a more important role in the Union's external relations. We have called for a more systematic and effective promotion of human rights and democracy in the world. As rapporteur for last year's EU human rights report, I will repeat what I said back then. The protests in Ukraine and the Arab Spring have reminded us that people are not going to get over the restrictions on human rights and want to decide the direction of their countries. And it is our duty to help them in this.

name: Liisa Jaakonsaari (S&D). -
text: Mr President, I share Mr Soru's idea that perhaps one of the greatest human rights violations of this time is that the Mediterranean is becoming the grave of tens of thousands of people. I believe that this is something that we really need to tackle more forcefully.  It is a great thing that we now have the External Action Service and a specialist in human rights and that all these instruments are starting to be in order. We must now focus in particular on trade agreements. I myself have been rapporteur for the Kazakhstan-EU trade agreement, and it has been a little sad to see that the negotiations are progressing, but the human rights situation in the country is deteriorating. I believe that Parliament must up to its right to intervene in the content of these trade agreements until the end before they are concluded.

name: Pablo Echenique (GUE/NGL). -
text: Madam President, the truth is that I can think of few sets of principles more important than human rights and I think it is very important that reports are made on this. However, I am surprised by the look, always outward and so little inward, with which the European Union deals with this issue. It is very nice for us to monitor human rights compliance beyond our borders, but perhaps it would also be interesting to look a little inward. Look a little at people with disabilities, people who lose their homes, people who can't put heating in winter, people looking for food in containers, immigrants who are locked in detention centers... We could also use a report on these human rights violations.

name: Soraya Post (S&D). -
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by congratul Actually, I had questions, but the people I wanted to ask are not in the room today. However, I would like to make a few comments. I agree with some speakers who have expressed continued support for Mr Lambrinidi's work. So do I. There is a major crisis in Europe, throughout the world. I was also going to say that this is a top priority at all, also in view of far-right parties that are emerging in our democratic for a and then destroying democracy. It is strange that those who talk most about democracy and human rights are the very people who choose to say human rights to Christians. What about everyone else? I am also thinking of Járóka. You're not the only Rum, now I'm also a Roma woman here. I have experienced and experienced all these violations. Today, in 2014, there are almost no Roma in the EU or outside the EU who are given access to human rights in any area – rights that are universal, indivisible and indeed effective worldwide. It should not have to be set group-to-group in order to be recognised and to experience the equal value and dignity of all people. There is much to be done, and I support it.

name: Neven Mimica
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. - Madam President, I would like to thank honourable Members for this very fruitful debate. I can assure you that your constructive remarks are well noted and will be duly considered. We take note of your recommendation to support and step up cooperation with the European Ombudsman. It is an excellent idea and complements our determination to support civil society. I fully agree with you that we need to develop indicators to measure the impact of our actions. This is precisely one of our objectives and we look forward to discussing this issue with you, including in the contact group, to which we are committed. Thank you also for your positive words about our work on human rights defenders around the world and your appreciation for the excellent work done by Special Representative Stavros Lambrinidis. Rest assured that we make every effort to make our human rights dialogues result-oriented and to see that all agreements contain effective human rights clauses, as foreseen in our action plan, and to broaden our action beyond civil and political rights to economic cultural and social rights. I would like to assure you that we are making – and shall be making – every effort to alleviate the plight of Christian communities and ethnic minorities in the Middle East and worldwide. Those responsible must be made accountable.  I fully agree that future annual reports should be the outcome of active and constructive discussions among EU institutions. This also means that, during this exercise, we should seek full use of parliamentary diplomacy in promoting human rights in the world. We could not agree more that maximising our internal-external coherence is of huge importance. If we want our policies to be fully efficient in this process, the role of Parliament is vital. Mainstreaming human rights into all our external policies, especially into development policy, is an ongoing process and, despite progress so far, it is imperative that we step up our efforts. Let me underline once more our engagement to continue to work in this direction together with all stakeholders, including the Commission and Parliament. Our achievements are numerous but our endeavours are not finished. We need to continuously fight against all actions that threaten the universality, indivisibility and interdependence of human rights. We need to voice further our human rights concern with our partners at all levels and in all forms of dialogues and contacts.  Challenges do not only come from the outside, which is why we will strive to achieve the most challenging objective – integrating human rights in all EU external policies such as trade, development, conflict prevention, counter-terrorism and other areas. We have made progress but need to continue to work in that direction, including a human-rights-based approach to development and in business, together with Parliament, the Commission, Member States, civil societies and other stakeholders. We can all be proud that these past years illustrate a strengthened EU human rights policy. Today we can be proud of our achievements but should also renew our engagement to address the many challenges we have around the world. Let me conclude by praising once more the proactive role of Parliament on human rights and reiterating our commitment to work closely with it.

name: Preşedinte. -
text: The debate on this subject has been closed. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing.– I welcome the Annual Report on Human Rights and I am proud of the role played by the European Parliament as a champion of democracy and human rights. It is encouraging that almost 150 human rights country strategies were adopted and, at a civil society level, more than 530 new EIDHR 1 initiatives were launched. It is important that all actors should continue to promote human rights, democracy and the rule of law, and in particular to abolish the death penalty, combat torture, and fight racism and other forms of discrimination. However, the challenge remains for the newly agreed country human rights strategy papers to be fully implemented and to uphold human rights through the EU’s trade, investment and development actions. We see everyday stories and images of great suffering which lead us to realise that further urgent action is needed. The Action Plan will help us to ensure continued progress and we should make all the efforts to implement the EU Strategic Framework on Human Rights and Democracy, with adequate flexibility so as to respond to new challenges as they arise. We should continue to step up our efforts and provide help to peoples in need around the world.
