name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE). -
text: Your predecessor in the chair office missed the opportunity to give the opportunity for a Democratic debate that earned the name "catch the eye" and did not give me a say. I regret this and I hope that this instrument will actually become an instrument of dialogue in Parliament, not declamations and monologue.

name: Preşedinte. -
text: It is the prerogative of the Vice-President. Thank you very much.

name: Arne Gericke
text: Author. - (DE) Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for the excellent work he has In May 2012, Baku, the capital of Azerbaijan, hosted the Eurovision Song Contest. The motto of the event: Light your fire. Even then, the country was criticized; Human rights organisations have long complained of democratic deficits. As always, women, children and the elderly are particularly affected. Only in recent weeks have human rights violations shaken even experienced Azerbaijani experts. I am glad that we are naming and condemning these incidents here in this House. I expect the new European Commission to give a clear voice to human rights as an unwavering part of our neighbourhood policy and, in particular, our economic policy. It was Anke Engelke, the German presenter of the Eurovision Song Contest 2012, who was the only one of 47 television professionals to have the courage to criticize the human rights situation in Azerbaijan when awarding points. I quote: 'It is good to be able to vote. It is good to have a choice. Good luck on your journey, Azerbaijan! Europe is watching you." I would like to add: people and human rights activists in Azerbaijan, Europe is still on your side today. And I would like to encourage all of us: Light your fire for human rights!

name: Alexander Graf Lambsdorff
text: author. - Madam President, it is good to see you there and I regret that we will not have this opportunity for much longer but congratulations on your appointment.  The situation in Azerbaijan is extremely worrisome. Due to the crisis in Ukraine, the Middle East, Iraq, we have been looking at other places but it is good that we now turn our attention to this country where the situation for human rights defenders has got worse and worse. The government has intensified its already authoritarian crackdown on independent political and other public voices in Azerbaijan. According to Human Rights Watch and according to Freedom House, the authorities have imprisoned at least 40 political activists, human rights defenders, journalists and others, on various trumped-up charges including drug possession, tax evasion and even treason in the last two years. In a dramatic escalation since last July the government rounded up the country’s most senior human rights and other public figures, imprisoning them on politically-motivated charges. These include Leyla Yunus, the well-known director of the Institute for Peace and Democracy, and her husband, the historian Arif Yunus, Rasul Jafarov, Chair of Azerbaijan’s Human Rights Club, and Intigam Aliyev, the highly respected Chair of the Legal Education Society. They were all part of a group compiling a comprehensive list of victims of politically-motivated arrests in Azerbaijan. Now they are on that list.  In addition, the governmentʼs already tough restrictions on the activities of non-governmental organisations have been further tightened. Many groups have been effectively forced to shut down after their bank accounts were frozen or their sources of funding blocked.  On the other hand, Azerbaijan is making the most of new opportunities to boost its international profile. In a perverse twist – there is no other word to express it – Azerbaijan in May assumed a prestigious position in Europe’s leading human rights body, the rotating chairmanship of the Committee of Ministers of the Council of Europe, and on 24 June President Ilham Aliyev used his speech before the Council’s Permanent Assembly in Strasbourg to deny any human rights problems and to call his critics liars. Only four weeks later all his critics were proven right.

name: Josef Weidenholzer
text: Author. - (DE) Madam President, I would like to thank Azerbaijan has been a member of the Council of Europe for 13 years, and this is an important achievement for that country and for Europe. At present, it even presides. At the heart of the Council of Europe is the European Convention on Human Rights, and Azerbaijan must be judged by these standards. Despite official assertions, the human rights situation has been constantly deteriorating and the scope of NGOs is being systematically restricted. On flimsy pretexts, people who exercise their right to freedom of expression are harassed and sentenced to prison. During his visit two weeks ago, Commissioner Füle praised the commitment of civil society in the face of such conditions and assured the european Union's full attention.  It is against this background that our resolution must be seen. It deals with a number of cases, such as Aliyev and Yunus, where people are persecuted for their commitment to human rights. Our resolution is a serious warning sign: there can be no more lasting European perspective if current practice continues.

name: Jaromír Štětina
text: Author. - Madam President, unfortunately, human rights violations in Azerbaijan are a demonstrable fact. Unfortunately, I say this mainly because Azerbaijan is an Eastern Partnership country, a country very important for building relations between the European Union and the countries of the South Caucasus. This was made aware by the authors of the present resolution, its text is designed in a balanced agreement of representatives of all factions. The draft resolution lists mainly the cases of political prisoners in Azerbaijan. Allow me, ladies and gentlemen, to briefly highlight one of them.  It's the case of jailed lawyer Intigam Aliyev, an advocate for the politically persecuted. For me, his case is particularly troubling. Intigam Aliyev recently received the Homo Homini award in Prague from the most important NGO, People in Need foundation. Please, ladies and gentlemen, support this resolution in today's vote.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat
text: Author. Madam President, in the spring of 2012, hundreds of people took to the streets of Baku to demand democratic reforms. The government has responded with a wave of repression, the effects of which are still being felt today, which are even getting worse. Political opponents, civil society activists and journalists are, as always, the victims. Leyla Yunus is the symbol.  While international tension is focused on Ukraine, European tension, I would even say, the ruling clan believes it enjoys total impunity, as it is courted because of its high hydrocarbon reserves. Azerbaijan is linked to the European Union through a partnership and cooperation agreement and an association agreement is being negotiated. What is the meaning of these negotiations if they are not conditional on respect for human rights? In Azerbaijan, not only is there no progress, but it is constantly regressing. There is therefore an urgent need to interrupt the negotiations, to strictly apply the Association Agreement to the strict benefit of civil society and to suspend it if necessary. Otherwise, all we have said before is just wind. There, the European Union has the means to act, let it do so!

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: Author. - (IT) Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Republic of Azerbaijan currently has the rotating Presidency of the Council of Europe, the organisation that guides the defence of human rights and the promotion of democracy.  The Republic of Azerbaijan is at the same time a country where rights are systematically violated, from freedom of expression – particularly on the Internet – to freedom of association and assembly, an absurd contradiction, I would say. Azerbaijan aims to become one of europe's main gas suppliers, so from a commercial or energy-strategic point of view it seems to be of great interest to us, while our interest in its democratic hold and in the protection of human rights has so far been less strong. Press reports and reports from major non-governmental organisations inform us that there are dozens of prisoners of conscience behind bars for expressing their views as journalists, bloggers or activists, on the basis of spurious accusations and, above all, without due process. In addition, eight detainees between the ages of eighteen and thirty are on hunger strike to raise awareness among international public opinion.  We call on Europe to put pressure on the Azerbaijani Government to respect the international agreements it has signed, including the one that allows it to chair the Council of Europe. Europe is the main financier of civil organisations in Azerbaijan. We therefore call on the Commission to monitor the use of these funds. They must be spent transparently and effectively, otherwise it would be like turning our backs on those children in prison who are only asking for a little dignity.

name: Molly Scott Cato
text: author. - Madam President, in July we watched with horror as the Azerbaijani Government waged war on its civil society. It has targeted some of the country’s most prominent human rights defenders, imprisoning them on the basis of trumped-up and politically motivated charges. I name in particular Leyla Yunus, Arif Yunus, Rasul Jafarov and Intigam Aliyev. We need a strong condemnation of the detention of Azerbaijani human rights defenders in order to raise their profile and offer them protection, and for the same reason I am proud to say that the Green Group has nominated Leyla Yunus for this year’s Sakharov Prize. I also note the most recent news that the UN Subcommittee on the Prevention of Torture has decided to suspend its visit to Azerbaijan due to obstructions it encountered in carrying out its mandate under the Protocol Against Torture, of which Azerbaijan is a signatory. In our own resolution we call for all bogus charges against the human rights activists to be dropped and urge the Azerbaijani authorities to end the practice of selected criminal prosecution and imprisonment of critics of the government. We call on the Azerbaijani authorities to halt all actions aimed at supressing freedom of express and assembly. In relation to our own EU institutions, we call on the Council and Commission and our High Representative to ask for the immediate release of all Azerbaijani human rights defenders and to apply the ‘more for more’ principle with a specific focus on their situation. We also insist that negotiations towards a new strategic modernisation partnership with Azerbaijan should be put on hold until these minimum steps are taken, and that the advancement of relations between the EU and Azerbaijan should be clearly linked to practical steps by the government to improve its abysmal record. The case of Leyla Yunus was brought to my attention by a constituent who knows her well and who has told me of the terrible suffering that Dr Yunus is undergoing. It is too personal to be detailed here but it should not be forgotten and it should motivate us to condemn the actions of the Azerbaijani Government in the strongest terms and to demand the same standards of human rights that we ourselves would expect as EU citizens.

name: Róża Gräfin von Thun und Hohenstein
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Those of us who enter the European Parliament every day from the side of the Council of Europe building see this big banner indicating that Azerbaijan has just the presidency of the Council of Europe. I would like to emphasise today in this debate how extremely destructive action has been taken by the Azerbaijani authorities in recent months and they have succeeded, taking advantage of the confusion surrounding the Russian-Ukrainian conflict, to dismantle civil society, it can be said, in the last two months. It is society that is so intimidated that it will not dare to take to the streets today or oppose political detention. Unfortunately, the reaction of the international community is very weak. What is happening in Azerbaijan today should, for example, result in the immediate appointment of a special rapporteur and condemnation of this conduct by the Council of Europe. We should also require the European Union, our delegation in Baku, to condemn this situation more broadly, to consider introducing a visa ban for some of Aliyev's henchmen. Only such a strong signal could affect Azerbaijan's policy at the moment.  And at the very end, I wanted to say a few more words to the business. Various European companies (I do not want to mention their names here) have decided to sponsor the first European Olympic Games, which will be held in Baku. Of course, the interest – raw materials – is huge here. But I wonder if these companies have made any assessment of the impact of this sponsorship on human rights in the country, in accordance with UN rules? These Games, let us realize, will be used by Aliyev to promote the country and present it in the best possible light.  Last word – this resolution is very good, but let this be only the first step and let us get involved further.

name: Kati Piri
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. According to Human Rights Watch, 40 political activists, bloggers, journalists and human rights activists have been wrongly put behind bars in Azerbaijan in the past two years. For these people, we are calling attention here today. Azerbaijan is part of the European Neighbourhood Policy and a strategic partner of the EU. It is precisely for this reason that we must be particularly critical if the common values on which our partnership is built are so seriously violated. In recent months, there has been an unprecedented wave of arrests against people who dare to criticise the authorities. Among them also, often mentioned here, Leyla Yunus and her husband Arif, Rasul Jafarov and Intigam Aliyev. Because what have these people actually done? They have applied the principles of the Council of Europe and denounced human rights violations. We call on the authorities in our resolution to release these political prisoners immediately and to put an end to the witch-hunt for people who stand up for universal principles such as freedom and democracy.

name: Ryszard Czarnecki
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I hope that you will be a great Commissioner and I wish you very much, although of course the European Parliament is losing an excellent MEP and a great Vice-President. I keep my fingers crossed for you, Commissioner.  Ladies and about! This is an important debate also because it draws our attention to the countries of the South Caucasus, which have recently been talked about in our Parliament as if they were less, and wrongly, because it is a very important region. A region that generally strives – I am talking about societies, not necessarily governments – to be as close as possible to Europe: a political Europe, European standards, European values. I have met with Georgians, Armenians and Azerbaijani people many times, and I know that they think like us on many issues. I hope that in the future we will also have debates on respect for human rights in Russia as soon as possible, because this, too, has been very quiet lately and wrongly.

name: Kateřina Konečná
text: on the part of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, I was very happy to hear Martin Schulz's speech yesterday. I understood that Germany needed more than 70 years to come to terms with its tragic past.  Today we are discussing a resolution on the Republic of Azerbaijan, in which we are forcing a sovereign state to adapt from its roots to our concept of democracy within two to three years. In this context, I cannot and will not agree to any preliminary ruling that should serve that purpose. The sovereign state of Azerbaijan has the right to give the judiciary and the executive power sufficient time to investigate cases of human rights violations, but without external pressure and political statements by the European Union. Biased assessments of these cases, not only in Azerbaijan, are counterproductive and are in direct conflict with the spirit of cooperation promoted by the European Parliament. My knowledge of Azerbaijan is that it shows more than a considerable degree of commitment and effort to bring its national legislation into line with international law. We are obliged to criticise, but at the same time respect, the historical-cultural context of specific countries and to have a dialogue with them, and to cooperate not only within the Framework of the Venice Commission. I am deeply convinced that an expert assessment of the compliance of national laws with the real defence of human rights is a matter for example of the Venice Commission, but not of the Political Declarations of the European Parliament. If we want to help Azerbaijan, let us help with reforms, not destruction.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D). -
text: Madam President, I join my colleagues in condemning this attack on human rights defenders and journalists, political activists, bloggers, NGOs, all those who fight Azerbaijan for democracy, freedom and plurality. The use of criminal proceedings forged by fraud, tax evasion, treason and other arguments is absolutely unacceptable. These people must be released immediately and unconditionally. The authorities should end the ongoing campaign of harassment and intimidation against non-governmental organisations and allow them to work without restrictions, in particular in the framework of the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative, therefore for human rights and democracy.  Azerbaijan must carry out without delay and genuinely the human rights reforms it has undertaken with the Council of Europe of which it is a member. And for us, the European Union and the Member States, we cannot continue with the usual business policy towards Azerbaijan. We have responsibilities and obligations within the European Union's strategic framework for human rights and democracy. And that is why we must speak urgently, and in the most incisive terms possible, against the ongoing repression in Azerbaijan. Negotiations for a Strategic Modernisation Partnership with Azerbaijan should be suspended until the minimum stages are taken, and any future progress in relations between the European Union and Azerbaijan should be dependent on concrete measures by the government to improve the human rights situation.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE). -
text: I think it is right that we are serious about the human rights situation in Azerbaijan, as in other countries that are in a comparable status. I think there's one imprisoned human rights activist and one imprisoned journalist, one too many. And I, too, am in the power of Azerbaijan to show a little more sensiti viability to human rights, but at the same time I would like to point out that Azerbaijan is a very specific country, subject to pressure from both Russia and Iran, and that it is also an extremely important strategic partner for us. I think it is right that we help this country, especially with its most difficult problem, the problem of the occupation of Nahytho naut the Nahobakh. The European Parliament or the European Union have done enough in this regard.

name: Neven Mimica
text: Member of the Commission. - Madam President, relations between the EU and Azerbaijan are indeed very important, in some areas even strategic. However, they also present us with a number of challenges. Let me highlight two concerns in particular. First, we are witnessing a serious deterioration in the human rights situation in Azerbaijan. In recent months several prominent human rights defenders have been arrested and imprisoned as part of an accelerated crackdown on civil society. Secondly, this summer we also saw an escalation in the conflict over Nagorno-Karabakh, which registered the most serious breaches of the ceasefire agreement since its signature in 1994. The EU had been vocal in expressing its concerns over these worrying developments, in particular over human rights and the conflict situation. Human rights have also been raised bilaterally with the Azerbaijani administration. Commissioner Füle and Deputy Secretary-General Helga Schmid did so during their meetings with President Aliyev and with civil society representatives in their recent visit to Baku for the Eastern Partnership informal ministerial dialogue. These issues were also addressed during President Barrosoʼs visit to Baku in June. In response to the rapidly deteriorating situation we have also triggered our Guidelines on Human Rights Defenders and instructed the EU delegation to offer concrete support to human rights defenders at risk. The ongoing pressure on independent civil society in Azerbaijan contradicts our common values and the spirit of the Eastern Partnership. We cannot stress enough the importance of a thriving civil society for a thriving democracy and we will keep on reminding our partners in Azerbaijan that the best way to achieve stability and prosperity in the country is through a functioning multiparty democracy, open societies and open economies. We maintain our offer to base our relations with Azerbaijan on a new, legally binding basis. It will have to be inspired by common values and in particular human rights and fundamental freedoms. We have started negotiating an association agreement and a strategic modernisation partnership. These steps are very important, not least in the context of Azerbaijan’s role in ensuring Europe’s energy security. The EU recommends that Azerbaijan, which is currently chairing the Council of Ministers of the Council of Europe, reviews its recently amended NGO legislation and takes forward the recommendations of civil society and international organisations to bring the legislation into line with the commitments it has made in the Council of Europe. We will continue to pass messages to all relevant stakeholders in a spirit of partnership. Following the contact between the Council of Europe’s Secretary-General Thorbjørn Jagland and President Aliyev, we look forward to a meeting of the Joint Committee between the Presidential Administration and representatives of civil society in the presence of a Council of Europe representative. Unfortunately the committee has not been convened in the last six years, so this meeting would be an opportunity to relaunch dialogue between the Azerbaijani authorities and civil society.

name: Preşedinte. -
text: The debate has been closed. The vote will take place at the end of the debates. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Jarosław Leszek Wałęsa (PPE)
text: in writing. –  The issue surrounding the human rights defenders in Azerbaijan continues to grow, as a European institution focused on the rights of all it is our responsibility to intervene in the best way we can. I clearly support the findings of my group and side with them on any interaction they pursue. Persecution of human rights defenders in Azerbaijan [2014/2832(RSP)] clearly outlines the atrocities’ occurring in Azerbaijan and sets forth the action that should be taken by this House. Having had the opportunity to follow closely the trials of prosecuted journalists in Turkey it is quite evident that this situation mirrors the Turkey issue in that journalists are being censored and then prosecuted for what they publish. However the issue in Azerbaijan is even further reaching in that the government is prosecuting those who are attempting to assist the citizens in need. I will continue to follow these events and assist in any way I can as these prosecutions are senceless. . –

name: Preşedinte. -
text: The next item is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on Burundi, in particular the case of Pierre Claver Mbonimpa [2014/2833(RSP)]

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: Author. - (IT) Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Nelson Mandela is a symbol of redemption for the whole of the African continent and beyond. Pierre Claver Mbonimpa, like Mandela, is a symbol of freedom, of struggle, of justice for a continent unfortunately still at the mercy of corrupt leaders and local potentates who exploit the territory to enrich themselves. In Burundi, for Mbonimpa, history repeats itself. Exactly twenty years after his arrest and torture in prison, the journalist and human rights defender returned to his cell on 15 May. His fault? Persevere in the defence of freedom of expression, a freedom that should be sacred.  Mbonimpa is a brave man. He defied power by paying the consequences and nevertheless decided to challenge him again. His arrest is a political issue: there will be elections in Burundi in 2015 and the current government seems intent on maintaining power by all repressive and violent means. His health has now worsened and he has been transferred under surveillance to the hospital. With this resolution we are calling for this story to be repeated and for the immediate and unconditional release of the prisoner of conscience, Mr Mbonimpa. The European Parliament must condemn this new and unjustified detention of Mbonimpa and use all diplomatic means to persuade the local authorities to stop the use of violence against all civilians peacefully demonstrating in Burundi for his release. Fifty-two are currently being held without due process in the country's prisons. Let us help healthy civil society in Burundi to ensure that history in that country has a new course.

name: Louis Michel
text: Author. Madam President, the progress of the 2000 Arusha Agreement seemed promising for peace and democracy in Burundi. Today, unfortunately, we are witnessing drifts, increasing slippages, worrying in the areas of the rule of law, human rights, security and good governance.  In the run-up to the general elections scheduled for May to July 2015, relations between the various political parties are seriously deteriorating and acts of intimidation are increasing. Civil society is increasingly the target of threats, violence and harassment. I do not address in the context of this discussion the situation of homosexuals in Burundi who are victims of a real unacceptable political instrumentalization.  The arrest on 15 May of Pierre, President of the Association for the Protection of Human Rights and Detainees, widely recognized nationally and internationally as a leading figure in defending victims of human rights abuses in Burundi, is a clear example of this. The actions of the government authorities seem to indicate a real autocratic drift. That is not acceptable and it would be good if we sent a clear signal to the President to do so. Sir must be released as soon as possible.  Elections scheduled for 2015 are crucial. In view of the situation, I would like to formally urge the future Vice-President, High Representative, Federica Mogherini, to decide to send an election observation mission.

name: Josef Weidenholzer
text: Author. - (DE) Madam President, I would like to thank Burundi is not only one of the poorest countries in Africa, it is still suffering the consequences of a cruel twelve-year civil war that has led to a terrible genocide. Only the Arusha Agreement ended this tragic chapter. Here, the parties to the conflict had agreed on a national reconciliation based on the principles of the rule of law, tolerance and democracy, while respecting human rights. For a long time, it seemed that the country could shed the shadows of the past. In recent years, however, it has increasingly deviated from this promising path. One of the loudest voices to publicly highlight this regrettable development is the human rights activist Pierre Claver Mbonimpa. He was arrested in May this year on flimsy charges.  Burundi is a recipient of considerable European resources. Parliamentary elections will be held next year. Against this background, it is essential to remind the country of its self-formulated commitments. The release of those detained for political reasons is an essential test of this.

name: Maurice Ponga
text: Author. Madam President, the case of Mr Mbonimpa, a staunch defender of human rights in Burundi, is of great concern. On 15 May, Mr. Mbonimpa was arrested and remanded in custody following statements made on Burundian radio to denounce the training camps of the Imbonerakure - the youths of the ruling President's party in eastern DRC. However, these camps exist and represent a major threat to peace in Burundi.  We condemn Mr. Mbonimpa's pre-trial detention and call for his release and respect for the rights of the accused and judicial proceedings. We also call for human rights defenders to be protected and for an investigation into the actions of the Imbonerakure.  The context is hardening in Burundi and the current government is limiting demonstrations and the rights of political opponents. Next year, however, elections will be held in Burundi and it is necessary that the political debate can take place in a serene and peaceful manner.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat
text: Author. Madam President, Burundi is one of the poorest countries in the world, with the highest hunger rate among the countries where this index is calculated. It is suffering the consequences of the crisis among its major neighbours and is facing the influx of thousands of refugees. A series of elections are due to take place in 2015, the climate is deleterious. All those who do not support the regime, who dare to criticize it, are victims of a terrible repression, whether they are political activists or NGOs, journalists or ordinary citizens. Pierre Claver Mbonimpa is one of them. A courageous man who dedicated his life to human rights.  Our debates, Commissioner, are currently being followed in Burundi. I greet those who are watching. Our debates must bring hope to them. The European Union has the means to act. Its aid to the tenth EDF has more than doubled to 432 million euros. This is essential for a country whose budget depends on more than 50% of foreign aid. Yes, the leaders of this country are corrupt. The European Union must therefore press for its aid to be allocated only to the country's priority problems, conditional on respect for human rights, the release of all political prisoners, in support of the UN's request to open an investigation into the military training centres, which are at the heart of Pierre Claver Mbonimpa's accusation.

name: Judith Sargentini
text: Author. - Last November I was in Burundi, after travelling through Rwanda and Eastern Congo, to look at mining and the smuggling of minerals that finance rebels. I spoke to NGOs in Burundi. There are. There are a lot of good, smart and sensible people who take a risk. As early as November 2013, they were afraid and saw that the youth militias were becoming more aggressive and that radios and newspapers were allowed to write less than they wanted. I spoke to them in a hotel, behind closed doors, but they had all made sure that their car was not at the door. These people are taking risks and need protection and we can give them that protection by talking about them. A very painful example of this is Mr Pierre Claver Mbonimpa, who is now imprisoned for his work of protecting the human rights of people in prisons! Is there a better way to see what a country is like than to look at how you deal with prisoners? It is distressing that this man is now in prison himself and that is why I am concerned about the 2015 election. Burundi has raw materials and can therefore also be a rich country. But it's not. It's the sad little brother between Congo, Rwanda and Uganda. There is smuggling, but those proceeds do not remain in Burundi. It is good that we are paying attention to it again. I am also convinced that we must observe the elections there and ensure that human rights defenders and politicians who are trying to fight a fair fight are helped.

name: Bogdan Brunon Wenta
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Pierre Claver Mbonimba works for human rights, persecuted and unlawfully arrested in Burundi. Today, in the plenary chamber, both I and the previous previous voters are defending him, calling on the authorities to release him immediately and unconditionally from custody. Internationally, his work was recognized, awarding him important decorations, and Amnesty International recognized him as a prisoner of conscience. The economic and political situation of one of africa's smallest and poorest countries is, of course, very difficult. However, it does not relieve the Burundian Government of its duty and responsibility to respect the African Charter of Human Rights, the UN Declaration, the Kigali Declaration on Human Rights Defenders. Freedom of expression and respect for rights in Burundi are particularly important in the context of the upcoming elections in 2015, which will not be recognised unless they fulfil the fundamental principles of democracy.

name: Kashetu Kyenge
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the dramatic situation in Burundi calls on Europe to take a strong stand in the face of its role as a global player in the defence of the rule of law and fundamental freedoms.  Depriving a human rights defender, Pierre Mbonimpa, of his freedom is an attack on the democracy of this country, which unfortunately still manifests all the fragilities that led to a decade of civil war, giving history a tragic toll of three hundred thousand deaths. We do not want to see a new genocide in Central Africa. The alert level is high, especially in view of the forthcoming elections, which must take place in a democratic and inclusive climate, with the participation of the opposition.  Without full respect for the will of the people and their rights, the country is in danger of being relegated to its underdevelopment, with dramatic repercussions on the lives of hundreds of thousands of people. We need a strong signal of hope, strength and courage for those who defend freedom and democracy. Pierre Mbonimpa must be released immediately.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE). -
text: Madam President, I convey my best wishes to you. About twelve years ago, I had the opportunity to work in this house, as an assistant, especially the peace process of the Great Lakes countries, also in Burundi, following the serious conflicts of the 1990s. At the beginning of this century, it seemed that the long-awaited peace and reconciliation, fostered by the Arusha Agreements, was consolidating. But the situation is getting worse, as evidenced by the fact at hand today: the arrest of Pierre Claver Mbonimpa and others for denouncing, as the local United Nations office also did, the youth training centres of the ruling party. 2015 is election year in Burundi and these facts cause us added concern, about the intimidating situation towards opposition parties and the use of the judiciary to exclude political competitors. It is appropriate for us to consider an electoral observation: the Cotonou Agreement and the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights bind and bind the Burundian Government.  From the institutions of the European Union and, from this Parliament in particular, we must always raise our voices in defence of those who do not have it and today, in this case, ask the Government of Burundi, for the immediate release of Mr Mbonimpa and full respect for human rights and freedom of expression.

name: Goffredo Maria Bettini (S&D). -
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the situation in Burundi is very serious. The violation of human rights is also taking place in the field of freedom of speech, thought and opinion. It is the most odious attack that a person can suffer, as in the case of Mbonimpa.  Of course, today's tragedy, let us never forget, is the result of a terrible story, it is the result of permanent political instability, of constant institutional precariousness, of atavistic poverty. Europe must work hard to help refugees, to respect peace, to guarantee people and their freedom. Every country, even the smallest, even the one with the least power, has the right to live in freedom and to be helped to conquer it permanently.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D). -
text: Madam President, Commissioner, less than ten years have passed since the end of Burundi's 12-year civil war, which claimed the lives of tens of thousands of people. The period following the end of the conflict in 2005 was marked by a huge sense of relief as peace gradually returned to the country through the Arusha Accords.  But this euphoria quickly faded because although Burundi emerged from the most violent period, the country was unable to lift itself out of poverty. Commodity prices have only increased, soared, and corruption at all levels of power has skyrocketed.  The government is increasingly repressive and the political climate is deplorable. The case of Pierre Claver Mbonimpa is the latest and most emblematic example of state repression. One of Burundi's leading human rights defenders has been arrested for one reason only, that of criticizing the government on a radio show. I have the greatest fears about the upcoming elections in 2015. The ruling party has ruled the country for almost 10 years and probably does not want to share power. As Louis Michel said before me, this is a real autocratic drift that we are witnessing. We, the European Parliament, must send a clear message in favour of Pierre Claver Mbonimpa and, more broadly, in favour of democracy, which is under threat in Burundi.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE). -
text: A Uachtaráin, tar éis dosaen bliain d'aighneas cheapamar go raibh rudaí ag dul i bhfeabhas sa Bhurúin ó thosach na míosa seo. Ba léir go raibh siad ar an mbóthar daonlathach.  Ach anois, le toghcháin ag teacht an bhliain seo chugainn is léir freisin go bhfuil an rialtas chun gach rud a dhéanamh chun iad féin a choimeád i gcumhacht. Níl sé seo ceart. Agus is eiseamláir an rud atá ag tarlú do Claver Mbonimpa ar cad atá ar siúl. Ní ceart go mbeadh sé i bpríosún; caithfimid brú a chur ar na húdaráis ann é a ligean saor; agus go háirithe a chinntiú go mbeidh toghchán oscailte féaráilte acu an bhliain seo chugainn.  Táimid ag tabhairt a lán airgid don tír bheag seo: EUR 432 mhilliún idir seo agus 2020. Caithfimid brú a chur orthu a bheith féaráilte agus an fear maith seo a ligean saor.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D). -
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. Human rights activist Pierre Claver Mbonimpa was arrested on May 15 on charges of inciting public disobedience and endangering national security in a statement to Burundi's public radio about arming the ruling party's youth wing. This is not the first time that burundi's government has been unpardonable in cracking the opposition. Let us recall that political killings between 2010 and 2012 have not yet been explained. The Burundian authorities have committed to the Cotonou Agreement and the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. In addition, the European Union has already provided €432 million in financial support to Burundi to support civil society. I call on the Burundian Government to have a democratic political debate, especially in view of the upcoming elections in 2015. I hope that the newly nominated High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs will make every effort to ensure that the Union's voice is unequivocal wherever fundamental human rights are violated.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI). -
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to ask this question: I have heard the question of Burundi, but is it possible – as I saw in the Italian newspaper today – that Jews in Europe must be afraid of being Jews?  That is this argument: we still have Jews in Europe today, Jewish brothers who are afraid to go to synagogues, 75% of children do not go to Jewish schools because they are afraid. Of what? The cancer that there is, this cancer of Islam, this fearful Islam, and we are talking about Burundi. Burundi will be important, but is it no longer important to defend Jews in Europe and defend the freedom of Christianity in Europe?  That is my question. Or do we want to wait, as Hitler did in the 1930s, where everyone was having sleep, and now we're going to have the new Hitler from the desert sands? We must defend Europe and the people of Europe and the Jews first of all.

name: Preşedinte. -
text: I want to remind you that we are here in this Chamber which is the most democratic institution of the European Union, and I do not think it is appropriate to make such statements. Please apologize. (End of catch the eye procedure)

name: Neven Mimica
text: Member of the Commission. - Madam President, I welcome the opportunity provided by this emergency resolution to address the case of Pierre Claver Mbonimpa. We attach great importance to his situation, which has received considerable attention in our dialogue with the Burundian authorities. As you know, protecting and encouraging human rights defenders is one of the major priorities of the overall EU policy on human rights and democracy. Human rights defenders have a vital moral and practical role to play in giving confidence to civil society organisations and to citizens wishing to assert their rights and enjoy their fundamental freedoms in challenging circumstances.  The arrest of Mr Mbonimpa gave us cause for significant concern. The EU expressed that concern strongly, underlining to the Burundian authorities that the legal and human rights of the accused should be scrupulously and transparently respected. We also reacted publicly to the misguided decision to keep Mr Mbonimpa in pre-trial detention.  The EU delegation and the EU Member States represented in Bujumbura have been in close contact with Mr Mbonimpa’s lawyer. Just a few days ago we were informed that he had been sent to hospital. Naturally we will continue to enquire about the conditions under which he is being treated and about his state of health. We must also continue to insist that his rights are fully respected.  The world is watching this case as a test of the respect in practice for rights and freedoms in Burundi. In Burundi, and throughout the world, the EU has spoken out against any measures that encourage the perception of politically motivated justice. Experience shows that this perception in itself is dangerous and destabilising. It is regrettable that Mr Mbonimpa’s case should need to be assessed in such a context and even more so that it comes against a background of other apparent breaches of judicial standards and of increasing tension ahead of the elections in 2015. These threats command continued attention and response. The Cotonou Agreement is about dialogue of equals and we will not hesitate to raise our concerns. The EU is fully committed to accompanying and supporting Burundi in its peace-building process and democratisation. Promotion and respect for human rights and the development of an independent and reliable justice system are, of course, at the core of this action. Through the European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights and the European Development Fund we are supporting actions against discrimination and violence in the country and promoting a diverse and constructive Burundian civil society, including for the LGBTI communities. The local, legislative and presidential elections in 2015 are an important test for the stability of Burundi as well as its democratisation. It is important that the UN also follows the situation closely in cooperation with the EU. Effective monitoring of human rights by the international community must continue during and after the elections. The EU, in close coordination with the Member States represented in Bujumbura, will continue to follow this case and take the necessary steps as the situation evolves.

name: Preşedinte. -
text: The debate on this subject has been closed. The vote will take place at the end of the debates.

name: Preşedinte. -
text: The next item is the debate on six motions for resolutions on human rights violations in Bangladesh [2014/2834(RSP)].

name: Charles Tannock
text: author. - Madam President, whether one looks at the progress made in achieving the Millennium Development Goals, reforms to the police force aimed at ending human rights abuses in that institution, or the strong support that the reconciliation process is receiving from the Bangladeshi Government, particularly in terms of setting up the International Crimes Tribunal (ICT) in order to bring closure to the terrible crimes committed during the 1971 war of liberation, what is happening in Dhaka is worthy of praise. Such praise is especially well deserved when we consider that Bangladesh exists under the continued threat of jihadi terrorist activity and the subsequent need constantly to reconcile security concerns with civil liberties – a concern that all of us in the West are increasingly acutely aware of. This is something we must take into consideration when thinking about this country. The self-defeating conduct of the Bangladesh National Party during the recent general election and its ultimate boycott of that election have been unhelpful to one of the rare examples of a genuine secular democracy in South Asia. Following the disasters in the garments industry, the EU must give more support to this strategic South Asian country.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal
text: Author. - Madam President, this Parliament has adopted numerous resolutions on Bangladesh in recent years. However, the situation remains worrying. 2013 and 2014 have been tumultuous and unstable, with elections boycotted by the main opposition party, violently suppressed demonstrations, arbitrary detentions and forced disappearances. To this we must add the unfortunate situation of human rights defenders and journalists in self-censiveness in a country that ranks 146th, among 180, in the ranking on press freedom of Reporters Without Borders. The number of death row inmates is also worrying, around 10,000 The European Union must insist on promoting the defence of human rights as a value in itself, but it is that, moreover, political instability in Bangladesh could have dire consequences on the economic growth that the country has been experiencing over the past ten years, thwarting its chances of meeting the Millennium Development Goals and its aspiration to move from a country of income down to an average income in 2021, the 50th anniversary of its independence. Poverty and democratic deficits undermine the rights of Bangladeshi citizens and can be a breeding ground for extremist movements, which is particularly worrying in the world's second-largest Muslim-populated country, 90% of its 150 million inhabitants. This danger is increased by al Qaeda leader Ayman al-Zawahiri' call in early September for the establishment of an Islamic caliphate in Bangladesh, Myanmar and parts of India. We must send a clear message. We welcome Bangladesh's implementation of the Millennium Development Goals and recognize its steps in the right direction, for example by preventing marriages with minors, but we must continue to insist that strong action be taken to ensure freedom of expression and political freedoms.

name: Josef Weidenholzer
text: Author. - (DE) Madam President, I would like to thank Bangladesh is one of Asia's most populous countries and an important trading partner for Europe. We source a significant proportion of our consumer goods from this country. There are repeated reports of inhumane working conditions. Whether democracy and respect for human rights exist is therefore of immediate importance. Bangladesh is committed to complying with the rule of law and to implementing a policy of zero tolerance of the violation of human rights standards by the authorities. NGOs and trade unions that are committed to complying with ILO standards and claiming the right to freedom of expression are increasingly under state pressure. Religious and ethnic minorities are also coming under pressure. Activists are imprisoned or are victims of so-called enforced disappearances. These developments are worrying and hinder the way in which the country develops. A positive development of the country is in the interest of the region and in the interest of all peaceful development in the region.

name: Ivo Belet
text: Author. - Please highlight two additional points: First, the rights and freedoms of factory workers in Bangladesh. The recent cases of intimidation and physical violence against trade union representatives are legion. We must continue to raise this issue with the authorities in Dhaka. Secondly, the donor fund for the victims of the Rana Plaza disaster. Despite the efforts of the European Commission and the Clean Clothes Campaign, that fund has so far only been half-filled. Commissioner, therefore, would like to make an explicit commitment to send a clear message to all those involved, in particular all the companies involved, so that the victims and survivors can still be compensated.

name: Paloma López
text: Author. - Madam President, we must condemn the continued repression of political opposition, trade unionists, human rights defenders and journalists, and investigate extrajudicial executions, enforced disappearances and torture by paramilitaries and state security, as well as abolish the death penalty. In Bangladesh, 87% of work is informal and therefore without social or labour rights. In the textile sector, wages are well below the countries around them and agreements are systematically breached by exporting multinationals, which make the most of this situation. We must demand compliance with commitments to respect the rights of workers, especially workers, who suffer from conditions of labour exploitation. The ban on trade unions in export processing areas, where working, health and safety conditions are extraordinarily negative, must be ended. The mandatory mechanism should now be put in place to compensate the 1,100 dead and 2,500 wounded in Rana Plaza still unscathed. It is the need and obligation of this Parliament and the Member States to publicly denounce multinationals which have not met the victims and to exclude companies that violate human and labour rights from aid and public procurement.

name: Jean Lambert
text: author. - Madam President, during the many visits this Parliament made to Bangladesh in the previous parliamentary term, we experienced a very vibrant and very diverse media, and we met with many NGOs working on a variety of important issues from women’s rights – where Bangladesh is making progress – to poverty reduction, human rights and torture allegations. They have helped the government make significant progress on the Millennium Development Goals and we want that to continue to be the state of affairs. That is why we are concerned at particular legislative changes which we feel put that dynamism at risk. This is an issue that we raised when we were there earlier this year. We are not yet clear about how these changes, and particularly the NGO changes, will affect donor engagement. The EU is, of course, a significant part of that, so I would hope to hear something from the Commission about it. We all know that politicians, whatever their party, find a critical press and NGOs inconvenient, embarrassing and even threatening at times, but they are an important element of a democratic society, especially when the formal political opposition is weak or non-existent.  We also raise the issue of the Rapid Action Battalion. We should welcome recent moves to indict a number of officers, but the number of those dying at the hands of the RAB has begun to rise again. We have seen 88 deaths in the last seven months and there is real concern about the lack of accountability. We want to see the government operate its zero-tolerance policy against human rights abuses by law enforcement agencies and we welcome the training put in place with the International Committee of the Red Cross.  We need a strong and independent judiciary and a civil society and active parliament to make sure that the measures take effect. Others have referred to the death penalty. There is widespread public and political support in Bangladesh for this, so we welcome the government’s acceptance of the Supreme Court’s commutation of the death sentence of Mr Sayedee under charges under the International Crimes Tribunal. For those who are concerned about the issues around trade union rights and decent pay – and quite rightly concerned – there are major issues there. I would also pick up on what a previous speaker has said that we need to make sure that the international community is paying what it owes to make sure that changes can really be made and take effect.

name: Seán Kelly
text: thar ceann an Ghrúpa PPE. –  A Uachtaráin, tá gaol againn leis an mBanglaidéis anois ó 1973, sin bliain agus dhá scór ó shin. Caithfear a rá go bhfuil a lán dul chun cinn déanta ag an dtír seo, mar a dúirt cainteoirí eile.  Ach i slite eile, ní féidir an dul chun cinn seo a bhrath ná a fheiscint. Cúpla sampla de sin ná: nach bhfuil lucht freasúra láidir ann; gur léir go bhfuil comhcheilg idir na breithiúna agus an rialtas – agus ní féidir cur suas leis seo, ba chóir go mbeadh triail fhéaráilte le fáil ag gach uile dhuine; na coinníollacha slándála atá ag na hoibrithe – chonaiceamar cad a tharla i monarcha éadaí Rana Plaza anuraidh nuair a fuair 1 100 duine bás; agus níos measa is dócha, an neamhaird agus an chluas bhodhar a thugtar do mhná nuair a tharlaíonn coireanna coiriúlachta gnéis ina gcoinne.  Dá bhrí sin, ba chóir go mbeadh muid san airdeall faoi na rudaí seo agus brú a chur ar an mBanglaidéis iad a fheabhsú.

name: Liisa Jaakonsaari
text: On behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, there is indeed a serious spiral of violence in Bangladesh and it is up to the Government of Bangladesh to change the situation. One and most important instrument for changing the situation is legislation, which must be based on the principle of human rights and freedoms. The free movement of information, the activities of NGOs and the rights of the trade union movement are also an essential factor for one's own country, as is the protection of journalists, etc. These things need to change in Bangladesh, otherwise the country will not develop.  In particular, this tragic rana plaza event does show that the country needs profound changes. It is therefore good that the European Parliament is demanding clear and principled action from the Member States and from itself, the European Union, and also that multinationals and the business community should be held accountable for what has happened.

name: Jana Žitňanská
text: for the ECR Group. – I am glad that, in this resolution, Parliament also decided, at my instigation, to condemn the July attack on the reversals in Boldipur, when the peace sisters, who are otherwise highly respected in Bangladesh, were brutally attacked. I would add that this was not just a religiously motivated attack. The diocese there helps to legally defend the assets of the poor population. In fact, various groups have long sought to illegally acquire their fertile land, and attacks on missionaries are acts of intimidation. Following the July attack and subsequent protests by Bangladeshi bishops, the government ordered a temporary police presence around the monastery. Let us hope that this will not only deter rapists from further similar attacks, but will, above all, end the persecution of indigenous minorities in the region.

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the latest Amnesty International report on the situation in Bangladesh paints an extremely worrying picture which should lead us to take prompt action to protect human rights. We are witnessing a worrying escalation of political violence in order to silence the protests and strikes called by the opposition against a government that stands out for its very high level of corruption.  The maintenance of human rights is seriously compromised and the minimum protections provided for by most of the world are not guaranteed to Bengali citizens. Around thirty extrajudicial executions have been reported in the Asian country, so there is no culprit and no suspects. In Bangladesh, medieval practices of torture and other types of ill-treatment are so widespread that they seem normal and are committed with almost total impunity by the police, the army and intelligence agencies. To aggravate the picture we can add numerous cases of enforced disappearances, systematic violence of all kinds against women, conflicts between Bengali settlers and native populations, intimidation and aggression against trade union leaders and numerous cases of aggression and destruction against ethnic and religious minorities. We cannot see this with indifference. Europe can and must act to ensure that dignity, freedom, equality, solidarity and justice do not remain sterile words on the Nice Charter, but become universally recognised and affirmed rights.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI). -
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, today we are debating and voting on human rights violations in Bangladesh. No one will argue that, despite any progress in the development of the country, human rights are being grossly violated by the security forces. Disappearances of individuals, death sentences by biased justice, persecution and intimidation are contrary to the principles of democracy and the rule of law. The leader of the third-in-power political party was arrested without waiver of his immunity and has been jailed for a year now along with six other members of his party. His wife, also an MP, is allowed to visit her husband only once a month. Three other Members are under house arrest, two Members are prohibited from speaking at political gatherings, and all have been subject to restrictive conditions. The government and some jurors set up a plot based on the criminal activity of a person who simply declared himself a member of the party. Totally undemocratically, the party's funding was cut off, which was subsequently classified as a criminal organisation without even a trial. However, ladies and gentlemen, what I have described to you unfortunately does not happen in Bangladesh but in Europe, in my country Greece, and in my party the Golden Dawn People's League. For reasons of political expediency and avoidance of their upcoming electoral crash, the Samara-Venizelos co-government, completely against every rule of law principle, imprisoned, strangled financially, gagged and falsely charged a political party that simply believes that Greeks deserve better luck than the other political parties that have ruled in the past. What is the European Parliament's position on these human rights violations?

name: Cristian Dan Preda (PPE). -
text: Madam President, in the last two years we have discussed Bangladesh four times in our emergency resolutions. This shows that there is an interest in the European Parliament for developments in this country with which the European Union has cooperation relations, especially, as is known, under a partnership and development agreement. The fact that we are interested means that we are also tracking what is happening positively, and what is happening negatively. Bangladesh, for example, has made significant progress in recent years in achieving the Millennium Development Goals or, very recently, on legislation on the prevention of child marriage. On the other hand, serious concerns remain, as demonstrated by amnesty International's report earlier this month, on enforced disappearances, on the new policy adopted in August on the press or on the persistence of violence on ethnic and religious grounds. Precisely because we are partners with Bangladesh, we must ask this country to take these human rights violations seriously and remedy them urgently.

name: Richard Howitt (S&D). -
text: Madam President, I join other Members in recognising that Bangladesh has made incredible progress on the Millennium Development Goals, and also in recognising that the devastating impact of the recent floods in the country is simply one demonstration of how Bangladesh is so vulnerable – the most vulnerable country in the world – to the impact of climate change. But today we emphasise that it must make progress on human rights and democracy too. We express deep concern about the new media law restricting criticism of the government, the proposed NGO law and allegations of widespread abuses by the security forces, although the recent commuting of sentence of the Islamist leader in the Supreme Court could help set a new precedent about the absolutely unacceptable use of the death penalty. Finally, following the Rana Plaza tragedy, the new labour law has not yet led to the necessary progress towards the formation of trade unions in the country. While we should absolutely welcome Tesco, Sainsbury’s and Next taking responsibility through the Accord on Fire and Building Safety in Bangladesh, we should absolutely condemn Gap and Asda-Walmart for failing to do so.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI). -
text: Madam President! When we talk about human rights violations in Bangladesh, we must not forget the seven million children who work up to 15 hours a day seven days a week in inhumane conditions, especially in the textile industry. If we buy a T-shirt for ten dollars, the worker will only be left with a starvation wage of 0.03 dollars. The EU is Bangladesh's largest textile trading partner. Every year we import clothing worth EUR 15 billion. In other words, we also have a responsibility and must no longer be in default. We should consider that we should also give a seal of approval to products produced under decent conditions and paid for fair wages, if we can verify this. The consumer should decide in Europe. Many Europeans, many consumers, would be willing to pay a few euros, a few dollars more, for a corresponding product.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D). -
text: Madam President, "about sixty men tried to loot the building and rape the nuns. The attackers first gagged the two night guards of the religious mission in the early hours of the morning. They then broke down the door of vicar Anselmo Marandy's room while he was asleep. They then attacked the convent." This is one of the excerpts from the report dated 3 September and written by an NGO in Bangladesh. These acts took place on 1 September, but so many human rights violations were reported. The Rana Plaza tragedy and the deplorable conditions of textile workers, including children, were also rightly recalled. There is also no need to recall the violent repression of the January 2014 protests and the thousands of human rights activists imprisoned under the pretext of having a political opinion. The European Union and Bangladesh signed a cooperation agreement in 1976 and in May 2000 signed a so-called "third generation" agreement, which includes, I believe, a human rights clause. It is time for Bangladesh to fulfil its obligations of full human rights compliance, otherwise some agreements could be revised or even sanctions set out.

name: Neven Mimica
text: Member of the Commission. - Madam President, I welcome the Parliament’s resolution on human rights violations in Bangladesh. As part of bilateral relations, the European Union has consistently engaged with Bangladesh to support the consolidation of democracy. It has repeatedly called on all parties to create favourable conditions for transparent, inclusive and credible elections. The EU regretted the fact that such conditions did not materialise in the elections of 5 January of this year. This means that the people of Bangladesh were not given the opportunity to express fully their democratic choices. Since then we have been closely monitoring developments, which unfortunately remain a cause for concern. We are in a situation where the main opposition party is not represented in Parliament, which would help to ensure democratic accountability and meaningful oversight. This leaves the country without proper checks and balances. We are concerned about the situation of human rights and those of minorities and indigenous people. The space for civil society appears to be narrowing. We recognise the strong support of Bangladesh for women’s empowerment. However, violence and discrimination against women and child labour still exist and demand further efforts. Overall, as the Parliament has rightly stressed in its resolution, the situation remains worrying. The EU is closely following key human rights issues, notably allegations of excessive use of force by law enforcement agencies and discrimination against minority groups and indigenous people, including the lack of implementation of the peace accord for the Chittagong Hill Tracts region. We are monitoring the recent policy guidelines on broadcasting. This policy is likely to limit and restrict freedom of speech and have a chilling effect on media freedom. The EU opposes the death penalty as a matter of principle. The EU is also closely following the situation of the Rohingya minority in Myanmar and Bangladesh. We encourage both countries to discuss the issue and to address the humanitarian situation.  The EU remains committed to continuing to help the government of Bangladesh in the implementation of its national strategy on Myanmar refugees and undocumented Myanmar nationals, whilst seeking to improve the conditions of operation of humanitarian service providers. After the Rana Plaza disaster, the EU launched the Global Sustainability Compact to improve working conditions, labour rights, and safety conditions and to foster corporate social responsibility. The signature of the Sustainability Compact has permitted Bangladesh to continue benefiting from the duty-free, quota-free tariff preferences for exports into the European Union, which are key to sustaining exports and a major instrument of stability and poverty alleviation. We very much value the commitment of Bangladesh to pursuing the implementation of the Sustainability Compact and we call on the government to make real progress in meeting compact commitments. While progress has been significant, much remains to be done and we must keep up the momentum. Human rights and governance dialogue between the European Union and Bangladesh is in place within the framework of the EU-Bangladesh Joint Commission. The next meeting will take place in the coming month. When preparing for it we will remain in close contact with and give support to civil society partners and human rights defenders in Bangladesh. We will continue to work with the European Parliament to monitor the situation and encourage the political parties to engage in genuine dialogue to strengthen democratic accountability and to hold transparent, inclusive and credible elections as soon as possible. Let me finish by saying that only a genuinely democratic set-up can guarantee the fulfilment of the wishes and aspirations of the people of Bangladesh, going along with economic progress and development.

text: The debate is over. The vote will take place today. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. Mr President, I would like to thank the The 2013 Amnesty International Report outlines the status quo: "In 2012, about 30 extrajudicial executions are said to have been carried out. The security forces were involved in torture and other ill-treatment, as well as in at least ten cases of 'disappearance'." There is no improvement in sight, even if the government in Bangladesh does not want to have observed violations of human rights. Prisoners continue to be systematically tortured until they confess to crimes. This kind of medieval truth-finding is still present in Bangladesh in 2014. Suspects are arrested and found shot dead in the streets the following day. Investigations in this respect, if they are initiated at all, will be terminated without result. However, as a substitute member of the FEMM Committee, i was extremely shocked by the following lines in the report: women continue to be exposed to different forms of violence. These include acid attacks, murders, flogging by illegal arbitration committees, domestic and sexual violence. But especially the case of Aleya Begum and her daughter: they were arrested without a warrant and raped by police officers. The court acquitted the two women. When they spoke publicly about the rapes, they were arrested again and now also imprisoned. Who knows what martyrdom they had to endure this time. Unfortunately, European feminism deals with linguistic 'equality' rather than where real suffering arises.

name: President. -
text: The next item is the vote. (For the results and other details of the vote: see Minutes)

name: Mario Borghezio (NI). -
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, on a point of order, I would like to know whether the Presidency does not intend to send a democratic greeting to the people of Scotland who are currently voting for their freedom.  "Alba saor"! Independent Scotland!

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE). -
text: Madam President, the amendment is more of a linguistic nature. Instead of the words ‘can be’ I propose the words ‘should be’. The sentence would read like this: ‘strongly stresses that there should be a political solution to this conflict’.

name: Knut Fleckenstein (S&D). -
text: Madam President! We ask, also in consultation with the other groups, to replace the words 'on the ground' with 'in Ukraine' at the very end of Amendment No 10.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR). -
text: Madam President! I would like to make a point of order relating to this resolution. We received it last night at 8 p.m.: 27 pages, in English for those who do not speak English. 27 pages, English language, entrance: last night 8 p.m. with us. Today at 12 noon we voted on it. I would therefore like to put on record that this is a way of not dealing with this Parliament. (Loud applause)

name: Alexander Graf Lambsdorff (ALDE). -
text: Madam President!  Why do we vote first on the resolution of a single group when there is a joint resolution by several groups – the PPE, S&D, ECR and ALDE/Verts? My second question is this: we want to limit roll-call votes to really important votes. In the vote on this motion by one political group, every single vote is a roll-call vote. Can you explain why this is the case?

name: President. -
text: Mr Lambsdorff, it is noted but I am sure you know the answer to your question: procedural resolutions are voted in numerical order and the first one is this one. The roll-call votes are not an abuse of procedure so it would be good just to move on. – Before the vote on paragraph 8:

name: Knut Fleckenstein (S&D). -
text: Madam President! Can we not vote en bloc if no one opposes it? (Applause)

name: Pervenche Berès (S&D). -
text: Madam President, excuse my inexperience. I wonder: on the basis of what section of the regulation do we vote in the order you have chosen today? It seems to me that usually - but perhaps again I am wrong, and I will be delighted to be denied by you - a compromise resolution presented by several groups comes to the vote as a priority.

name: President. -
text: I am told that it is Rule 123(4), which says: ‘A joint motion for a resolution shall replace the motions for resolutions tabled previously by its signatories, but not those tabled by other committees, political groups or Members’. That is the answer.

name: President. -
text: That concludes the vote.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D). -
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I am voting in favour because every effort must be made to facilitate dialogue between Ukraine and Russia without losing sight of the fact that sanctions cannot replace a diplomatic and political solution that we all hope will be found as soon as possible.  There is an urgent need to find an immediate and peaceful way out, while at the same time keeping the communication channels open and ready to review sanctions and their repercussions in the event of positive feedback. I am thinking in particular of what is happening in that country's agriculture, and, although I have heard What Commissioner Cioloş said, I insist on the need to establish rules that are clear so that each Member State can actually benefit from the aid in relation to its own production peculiarities.  It is clear to everyone, however, that the funds are insufficient and that more money is needed. In this respect, to give the Italian example, I would just like to point out that our damage amounts to two hundred million euros.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE). -
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, to explain why we were unfortunately unable to vote in favour of it, but abstained on this important resolution, because while we obviously share the enormous concern and closeness to the Ukrainian people about the dramatic moments they are experiencing and if we strongly share the whole part aimed at paying attention and support and a solution to those sectors of European and Italian industry that have been severely affected by the , there are other equally important points that we do not want to share, first of all the point concerning the energy sector, where there is even talk of cancelling the existing agreements with Russia, including the South Stream project.  That is why we reluctantly had to abstain, but we hope that the diplomatic route will become more and more strong because the solution can and must be the political one.

name: Tatjana Ždanoka (Verts/ALE). -
text: Madam President, I voted against this resolution. I am sure that a number of colleagues are continuing to produce the very same kinds of texts based on a one-sided approach to the events in Ukraine.  Just one concrete example. In a number of reports by international NGOs, and Amnesty International in particular, the Ukrainian Government is accused of harsh human rights violations during so-called ‘anti-terror’ operations in the east. The initial text of our resolution, when referring to these reports, speaks about violations perpetrated mainly by regular Russian troops and separatists and in some cases also by government forces. Nevertheless, even this very wrong presentation of NGO findings was washed out during the vote by the majority of this Parliament.

name: Sirpa Pietikäinen (PPE). -
text: Mr President, I, for my part, voted in favour of this resolution and I also welcome the European Union's common line on the neighbouring region and foreign and security policy. We need a good, coherent EU policy that emphasises human rights, citizens' fundamental rights, conflict avoidance and closer economic and people-to-people cooperation in neighbouring regions. This also means, in the long term, stabilising and intensifying cooperation with Russia. We don't create permanent enemy images. I believe that the crisis in Ukraine will do to the EU's foreign and security policy what the financial crisis did to our economic policy at the time. We must work better together and find a strong unified line in the midst of our different mutual emphasis. And here I believe that the policy of small sanctions, small steps towards Ukraine has worked and is working well.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted against this resolution because it is obvious that the spiral of violence in Ukraine is the result of a coup against legitimate President Yanukovich instigated by the US and the EU itself. In fact, the very partnership agreement that has just been signed by the EU with Ukraine, which was what led to the coup d'am, is being used as a weapon against Russia. This, coupled with the new sanctions adopted by the Council against Russia on 12 September, can by no means be regarded as an example of the EU's good neighbour to Russia.

name: Andrus Ansip (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I supported the resolution on the situation in Ukraine and the state of play of EU-Russia relations. Our discussion could not be more timely in light of everything going on in and around Ukraine. The decisive steps that the EU and the US and others have taken in response to Russiaʼs behaviour have brought some results, but it is important to think what more can be done to support Ukraine.  I see this very much as a two-track approach. We must continue to look for a lasting solution to this conflict through political dialogue. But as long as Russia continues to send weapons and soldiers to Ukraine, we cannot take Russian demands seriously. Russia is trying to impose a solution on Ukraine through military means while it should in fact take responsibility and admit that it is a party to the conflict. It must take real steps that will lead to a de-escalation of the conflict. Until Russia does so, we must continue to maintain pressure. We need to be clear and consistent in the language that we use to describe the situation on the ground – this is Russian aggression against Ukraine.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. - Amendment 8: UKIP is deeply concerned by the escalation of the crisis in Ukraine, and feels the grandstanding that occurred in Parliament on 16 September only deepened the potential for a prolonged crisis. We welcome this amendment that stresses that dialogue, not military action, is the means to a peaceful solution.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. - It is necessary to reiterate the Union's support for the Ukrainian people and to recall the need for any political settlement to maintain Ukraine's territorial integrity, sovereignty and independence while respecting the rights of minorities. In this regard, the group condemns once again the annexation of Crimea. We must also hope that the ceasefire will be a first step towards a peaceful and comprehensive political solution.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. - (IT) I did not support the report that was the subject of the vote, as I consider the EU's sanctions policy towards Russia to be wrong. The only result of the decisions taken so far has been enormous economic damage to the European internal market, particularly the Veneto and Italian internal market, and I therefore believe that the EU must review its positions as soon as possible.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. - More than three thousand people have lost their lives in the Ukraine-Russia conflict, including many community citizens who are victims of the downing of the Malaysia Airlines aircraft. The wounded in this climb are numbered by thousands and the displaced, by hundreds of thousands.  The EU must contribute to the peaceful settlement of a war happening at our own borders; providing the necessary financial, technical and human resources, supporting Ukraine's democratic consolidation and requiring Russia to respect international law, including ceasefire and the defence of human rights. In this direction go the humanitarian aid for development and in support of civil society that has been adopted, as well as the Association Agreements ratified in this House, important for the political relationship and economic integration that in 2016 must form an EU-Ukraine free trade area.  However, the highest level of political and diplomatic involvement remains necessary.
