Internally, the agricultural, dairy and fisheries sectors, in order not to see the difficulties they face aggravated, should be supported by the European Commission in dealing with the veto on imports imposed by Russia in response to sanctions.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. - (IT) I call on all parties to make every effort necessary for its full and good-faith implementation, with a view to laying the foundations for the establishment of a genuine peace process, including the permanent and effective control of the Ukrainian border verified by the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE), the complete and unconditional withdrawal of Russian troops, illegal armed groups and , military equipment and mercenaries from the internationally recognised territory of Ukraine, as well as the release of hostages. I also call on the Member States, the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy and the Commission to make every effort to strengthen and strengthen the OSCE Special Monitoring Mission in Ukraine, both in terms of experienced staff and logistics and equipment.  With regard to the Russian embargo on European agri-food products, I call on the Commission to increase the budget allocated to Community measures to alleviate the impact on European farmers and I call for its coverage to be extended to several products. Furthermore, it is essential that, through promotional activities, there should be a strengthening of sales of EU agricultural products in third-country markets in order to avoid oversupply on the European market.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. - Sanctions against Russia are a political gesture and a wretched decision for both European and Russian citizens. As is often the case on the eve of a conflict, it is the less well-off who suffer first and among the European countries it is those in the south, including Italy, who pay a high price.  The value of Italian exports to Russia is 500 million euros per year for the agri-food sector alone, in fact, due to sanctions, several small and medium-sized farms have found themselves with water at their throats having to invent new ways to sell their products, sometimes using Serbian or Montenegrin companies to circumvent sanctions and transit goods to Russia through companies that are not on Putin's "blacklist". In view of this scenario, we are in favour of the small businessman and ask Europe: have the Italians not suffered enough already? How long will the European institutions continue to demand heavy sacrifices from our companies without giving them adequate economic aid in relation to the continuing structural crisis?

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. - It was not easy to take a decision on this resolution. My political group is made up mostly of people who, until the end of the 1980s, fought against the oppression of the Soviet Union. Although I share the basic values of these colleagues, I do not have the same direct experience and I can distinguish what has been done in the name of socialism from what has been done on behalf of Russia. And, not blinded by fear, I see that the European position is doing damage in Europe, with an effectiveness over which I have serious doubts. I would like to start a serious, calm, objective debate, waiting for which I have preferred to abstain so as not to be misunderstood.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. - Recent events of Russian invasion and the consequent destabilisation of Eastern Ukraine and clear violation of the ceasefire between the parties require a strong one-way response from the EU. I support this resolution because I consider it unacceptable not to respect the independence, sovereignty and territorial integrity of the Ukrainian State, as well as the right of the Ukrainian State to make its internal and external choices by opting for rapprochement with Europe. In this respect I would like to welcome the simultaneous ratification of the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement and wish for rapid ratification by all Member States. The constant Russian pressure stemming from the occurrence of gross human rights violations in conflict areas perpetrated by regular Russian troops and separatists through the persecution of Ukrainians and Tatars and threats by self-proclaimed leaders against citizens who express interest in voting in the forthcoming legislative elections is regrettable. I welcome the eu's restrictive measures against Russia and the recent decision by the European Commission to mobilise EUR 22 million of humanitarian aid and development aid for Ukraine, considering it vital to constantly and rigorously supervise the humanitarian needs of refugees and people affected by conflicts.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. - (IT) I preferred to abstain on the resolution on the state of EU-Russia relations. The main reason for this choice lies in the non-sharing of the path of sanctions, which unjustly damages the European industrial sector and which, in any case, does not ensure a constructive contribution to the peace and good relations that must take place between the EU and Russia. The EU should strengthen diplomatic dialogue more than provide for or impose sanctions. The difficult situation with Ukraine must be disbanded through the negotiations.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. – Violating the borders of an independent state is a threat to that state and a violation of international law. When that violation occurs subsequent to a choice in favour of Europe made by an independent state, it becomes incumbent upon the EU to act. Ukraine must be assisted in strengthening its internal stability, democratic structures of governance, respect for human rights and the rule of law.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. - (IT) I think the resolution is very unbalanced on Ukraine. I cannot therefore vote in favour. On the other hand, Russia has its faults, which lead me not to vote against it. For the above reasons, I believe that the best vote is abstention.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted against this resolution because it is obvious that the spiral of violence in Ukraine is the result of a coup against legitimate President Yanukovich instigated by the US and the EU itself. In fact, the very partnership agreement that has just been signed by the EU with Ukraine, which was what led to the coup d'am, is being used as a weapon against Russia. This, coupled with the new sanctions adopted by the Council against Russia on 12 September, can by no means be regarded as an example of the EU's good neighbour to Russia.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. - The EU's support for Ukraine has as its main objective the protection of international law and the principle of territorial sovereignty in particular. Although Russia is a major economic power, which with its extensive territory holds vital energy for the West, and is an important partner for solving the problems in the Middle East, it is not acceptable for it to violate international law and go unpunished. International law is being blocked and undermined as a result of these violations. In the twenty-first century, the rules cannot be dictated by the aggressors, but there is an obligation to defend international law. I firmly believe that this role is a role for Europe, which, thanks to its balance of internal forces, can and must act as guarantors. This is an internal European continent issue, which the institutions must take responsibility for. An appeasement policy would be the wrong signal, on the other hand, it is essential to make a single, strong and decisive voice heard by the Member States.  I believe that the European Union's support for Ukraine is fundamental to the promotion of democratic and social development and to the protection of international law.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. – In violating Ukraineʼs sovereignty, territorial integrity and freedom of choice, the Russian Federation has embarked on a new chapter of relations with the European Union, drifting away from the common path of mutual responsibility for, and shared commitment to, ensuring peace on the European continent. In light of such developments, and thus as a result of the deliberate choice made by the Moscow authorities, the EU can no longer maintain its previous stance towards the Russian Federation and the strategic partnership thereof. However, there can be no peace and stability without an act of responsibility and political maturity on the part of Russia. Its role remains a necessary factor for de-escalation of the conflict and a political, sustainable, long-term solution. With this assumption in mind, the inclusion of our amendments was a precondition for a yes vote. While condemning strongly Russian actions, they emphasised the crucial need to support initiatives on dialogue with Moscow, keeping open all available channels of communication. They also reiterated the full reversibility of the current EU position and its readiness to overturn its stand and to re-engage with Russia as soon as it contributes genuinely and without ambiguities to a fair and negotiated settlement.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution, as I believe that whilst we need to support Ukraine we also need to be diplomatically mature in the way we interact with Russia.  Alongside my colleagues I welcome the ceasefire in eastern Ukraine and ask all sides to respect it. I also believe that the EU should focus on supporting direct talks between Ukraine and Russia, in its efforts to assist Ukraine with regaining stability and implementing crucial political and economic reforms.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. - I believe that the measures adopted by the EU Agriculture Council on 5 September are welcome, and I believe that the Commission must examine ways that would enable the EU to cope better with similar crises in the future, in order to support the affected European producers in a concrete and rapid way.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the situation in Ukraine and the state of EU-Russia relations which, in addition to taking into account the dramatic diplomatic situation we are going through, highlights the catastrophic situation facing our farmers. Indeed, the crisis that European farmers, French in particular, are going through is not of health or market origin, but a diplomatic crisis due to a tug-of-war between the European Union and Russia. We therefore called on the European Commission to act accordingly and to take better account of the needs of farmers while considering the possibility of relying on budget lines other than that of agriculture.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. – I am voting against because the EU was the first to make a major contribution to the worsening crisis in Ukraine, because the EU blames Russia for shooting down the Malaysian Airlines plane without any conclusion being made public on the real causes of the tragedy, as well as on the fact that the EU has not shown the same sensitivity to Serbia's territorial integrity in the Kosovo issue, and , therefore, we consider the attitude of acting hypocritical.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. - Ukraine is going through a difficult phase in its democratic history, with the recent conflict with Russia already causing the deaths of 3000 people, thousands of wounded and hundreds of thousands of civilians fleeing conflict areas. The signed ceasefire protocol, advocated by the Trilateral Contact Group, provides for the release of hostages, measures to improve the humanitarian situation, the withdrawal of all illegal armed groups, military equipment and mercenaries from Ukraine and measures on decentralisation in the Donetsk and Luhansk regions, data that this motion for a resolution reinforces. With this motion for a resolution, the European Parliament reinforces the need for the parties to pave the way for the start of a genuine peace process, which involves the withdrawal of Russian troops, illegal armed groups, war material and mercenaries. Early elections scheduled for October 26, 2014 in Ukraine must be free and fair, and the government must do everything in its power to make it transparent by assisting in the work of international observers.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We are faced with a reprehensible piece of war propaganda. This resolution whiteses and supports the nationalist, protised fascist and neo-Nazi forces that have taken power in Kiev and are trying to forcefully impose on the eastern regions of the country the hegemony of its political and national power, corresponding to the interests and aspirations of the US, NATO and the EU in the economic and political colonization of Ukraine and its strategy of siege and confrontation with Russia.  It is over the millions of dollars that the US has assumed it has spent in Ukraine to build a regime conducive to its interests; the responsibilities of the eu and NATO major powers in the brutal interference triggered after the refusal – in a sovereign decision of a legitimate power to that end – of the signing of the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement by the Ukrainian president, which would be deposed by force; the fact that the EU has negotiated this agreement with fascist and neo-Nazi coup forces in the meantime. The ceasefire is hypocritically welcomed, while at the same time valuing NATO's decision to strengthen Ukraine's ability to ensure its own security and supports the supply of the necessary arms, technology and knowledge by Member States to Ukraine. Obviously we voted against it.

name: Lampros Fountoulis (NI)
text: Writing. - I am voting against because the European Union was the first to make the most of the worsening crisis in Ukraine, because the EU blames the Russian Federation for the collapse of Malaysian airlines without any conclusion being made on the real causes of the tragedy, as well as on the fact that the EU has not shown the same sensitivity to Serbia's territorial integrity in the Kosovo issue. So we consider the EU's attitude to be hypocritical.

name: Mariya Gabriel (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the situation in Ukraine and on the state of EU-Russia relations, adopted in parallel with the simultaneous ratification of the Association Agreement in Kiev and Strasbourg, because it reminds us of the EU's message: the Union is not at war with Russia, the Union defends the principles of international law, human rights and its fundamental values. Part of the European identity is at stake in the EU's response to the Ukraine crisis. We reiterate our full commitment to a political, peaceful and lasting solution through dialogue, but let us stand firm through sanctions: the Minsk ceasefire must be translated into action - the immediate and unconditional withdrawal of troops before a full peace process can begin. Parliament calls on Member States and the EEAS to establish clear criteria that would allow the lifting of sanctions against Russia. Finally, with regard to Ukraine, the text also recalls that the signing of the Association Agreement must result in the implementation of the necessary economic, political and institutional reforms in Ukraine, for a real exit from the crisis.

name: Adam Gierek (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. - The resolution is generally right, because it calls for peace in eastern Ukraine, but unfortunately quite one-sided, because it lacks the deeper reflections resulting from knowledge of many facts, especially historical ones, and a better understanding of the diverse identity of the societies of the various regions of Ukraine and the role of Russia. Unfortunately, the eu's flawed policy of the so-called 'Eastern Partnership' has raised excessive, difficult-to-meet expectations of parts of Ukraine's population, resulting in already predictable consequences. Unfortunately, this situation may lead to a humanitarian catastrophe in the coming winter. It may be further compounded by the economic sanctions that are unfortunately called for in the resolution. It's a mistake. However, I consider the call for a ceasefire to be a fundamental value, disagreeing with this unilateral interpretation of the facts in the resolution, as well as the calls for sanctions, the consequences of which will be felt by everyone now and in the future. This can only open the way to talks that will peacefully shape the future Ukrainian state. That is why, despite many objections to the text of the resolution, I voted in favour of it. However, I do not want to emphasise with all my strength one point: to call on the international community to support the ukrainian people in the material, to support it in order to survive the winter and to avoid a humanitarian catastrophe in the country.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Amendment 8: UKIP is deeply concerned by the escalation of the crisis in Ukraine, and feels the grandstanding that occurred in Parliament on 16 September only deepened the potential for a prolonged crisis. We welcome this amendment that stresses that dialogue, not military action, is the means to a peaceful solution.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing. - (IT) Every effort must be made to facilitate dialogue between Ukraine and Russia without losing sight of the fact that sanctions cannot replace a diplomatic and political solution that we all hope will be found as soon as possible. There is an urgent need to find an immediate and peaceful way out while keeping the communication channels open and ready to review sanctions and their repercussions in the event of positive feedback. I am thinking in particular of what is happening in my country's agriculture and, although I have listened to Commissioner Ciolos' determinations, I insist on the need to establish rules that are clear so that each Member State can actually benefit from the aid in relation to its own production peculiarities. It is clear to everyone, however, that the funds are insufficient and that more money is needed. For Italy the estimated damage is EUR 200 million. Sicily, which produces grapes and citrus fruits, has barely had time to communicate, through AGEA, to only three requests from producers, that the funds have been blocked. Appropriations must also be made available for the crisis in the citrus fruit market. We need to think about special and extraordinary funds to be disbursed directly to companies.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Amendment No 14 voted no to the first part because it puts a number of conditions on Russia by taking Russia's partisan use of the conflict for a fact. Both Russia and the rebels of the east and the Kiev government appear to be taking steps towards a negotiated peace process. The second part of that amendment has been voted yes because it calls for cooperation with the Eurasian Economic Union by adopting a position in favour of dialogue and peaceful resolution of the conflict. It voted against Amendment No 11 because it accepts that NATO will take a key role in the conflict, even accepting NATO's permanent military presence. The approval of rapid intervention forces and statements on the conflict so far show that NATO is taking a challenging position and acting in a way that encourages hostilities to return.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: In writing. - In recent times of turmoil in relations between Ukraine and the European Union, we must support all peace initiatives but also remain clear about the intentions of Russia, which is engaged in the undeclared "hybrid war" it is waging against Ukraine.  It is in this context that I have contributed my voice to this resolution calling on the European Union to stand up to Russia by strengthening the sanctions, and to strengthen support for European farmers heavily affected by the trade embargo. While we can welcome the signing of the Minsk ceasefire agreement, we must deplore the fact that it has been violated by Russian troops and separatist forces. However, it is much more in the path of a political solution, not a military one, that all efforts must be made. Finally, I welcome the Decision of the French Government to suspend the delivery of the "Mistral" helicopter carriers to Russia, with the other Member States having to go in the same direction.

name: Eduard-Raul Hellvig (PPE)
text: in writing. - I believe that it is time for the European Union to speak with one voice and act in a coordinated manner in relation to Russia. After half a year of ineffective waveovers and sanctions, the Ukrainian conflict is on the verge of a Russia-friendly winter. In the face of the spectre of a gas crisis in Europe and the possible occupation of eastern Ukraine, the EU must make more than symbolic gestures. Ukraine has already paid a painful blood tribute for its European aspiration. That is why I voted in favour of this resolution, which calls for united action on the Member States to improve the EU's energy security and its ability to counter the asymmetrical challenges on the part of Russia. More firmness is needed in the face of Russia's violation of international borders and norms. The EU can no longer afford hesitation and steps, because there is a danger of feeding the Kremlin's aggression towards former Soviet states. In this context, I would like to draw attention to the risk that the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement will remain only a symbolic gesture, unless it is quickly ratified by the Member States of the Union and postponed its entry into force until the end of 2015.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. - The European Parliament has rightly denounced the Russian embargo on agricultural and food products, the immediate and disastrous repercussions of which we know in France. I am a strong supporter of French agriculture and am particularly concerned about this retaliatory measure, the effects of which are now spreading to other sectors such as the transport sector. The European Parliament calls on the parties to the conflict to dialogue and find a diplomatic and peaceful solution, which I welcome. However, I will remain cautious when it comes to discussing relations with our Russian partner, a major economic power and member of the G8. I have indeed read amendments calling Russia an authoritarian state. It would not be in the interest of the European Parliament to throw oil on the fire by further straining the parties currently in negotiations.  Let us not pour into caricature and rather be a support for the diplomatic path if we wish to put an end to this crisis as soon as possible.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Amendment No 14 voted no to the first part because it puts a number of conditions on Russia by taking Russia's partisan use of the conflict for a fact. Both Russia and the rebels of the east and the Kiev government appear to be taking steps towards a negotiated peace process. The second part of that amendment has been voted yes because it calls for cooperation with the Eurasian Economic Union by adopting a position in favour of dialogue and peaceful resolution of the conflict. It voted against Amendment No 11 because it accepts that NATO will take a key role in the conflict, even accepting NATO's permanent military presence. The approval of rapid intervention forces and statements on the conflict so far show that NATO is taking a challenging position and acting in a way that encourages hostilities to return.

name: Anneli Jäätteenmäki (ALDE)
text: Written. - I voted today in favour of the resolution on Ukraine and EU-Russia relations. Russia's actions during the Ukraine crisis, as well as the invasion of Crimea, are actions contrary to international law. However, I would like to say that sanctions are not a wise solution in a situation where the parties have agreed on a truce. I will not sign paragraph 13 of the resolution, in which Parliament calls on the EU to consider excluding Russia from civil nuclear cooperation and the Swift system. Marginalising Russia from such cooperation will not contribute to peace in Ukraine. After parliament's vote, the Finnish Minister of Economic Affairs said that Parliament's resolution is only a statement and Finland will not cancel the nuclear energy project with Russia.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. - I voted Yes because I am convinced that Ukraine deserves a European perspective. I have tabled an amendment in which I have demanded that the process of decentralisation or devolution of Ukraine incorporate the need for the best European practice of protecting ethnic and linguistic differences. Unfortunately, my amendment was not accepted.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the situation in Ukraine and the relations between the European Union and Russia. The resolution welcomes the ceasefire agreement reached and calls for the establishment of a genuine peace process, while stressing the inviolability and integrity of ukrainian territory. Russia's ambiguous role is also condemned. The resolution was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution to call for the continuation of the ceasefire in eastern Ukraine and for strict implementation of the Minsk agreements. Ukraine's unity and independence must be strictly guaranteed. To do this, it is important to work for a political solution to this conflict and to avoid any further escalation, including by completely isolating Russia at the international level. Nevertheless, it was fundamental in this resolution to strongly condemn Russia for its actions and to support the latest sanctions adopted against it by the EU. In the face of Moscow's retaliatory measures, namely the boycott of fruit, vegetables, meat, dairy products and fisheries from the EU, it is important that European producers are duly compensated. In addition, given the current particularly complicated situation, the EU must reduce its dependence on Russia in various areas (energy, technology, etc.). Finally, with regard to the association agreement between the EU and Ukraine, approved by the European Parliament and that of Kiev, it was essential to resist Russian pressure by saying that nothing could change it.

name: Sandra Kalniete (PPE)
text: Writing. - I voted in favour of the resolution on the situation in Ukraine and European relations with Russia, as the EP condemned the repeated Russian 'hybrid war' against Ukraine and expressed serious concerns about a possible further offensive by Russian troops with the aim of establishing a 'land corridor' to Crimea and further to Transnance. Importantly, for the first time, the EP document makes it clear that the contract for supplying Mistral warships to Russia does not comply with the EU Code of Conduct on Arms Exports and the EU's common rules on the control of exports of military technology and equipment. I believe that clear indicators should be adopted, compliance with which would allow the suspension or lifting of sanctions against Russia. On the other hand, the possibility of using NON-AGRICULTURAL EU funds to mitigate the effects of 'counter-sanctions' should also be examined. In my opinion, it is essential that the EP resolution stresses that EU and NATO member states can supply Ukraine, at bilateral level, with the necessary weapons, techniques and technologies for its security and defence, and that, in future, Ukraine has every right to stand as a candidate for EU member status.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the resolution asking all sides to respect the ceasefire and implement it without delay and further loss of life. Russia must cease supporting pro-Russian separatists in eastern Ukraine and stop the flow of military equipment and soldiers through the Russian-Ukrainian border. Further sanctions must be implemented if Russia continues to escalate the situation in Ukraine. The territorial integrity of Ukraine must be respected. The EU should also focus on supporting direct talks between Ukraine and Russia in its efforts to assist Ukraine with regaining stability and implementing crucial political and economic reforms.

name: Gabrielius Landsbergis (PPE)
text: in writing. - I welcome the resolution adopted by the EP. Ukraine now needs all our help in withstanding the hybrid war waged against her by Russia and our support for responding to huge economic challenges and staying on the path of the European reforms. At the same time, I am calling on Member States to adopt and implement full ban on any arms deliveries to Russia. The French Government's decision to suspend the planned delivery of the Mistral assault ships to Russia is a step in the right direction; however, the contract must be cancelled. This is the question of credibility and effectiveness of the EU policies towards the Russian invasion and occupation of its neighbour's territories. Taking into account that by cancelling the contract France will suffer financial losses worth more than 1.2 bln euros, the Member States should consider compensatory mechanism and modalities of engaging the Mistral ships in the EU related missions, such as Frontex in the Mediterranean.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. - I support the ceasefire agreement between separatists and Ukrainian authorities in the east of the country and a settlement through dialogue of the current crisis. The text of the resolution proposed to us, however, goes far beyond relations between Ukraine and Russia. The European Union can act as a moderator in the current crisis. But the resolution lacks impartiality as it calls for more sanctions against Russia, while supporting the EU-Ukraine free trade agreement. Ukraine must be able to choose its own path outside of any foreign influence and interference, find a system of government that will address the concerns of a part of its population in the east, and find a modus vivendi with Russia that addresses its concerns without Ukraine losing its sovereignty. This must be done out of any pressure, whether from Russia with gas prices or from the European Union with the free trade agreement.

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. - Ukraine's relations with Russia must be balanced so as not to escalate the conflict, which has already absorbed many civilian casualties. The European Union should try to resolve this conflict. At the same time, diplomatic relations with Russia cannot be severed, as it will be very difficult to rebuild them.

name: Paloma López (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted against this resolution because it is obvious that the spiral of violence in Ukraine is the result of a coup against legitimate President Yanukovich instigated by the US and the EU itself. In fact, the very partnership agreement that has just been signed by the EU with Ukraine, which was what led to the coup d'am, is being used as a weapon against Russia. This, coupled with the new sanctions adopted by the Council against Russia on 12 September, can by no means be regarded as an example of the EU's good neighbour to Russia.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. - In general, I voted against this resolution, although it was not a personal vote (as in July 2014) and MePs voted by raising their hands. I raised my hand against. Despite the fact that, as part of the personal vote, I supported certain amendments to the resolution from our group (on a political solution to the conflict, etc.), the resolution as a whole was such that it would unfortunately not promote the development of political dialogue between Russia and the EU.

name: Ramona Nicole Mănescu (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution. I welcome the signing of the Minsk ceasefire agreement. This agreement must be fully and in good faith in order to lead to a genuine peace process. I support the commitment to independence, sovereignty, territorial integrity, the inviolability of Ukraine's borders and its European option. There is a need to significantly improve energy security, ensure the EU's independence from external pressure, by strengthening the energy sector, developing energy infrastructure in neighbouring EU countries and developing energy interconnections between these EU countries. I believe that the EU's only viable response to Russia's threats is to be united, to send a unified message, to abandon the concept of strategic partnership and to identify a new unified approach.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The current situation in Ukraine and the state of EU-Russia relations show, inter alia, the weakness of EU policy, the powerlessness of the European Parliament in solving specific problems, the dangerous uncontrollability of the work of members of the European Commission. An example is the preparation of an association agreement between Ukraine and the European Union, which took place behind closed doors. The European Union has been blindly dragged into foreign disputes that are damaging it, whether it is internal conflicts or the most extreme global political games. Loud anti-Russian rhetoric everywhere, russia's role as the culprit for the current Ukraine crisis, and mutual recriminations cannot solve anything, but rather contributes to the escalation of relations. The current crisis cannot be solved by military means. Diplomatic negotiations must be conducted and a way out of the crisis through dialogue, political, constitutional and economic reforms. Politicians in the 21st century should address even the most dramatic divisions in society and with each other through negotiations, not shootings, not anti-government coups. No physical violence. Peace was at the heart of the first agreements they directed towards the Union. Negotiation and compliance with agreements are a condition of peace. We must assume our share of responsibility for peace in Europe and speak out in support of respect for eu-Ukraine-Russia international law and agreements. I voted against the joint resolution.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. This motion for a resolution paints the one-sided picture of this conflict, which is influenced by the Western media. When it comes to the situation in Ukraine and relations with Russia, Russia is automatically blamed. The motion clearly speaks of an "illegal annexation" of Crimea, although this is controversial under international law, especially since a large majority in the region voted for Russia. Furthermore, I do not think that the proposal to send NATO troops and weapons to Ukraine is effective, as it would exacerbate the situation and harden the fronts. I have therefore voted without hesitation against this motion for a resolution.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. - This inequitous resolution denounces the Russian "aggression" in Ukraine and calls for the continuation of sanctions against Russia. To justify these statements, it presents as proven facts very questionable assertions such as "the inability of investigators to access the site of the MH17 crash" or the presence of a "continuous flow of weapons and ammunition from Russia". But without any reaction as to the presence of Svoboda in the government. Or on the Azof division that makes up the bulk of the Ukrainian troops and which has the same emblem as the Nazi division "Das Reich" responsible among other things for the massacre of Oradour on Glane. I am voting against this bellicose text. I therefore welcome the defeats of the neo-Nazi "Ukrainian" armed gangs.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. - The situation in Ukraine is of particular concern to me. I consider it to be a strategic country in Europe, which has been successively undermined by Russia. The EU cannot ignore the escalation of the military conflict in eastern Ukraine, in which russian military personnel are known to be fighting Ukrainian forces alongside separatist rebels. There is also an EU-Ukraine Association Agreement and an Agreement on a Comprehensive and Deep Free Trade Area, signed on 27 June 2014, which must be respected and safeguarded. The EU's foreign policy must be at the forefront of unequivocal support for Ukraine in drawing up a peace plan. The EU must maintain good neighbourly relations with Russia, but it must be intimidated by its threats to Ukraine. We must be uncompromising in defending Ukraine's sovereignty, even if we have to extend the economic embargo measures on Russia.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The situation in Ukraine and EU-Russia relations are of paramount importance. It is essential that in this type of conflict, the EU can speak with one voice. I strongly condemn the "hybrid war" waged by Moscow that deliberately blows hot and cold. The ceasefire protocol between Kiev and the separatist rebels does not allow us not to remain vigilant when we see his repeated violations. A total withdrawal of Russian troops as well as armed separatist groups, thus ensuring Ukraine's territorial integrity, is a prerequisite for the resumption of EU-Russia political dialogue. In the meantime, I welcome NATO's decision to establish a joint intervention force that can be quickly mobilized.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution which sets out the state of affairs in Ukraine and EU/Russia relations. The European Parliament calls for all parties to respect the ceasefire and to avoid decisions that could compromise it.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. The present motion for a resolution paints a partly one-sided picture when it comes to the situation in Ukraine and relations with Russia. He speaks clearly, for example, of an "illegal annexation" of Crimea, although this is controversial under international law and a large majority of the predominantly Russian population in the region voted in favour of joining Russia. Furthermore, I do not think that NATO's proposal to send troops and weapons to Ukraine is effective, as it would exacerbate the situation and harden the fronts. I have therefore voted against this motion for a resolution.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Although the resolution reflects the relative improvement of the situation following the signing of the ceasefire in Minsk, the text promotes solutions that take too much sides of the conflict and thus threaten the security of the region and the Ukrainians. Similarly, the promotion of the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement cannot serve the interests of the Ukrainian people knowing that this treaty is one of the reasons that has led Ukraine to tear itself apart for several months now. I did not vote in favour of this text.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. – I condemn any interference in violation of the territorial integrity of a state. I voted against this resolution because the policy of sanctions has not led to a defuse of the crisis. On the contrary, EU member countries are economically and commercially affected by the continuing and increasing sanctions. The cold war climate in EU-Russia relations affects us first and foremost, and that is why we need to find a window of dialogue and cooperation with Moscow. The policies imposed by the United States must not be in agreement with us, as they create more tension and have a clear impact on the economies of the EU Member States and on the EU's relations with Russia. It is a great hypocrisy for the EU to react directly to the case of Ukraine, but it is not the same with my country, Cyprus, which has been under occupation for 40 years, nor with Palestine. In these cases, the EU has not rushed to sanction either the crimes committed and continue to be committed, or the violation of international law and human rights. Is EU policy a two-metre and two-station policy? The EU should develop initiatives to defuse the crisis instead of acting as a destabilising and divisive factor.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: in writing. – After the ratification of the EU-Ukraine agreement on Tuesday, Ukraine decided that the direction it wants to take in future is Europe. Therefore, we call on Russia to respect this decision and back the peace plan offered by Ukraine. I very much support the call for Member States to act coherently and ban arms and military equipment sales to Russia.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I am extremely in favour of the adoption of the European Parliament's resolution on the situation in Ukraine and on the state of relations between the European Union and Russia, because it was urgent for the European Parliament to take a clear and precise position. In this sense, I support this resolution because it establishes a rigorous political line in the face of Russia's actions. Nevertheless, the facts of the conflict should be best stated in order to establish such a policy on an unshakeable basis. Thus, I voted against Amendment No. 9, because the assertion that the ceasefire serves as a pretext for Russian troops to establish a "land corridor" to Crimea and Transdistria could not be proven.

name: Laurențiu Rebega (S&D)
text: in writing. - I argue that it is necessary and natural for the European institutions, in particular the European Commission, to monitor the effects of 'Russian counter-sanctions' and to take urgent measures to support and protect all producers affected by the trade restrictions imposed. It would be good for the Commission in the future to be better prepared to properly support agricultural producers. Perishable fruit and vegetable markets are currently the most affected. The new system from the Commission is expected and welcome.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Amendment No 14 voted no to the first part because it puts a number of conditions on Russia by taking Russia's partisan use of the conflict for a fact. Both Russia and the rebels of the east and the Kiev government appear to be taking steps towards a negotiated peace process. The second part of that amendment has been voted yes because it calls for cooperation with the Eurasian Economic Union by adopting a position in favour of dialogue and peaceful resolution of the conflict. It voted against Amendment No 11 because it accepts that NATO will take a key role in the conflict, even accepting NATO's permanent military presence. The approval of rapid intervention forces and declarations on the conflict so far show that NATO is taking a challenging position and acting in a way that encourages hostilities to return.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted against this resolution because it is obvious that the spiral of violence in Ukraine is the result of a coup against legitimate President Yanukovich instigated by the US and the EU itself. In fact, the very partnership agreement that has just been signed by the EU with Ukraine, which was what led to the coup d'am, is being used as a weapon against Russia. This, coupled with the new sanctions adopted by the Council against Russia on 12 September, can by no means be regarded as an example of the EU's good neighbour to Russia.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. - I support the European Parliament's resolution on the situation in Ukraine and the state of relations between the EU and Ukraine. With this resolution, the European Parliament welcomes the signed ceasefire signed in Minsk and calls on all parties involved in the conflict to respect and not jeopardise it.  It is important to condemn the role of the Russian Federation in this conflict, from using regular Russian forces in combat, arming illegal militias as well as denying its role in all of this. The European Parliament hereby reaffirms its commitment to safeguarding Ukraine's territorial integrity, inability of borders and independence, as well as the choice of Ukraine's European path. It must be stressed that artificial creations, such as the Donetsk Republic or the illegal secession of Crimea, are neither recognised nor recognised by the international community.  I welcome the simultaneous signing of the Association Agreement in the European and Ukrainian Parliaments, which represents the strong will of both sides to successfully implement the determinants of the agreement. We also strongly advocate further and even stronger sanctions on Russia for ukraine's violations of international law, with increased scrutiny of their implementation. We call on the Commission to closely monitor the impact of Russian counter-agreements on EU markets, so that appropriate action can be taken, in particular on agriculture and fisheries. This Resolution is of great importance for the stability and security of the whole of Europe.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. - I am voting against because I regard the European Union as the main culprit of the Russian-Ukrainian crisis both with its attitude and with its anti-Russian policy and finally because in other cases it has not respected the sovereign rights of other countries (e.g. Serbia and Kosovo) as it is now rushing to call for the non-federalisation of Ukraine.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. - I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution. This is because I fundamentally do not agree with the European Parliament adopting a resolution on the situation in Ukraine two days after the vote on the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement. The Association Treaty is a clear signal to Ukraine and to all citizens of the European Union. It is a step of symbolic and historical importance that we can proudly undertake in the interests of both parties. In addition, the parties must show restraint. We must allow sanctions on Russia to work, as has already been done. We must also wait for the election in Ukraine on 26 October. In the present situation, the adoption of such a resolution is not in the interest of either the Ukrainian side or the European Union.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I have, of course, voted in favour of this text. As the crisis in Ukraine worsened, relations between the European Union and Russia reached their lowest point since the end of the Cold War. In this context, we welcome the ceasefire in eastern Ukraine and call on all parties to respect it. New sanctions should only be implemented if Russia continues to worsen the situation in Ukraine. However, the EU must focus on supporting direct negotiations between Ukraine and Russia, as well as on the OSCE (Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe) assistance to Ukraine in restoring stability and implementing crucial political and economic reforms.  Ukraine's territorial integrity must be respected. Russia's international partners are still waiting for Russia to stop supporting Russian separatists in eastern Ukraine and stop the flow of military equipment and soldiers across the Russian-Ukrainian border.

name: Yana Toom (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I decided not to support the resolution for the following reasons. First, the resolution largely ignores the fact that the Ukraine crisis is essentially a civil war, even if with significant involvement by foreign actors. Second, in the period of the long-expected ceasefire the resolution justifies the logic of sanctions which proved to be inefficient in the case of such a complicated partner as Russia. Furthermore, existing sanctions and calls for new sanctions may undermine the fragile peace process in Ukraine. Third, the resolution does not pay enough attention to the issue of human rights violations by all parties involved into the conflict. I am especially worried that the signals sent to the Ukrainian Government in this respect are too vague to be taken seriously. Fourth, some statements in the resolution are based on media reports, low-quality analytics and/or based on information from biased or unreliable sources.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted against this resolution because it is obvious that the spiral of violence in Ukraine is the result of a coup against legitimate President Yanukovich instigated by the US and the EU itself. In fact, the very partnership agreement that has just been signed by the EU with Ukraine, which was what led to the coup d'am, is being used as a weapon against Russia. This, coupled with the new sanctions adopted by the Council against Russia on 12 September, can by no means be regarded as an example of the EU's good neighbour to Russia.

name: Johannes Cornelis van Baalen (ALDE)
text: Written. - Hans van Baalen (ALDE/VVD) was unable to take part in the votes on the EU Association Agreement with Ukraine in Strasbourg on Tuesday 16 September due to political commitments in the Netherlands. He fully supports the Association Agreement and should therefore be considered to have voted in favour.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. – The action undertaken by Russia has led me to support today’s resolution which urges the EU to take a greater stand against Russian action in Ukraine. I support the action undertaken by France to halt its delivery of the helicopter carriers to Russian authorities. In addition to this, I support the call to expand EU sanctions against Russia by excluding them from civil nuclear cooperation and the SWIFT international payment system.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - On this subject we can and must remember that it was the refusal to sign the association agreement by the former President of Ukraine at the Vilnius Summit that led to restraining acts of interference by the US, NATO and the EU (including many MEPs) that led to the coup d'état. This coup d'état was enthusiastically supported by the EU, despite all the properly documented trampling, with fascist armed gangs pursuing left-wing politicians and trade unionists. We can't help but remember the murder of dozens of helpless citizens by these gangs when they set fire to the union house in Odesa, killing 46 people. The European Union cannot pretend that it does not know when it negotiates with illegal governments, of which fascist parties are part and that, after removing the Communist Party of Ukraine from parliament, they are preparing for their illegalisation.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. - The joint resolution on the situation in Ukraine and the current state of EU-Russia relations clearly expresses the European Parliament's position on the situation created at the east of the EU border and also concerns the maintenance of European prospects for Ukraine. In this document, MePs strongly condemn the Russian Federation for waging an undeclared hybrid war against Ukraine, using russian regular forces and supporting illegal armed groups.  I also voted for the resolution because it reiterates the view that the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement, recently endorsed by European and Ukrainian parliamentarians, is not the ultimate objective of EU-Ukraine relations. The resolution stresses that, in accordance with Article 49 of the Treaty on European Union, Ukraine - like any other European State - has a European perspective and can ask to become a member of the European Union, provided that it has its principles of democracy, respects fundamental freedoms, human rights and the rights of minorities and ensures the rule of law.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This resolution is an authentic piece of war propaganda, the version that whiten and supports the nationalist, fascist and neo-Nazi forces that have taken power in Kiev and who try to forcethe eastern regions of the country with the hegemony of their political and national power, a unilateral version that corresponds to the interests and aspirations of the United States , NATO and the EU in the economic and political colonization of Ukraine and its strategy of siege and confrontation with Russia.  It seeks to pass over the millions of dollars that the US has assumed to have spent in Ukraine to build a regime conducive to its interests, the responsibilities of the major EU powers and NATO in the brutal interference triggered after the ukrainian president's refusal to sign the Association Agreement at the Vilnius Summit, which would later be deposed by force , it is clear that the EU has negotiated this agreement with fascist and neo-Nazi coup forces in the meantime. The ceasefire is welcomed, but this position is hypocritical, while at the same time valuing NATO's decision to strengthen Ukraine's ability to ensure its own security and supports the supply of the necessary arms, technology and knowledge by Member States to Ukraine.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE). -
text: I welcome the fact that the European Parliament has adopted a clear position on the occurrence of a serious infectious disease. The crisis surrounding the Ebola outbreak is complex. It has political, economic and social contexts and consequences that will persist even after the primary health threat has been over. The outbreak of this disease is no longer just a west African problem, but a global problem.  Action is needed in two directions. On the one hand, to support the rapid development of effective medicines and therapies, but, on the other hand, to pay close attention to ensuring quarantine and clinical care. It turns out that this quarantine only works when the population has confidence in health workers and the government, which is not the case in Liberia, and therefore the EU should use all diplomatic possibilities to stabilise the political situation in Liberia as well.

name: Sirpa Pietikäinen (PPE). -
text: Mr President, there is no reason to intimidate citizens with health threats, but we all know that in an open global world where people and goods move, all health risks and threats are genuinely global. That is why, from now on, the European Union must continue to strengthen its own rapid response capability in terms of transnational health risks and acute infections. With regard to Ebola, the measures have been reasonably adequate and proportionate to the level of risk and the severity of the disease. I believe that the European Union should develop this into a viable rapid response model for all infections and serious infectious diseases.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Sierra Leone, Guinea Conakry, Liberia and other countries in the African region are suffering from an Ebola epidemic that adds to their conditions of extreme poverty. The EU, the US and the international community have turned their backs on outbreaks for years, only when they have seen that they could reach our walls and could not stop it, have reacted, not to save Africans but themselves. Large pharmaceutical companies are not interested in the diseases of the poor. This voracity of economic elites is as voracious as Ebola itself. I voted against this resolution because it is advocating to send civil and military aid. What these countries need are doctors, treatment units and medical equipment, not military ones.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. The international community and the European Union must step up their efforts to counter the rampant Ebola epidemic in West Africa. It is a tragedy that more than 2 400 people have already died as a result of the virus. The WHO describes the Ebola epidemic in West Africa as a public health emergency of international importance. The United Nations has also called for the ebola virus to be combated by all means. The Ebola epidemic poses a threat to national and international security. Sufficiently researched drugs are missing. So far, only experimental medicines exist. I have already referred to this in a written question to the Commission. So far, only early detection and isolation of cases of illness have been effective. The West African states need our help for this. I therefore welcome the fact that on 5 September 2014 the European Commission announced funding of €140 million for the West African countries affected by the Ebola virus. However, in view of the catastrophic conditions in the affected regions, the EU must continue to step up its efforts and coordinate its actions with the other international partners. This includes, in particular, the intensive promotion of medical research so that reliable vaccines and cures against the Ebola virus can finally be used.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. – I applaud the work done by the various aid agencies and brave doctors and nurses from the United Kingdom and around the world, who have risked their lives to combat the Ebola virus. I believe that international help and support must be given to prevent the spread of this virus. However, as a UKIP MEP my view is that this is best co-ordinated through the World Health Organisation, the United Nations and the individual nation states themselves. The European Union is not well placed to take action.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. - The fight against an epidemic of this magnitude requires coordinated and determined action by the European Union but also coordination of the efforts of the international community including the African countries concerned. The aim is not only to combat the health ravages of the disease, but also to ensure the food supply of the affected areas in order to avoid many additional deaths. The role of the Union's development cooperation policy is once again essential here.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. In response to the rapid spread of the Ebola virus, which has already claimed 2,430 lives for 4,907 cases as of 15 September, this epidemic has been classified by WHO as a public health emergency of international concern.  The committee announced an 'Ebola package' worth 140 million euros and it was decided to launch immediate preparations for the development of a European mechanism for coordinating medical evacuations. In total, up to 20,000 people are expected to be infected and 373 million euros, according to studies, will be needed to stop the epidemic.  Some airlines have suspended flights from Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone. The National Front called for the suspension of these flights to and from these countries.  On this resolution, I have therefore decided to consider that, in view of the current situation, it is now necessary for us to engage in a rapid action plan, whether it be for the deployment of medical teams, the creation of treatment centres, the implementation of a sustainable risk management policy, the search for vaccine or the information and awareness of the population.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. - Since the beginning of the Ebola epidemic in Africa, I have taken action to call for EU action to stem the spread of the virus. The resolution we are voting on, albeit belatedly, calls for stronger action by Europe with development policies that move towards greater prevention, improvement of medical and social infrastructure in Africa and coordination of existing interventions in order to maximise results, for all these reasons I supported it with my vote.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution because the international community must play a more important role, and African countries must also take a share of their responsibility, because the Ebola outbreak threatens global security and is not only a problem in West Africa, but a global problem. Thus, in the fight against the Ebola outbreak, the European Parliament calls on the Commission to step up its efforts and coordinate with the United Nations. The European Parliament, in this resolution, is calling on the UN Security Council, together with the partner countries where the Ebola outbreak occurred, to consider the use of military and civil defence resources under the authority of the Secretary-General and coordination with the Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs.  The European Parliament also calls on the Council and the Commission to support and promote the African Union with regard to the necessary comprehensive action plan, as the situation continues to deteriorate rapidly and affects the economies and public order of the countries concerned. The Ebola crisis is complex and has political, security, economic and social consequences, which will have an impact on the region for a long time after this emergency.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. - (IT) I am voting in favour: although it does not entirely satisfy, it is a text which aims to deal with the spread of the virus quickly.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. - I voted in favour of the resolution on the Ebola epidemic. Since the beginning of this epidemic, the Structures of the European Commission have already provided EUR 147 million in humanitarian aid and treatment to help contain the virus, but our response remains slow. Affected regions of Central Africa do not have a suitable health system to contain the epidemic, which has security implications in the region. By carrying out coordinated action with the UN, the EU will therefore provide comprehensive assistance: not only health and logistics, but support for health care training, education and prevention, health and nutrition assistance, always supplementing long-term development assistance. The role of the African Union as a regional organization that can provide local responses is to be highlighted.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. - The Ebola virus epidemic, which has exploded in West Africa, has been underestimated by the international community and is now a challenge to global security. The countries affected are facing socio-economic collapse. I voted in favour of this resolution to call for more resources and operational capacity, including qualified human resources and logistical material.  I call on the Member States to coordinate flights and establish dedicated air bridges, and I call on the European Commission to draw up an assessment of the specific needs and plans for each affected country, in order to determine and coordinate the request for and the sending of health personnel, mobile laboratories, protective clothing and treatment centres. In addition, the African Union should be encouraged to consider a comprehensive action plan, as the crisis has become complex and has political implications. As far as medical research is concerned, I stress the importance of advancing clinical trials of treatment tested against the Ebola virus.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP has profound concerns about the risk of Ebola to the British people. This is particularly true given the lack of proper border controls, which could possibly allow recently killed infected meat into the country. However UKIP respects the courage of aid workers who are helping those in areas of outbreak and wishes to convey our deepest condolences to all those suffering as a result of this disease.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. - The Ebola virus has already killed more than 2000 people in West Africa, and according to the World Health Organization, the contagion could spread to 20,000 people over the next 3 months. NGOs such as Médecins sans frontières have issued an alarm about the inadequacy of the international community's responses to the spread of contagion (which has already affected, in addition to Guinea, 4 other African states). Europe must equip itself to prevent the spread of the virus within its borders, and we therefore call on the Commission to provide more funds for the affected areas but also to provide intensive protection for our southern borders through an increase in rescue operations and medical assistance for migrants.  The institutions common to the 28 Member States must realise that the EEA is a problem to be tackled globally and needs a globally coordinated response.  We also want to stress the need for a collective effort, not just an Italian one, to give relief to the tens of thousands of desperate people attempting to cross into the schengen countries.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. - (IT) This resolution is not only a necessary signal of attention to what has been called by the WHO a "public health emergency of international importance", perhaps initially underestimated. More specifically, it calls on the competent institutions to take specific action to try to remedy the serious shortcomings identified by the most active NGOs on the ground in all aspects of the response: - the possibility of using military and civilian defence resources under the leadership of the UN Secretariat-General;  - coordination by the European Commission of the dispatch of health personnel, mobile laboratories, equipment, protective clothing, treatment centres with isolation departments;   - introduction of control systems to prevent misuse of resources;  - the creation by states of air bridges dedicated to the transfer of personnel and equipment to the countries affected. The resolution also highlights the need for action not limited to the health side, given the dramatic implications of the epidemic in all areas of social life (with 4.5 million children under 5 living in the affected areas). The resolution as a whole therefore seems particularly welcome, and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. - As is sadly known since March, the Ebola virus has claimed thousands of lives at an ever-increasing rate.  Although the European Commission has recently stepped up its immediate support to contain the crisis, humanitarian workers are facing increasingly difficult conditions on the ground. This is the largest epidemic ever recorded in terms of cases, victims and geographical extent and, as the WHO has stated, the crisis is a public health emergency of international importance and therefore requires a coordinated international response.  I think it is right for Parliament to state in this resolution that the international community must play a greater role, while african countries must assume their share of responsibility, and that it should therefore call on the Commission to step up its efforts and coordinate action with international partners to combat the epidemic. As expressed in the text of the resolution, the international community has in fact underestimated the crisis and has been slow to draw up an appropriate coordination strategy and, in agreement on this, as on other points, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. - Since it was declared, the Ebola outbreak has affected 4000 people, caused 2000 deaths and spread at a worrying rate in the West African region. I consider the attack on this outbreak, which has a transnational and intercontinental dimension, to be extremely serious, and should receive all possible aid from the European Union. It's not just an Africa problem, it's a challenge to global security. I therefore welcome the EU's commitment, through DG DEVCO and ECHO, to provide more than EUR 147 million in humanitarian aid and development aid to halt the spread of the virus. I also consider it crucial to develop plans adapted to each national reality and to send specialized health professionals, laboratories, equipment and isolation units. Information alrisk actions and prevention measures against this scourge should also be put in place and stigmatisation of surviving patients should be avoided. At the same time, Member States and the Commission should strengthen medical research and the production of effective Ebola medicines and vaccines.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution calling urgently for the deployment of funding, personnel and health equipment to countries affected by the Ebola epidemic. This is an emergency situation that should not be underestimated in any way, all the more so because even the WHO has stated that the number of people affected could exceed 20 thousand cases in the coming months and spread rapidly in the West African region. Even NGOs currently active on the ground believe that international efforts are totally inadequate and deficient.  It is therefore necessary to set up a coordination mechanism with all Member States, the United States and all other international partners as soon as possible, so as to mobilise a medical response capable of developing clinical, epidemiological and diagnostic infrastructures, including surveillance infrastructures and training of local staff. There is no time to lose, there is global security at stake and not just the health of African citizens.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. – To keep the risk of Ebola reaching Europe low, the EU and its Member States must be alert and prepared, and must also assist the African countries in which this human tragedy is taking place. The actions called for in this resolution will strengthen the protection of EU citizens in regard to the risks concerned.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. - In Western Africa, the number of Ebola sufferers and victims continues to increase. Riots are taking place and isolation centres are unable to cope with emergencies. Health workers are among the first to fall victim to the infection and have a frightening number of deaths. Ebola treatment centers are reduced to places where you go to die on your own, and where palliative care and little else are offered. It is impossible to cope with the huge number of infected people pouring into health facilities. For these reasons and in order to ensure that all international plans are put in place to help the countries affected to put an end to the rampant contagion, I could only vote in favour of this resolution.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Sierra Leone, Guinea Conakry, Liberia and other countries in the African region are suffering from an Ebola epidemic that adds to their conditions of extreme poverty. The EU, the US and the international community have turned their backs on outbreaks for years, only when they have seen that they could reach our walls and could not stop it, have reacted, not to save Africans but themselves. Large pharmaceutical companies are not interested in the diseases of the poor. This voracity of economic elites is as voracious as Ebola itself. I voted against this resolution because it is advocating to send civil and military aid. What these countries need are doctors, treatment units and medical equipment, not military ones.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. – The Ebola outbreak was officially declared on 22 March 2014 in Guinea. It has reached four other countries (Liberia, Nigeria, Sierra Leone and Senegal), affected almost 4 000 people, caused more than 2 000 deaths, and is the largest recorded outbreak in terms of cases, deaths and geographical coverage. Information and communication are important tools in fighting the Ebola outbreak and it is essential to facilitate trust and popular cooperation with anti-Ebola measures. It is essential that the EU Member States have the capacity to mobilise immediate response teams to ensure early diagnosis, monitoring of contact persons and tracing of transmission chains, measures for burials, education and local support. I voted for the EU to support and encourage the African Union in regard to the need for a holistic action plan, as the situation is continuing to deteriorate rapidly; and for control systems to be put in place to ensure that the whole of the budget allocated to stopping the Ebola outbreak is actually directed at fighting the epidemic in countries affected by the virus. Furthermore, the Member States and the Commission should coordinate and strengthen medical research and the production of effective medicines and vaccines against Ebola.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution as I support the call for the Commission to take urgent steps towards country-specific plans for qualified health personnel, mobile laboratories, laboratory equipment, protective clothing and treatment centres with isolation wards. I also support efforts to strengthen scientific collaboration and technological support in the areas affected by this outbreak, paying particular attention to the engagement of local staff, including training.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. - I believe that the current crisis after the outbreak of Ebola cannot be solved by health systems alone, and a concerted approach involving different sectors, such as health, education and training, sanitation and food aid, is also needed in order to address critical deficiencies affecting all essential services.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. With this vote, the European Parliament wished to report on the critical health situation in West Africa. Faced with the spread of the Ebola epidemic, this region of the world needs stronger international support. This has led us to call on the international community to step up its efforts. In particular, it is important to encourage the European Commission to act more vigorously in close collaboration with the United Nations and the African Union by developing a needs assessment and country-specific action plans to identify and coordinate aid.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. – We are voting against this plan because the fight against the Ebola virus on the African continent is not the responsibility of the EU but of the UN and the WHO but also of the fact that we oppose the use of military means for the same purpose.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. - Ebola virus has spread in Guinea and four other countries (Liberia, Nigeria, Sierra Leone and Senegal) and has affected nearly 4,000 people, causing more than 2,000 deaths, and taking into account that there are also unconfirmed cases of Ebola infected and fatalities. WHO acknowledges that the outbreak had been underestimated and estimates that the number of patients could exceed 20,000 over the next three months. The Commission should therefore carry out a needs assessment and develop country-specific plans. It is also very important that information and educational actions are taken to raise awareness of symptoms and preventive measures, in order to facilitate people's confidence and cooperation with anti-Ebola measures, as information and communication are an important aspect of the fight against ebola. Finally, It is also necessary for Member States and the Commission to coordinate and strengthen medical research and the production of effective Ebola medicines and vaccines, and to promote the necessary clinical trials.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. - Ebola is one of the most serious cases of public health worldwide and has even led to the proclamation by who of public health emergency on an international scale. The disease first reported in Guinea has spread to four more countries, caused 2000 deaths and affected nearly 4,000 people. Who estimates that the number of patients could exceed 20,000 in the next three months in a region where 4.5 million children under five years of age live and where the large percentage of infected are women. The European Commission has already provided €147 million in humanitarian aid and development aid to halt the spread of the virus, provide essential treatment and equipment to infected people and mobilise humanitarian aid experts. This motion for a resolution, in addition to congratulating field work on partner organisations, calls on the Commission to undertake a needs survey and to draw up plans tailored to each country to determine and coordinate applications, as well as the sending of qualified healthcare professionals, mobile laboratories, laboratory equipment, protective clothing and treatment centres with isolation units.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Since the first reported case this year, about 2460 people have died of hemorrhagic fever; 4700 are infected. If the epidemic is not stopped, only about 2000 children in Liberia will be orphaned. In the most affected countries, the number of cases has grown more than in any other outbreak of this kind. There aren't enough beds to accommodate the sick. There are cases of infected people who are sent home, for lack of hospital means, infecting other family members. The lack of information means that 40% of the infected who overcome the disease are victims of stigma and discrimination, being prevented from returning to normal life. We are facing an unprecedented outbreak, with consequences that go beyond the dead and sick, which must be addressed. The need for funding to respond to the outbreak has grown more than 10-fold in the last month. The victims have doubled. The help that is spoken of in this resolution has nothing altruistic or supportive. It is a protection of the greatest powers against this type of disease.  The resolution welcomes the monetary aid given by the EU – which has been decreasing since 2011. It welcomes the sending of troops to the ground.  These countries need doctors, treatment units, hospital beds and medical equipment. Not military.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. - The sensitive issue of Ebola has always been treated very carefully by our movement.   We strongly point out the need for concrete action and action to prevent the spread of the virus. The vote on the resolution on the risks related to the spread of the Ebola virus is positive, although I lament the lack in this resolution of the issue of immigration as a factor of further aggravation of the danger of contagion given by the spread of the virus.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. – I am voting against the text on the global security issue caused by the Ebola virus because I am opposed to the use of military defence instruments under the leadership of the UN Secretary-General. Tackling the Ebola virus is solely the responsibility of the UN and WHO and not the EU.

name: Mariya Gabriel (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because it highlights the necessary holistic and international response to the Ebola epidemic. The resolution clearly reminds us that the epidemic is not an African problem, but a global threat. An international and coordinated response is needed to contain the epidemic. The rapid progress of the epidemic has surprised the international community and we will have to learn from it, but before that, we must support a shared responsibility of African countries, under the aegis of the African Union in particular, and support their efforts. It is not only about funding but also about concrete means, including qualified and trained medical personnel. As the adopted text indicates, the epidemic highlights on the one hand the challenges of the African continent (porous borders, fragile health and health systems, etc.) and on the other hand, the widely improved international coordination in scientific, medical and humanitarian matters. Finally, the resolution has the merit of anticipating the long-term consequences of the epidemic, including the social consequences, for the African continent, and thus encouraging international partners to propose health, safety and scientific recommendations to mitigate these consequences.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
