text: in writing. – The European Union and the international community must do more and act more promptly to stop the effects of Ebola contamination spilling over. Ebola has killed more than 2 400 people this year and its rapid spread is threatening hundreds of thousands of people. I strongly believe that the international community, together with the African countries, must act quickly in their joint efforts as the virus poses a global security challenge. I supported this resolution because we have to call on the Commission to intensify efforts and coordinate with the United Nations to combat the Ebola virus. Moreover, the Council and the Commission should support the African Union and encourage it to apply a holistic action plan as the situation continues to deteriorate rapidly and is threatening the economies and public order of the countries concerned.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. - The positive vote in favour of the adoption of the Resolution proposed by the European Parliament on the European response to the Ebola outbreak which is tragically hitting is the slightest response we can give to the drama in West Africa. We can't stand by in our arms in front of people who suffer. The humanism that vertebrates European construction must stimulate us to give a firm and complete response to human suffering. The Union is a peace project that has given our continent the greatest social progress in centuries, and which has led us to the current welfare state, and it is our moral obligation, by history, for our values, to help the people who suffer. It is therefore our duty also to urge Member States to increase aid, not only monetary but also in equipment, to countries hit by this human drama. The strengthening of integration ties is also needed so that the Union can provide a faster and sharper response in the field of humanitarian aid

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP has profound concerns about the risk of Ebola to the British people. This is particularly true given the lack of proper border controls, which could allow infected meat into the country. However UKIP respects the courage of aid workers who are helping those in areas of outbreak and wishes to convey our deepest condolences to all those suffering as a result of this disease.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - In point 3, the resolution suggests that "the possibility of using military and civil defence assets" be examined to respond to the crisis. The resolution, in paragraph 4, also supports and encourages the recent increase by the Commission of commitments to support the AFRICAN Union's ASEOWA mission, a mission of a not only civilian but also military nature. That is why I voted NO to this resolution. The Ebola epidemic, since it was officially declared on 22 March in Guinea, has reached four other countries (Liberia, Nigeria, Sierra Leone and Senegal), affected nearly 4000 people and left more than 2000 deaths. International efforts to date have been dramatically inadequate. The interest of most European Parliamentarians in this matter is welcome: A European plan is urgently needed to mobilise, from the Member States, the resources necessary for the provision of effective humanitarian aid, in particular to provide specialised medical personnel and technical equipment, such as mobile laboratories, which favour early warning and isolation cells to slow the pace of contagion. If such a plan includes military departures, it will be ineffective and rejectable.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Paragraph 3 of the resolution suggests that "the possibility of using military and civil defence assets" be examined to respond to the crisis. name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. - I voted for the resolution because it is the only way to involve the European Parliament in the fight against Ebola because it is accepted to introduce better coordination of the fight against Ebola and to invest more money in research into the drug. In addition, it is important that we express support for all those who selflessly help Ebola patients.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on Ebola, which calls for greater involvement of the international community in the fight against the epidemic and calls on the European Commission and member states to take coordinated action in this area. I welcome the adoption of this resolution.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. - I wanted to be a co-signer of the joint resolution on the Ebola outbreak in West Africa. This pandemic poses a real challenge to global security, which the European community must mobilise humanitarian, logistical and financial resources against. Deploring the delay in the international community in the definition and implementation of joint actions, MEPs call for rapid medical mobilization through the deployment of health workers and adapted equipment in areas affected by the epidemic. The resolution also calls on the European community to strengthen medical research and support African Union initiatives to combat the spread of the virus and to address the political, economic, and social consequences of the epidemic for the region.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the resolution calling for an EU emergency plan to fight the Ebola epidemic in West Africa. The Ebola outbreak has so far caused almost 2 000 deaths, reached five African countries, and its spread is fast accelerating, also having consequences for food insecurity. It poses a global security challenge. The international community must therefore mobilise immediately to contain the epidemic. The EU financial assistance is very welcome; however further, coordinated action is needed. We must also look into long-term solutions to strengthen health systems and avoid new epidemics.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. - First of all, I would like to begin my statement by dedicating a thought to the victims of this epidemic and applauding doctors, volunteers and nurses who are working day after day to help the sick. I am one of the signatories of the resolution that has been adopted today, in which we wanted to highlight how the European Parliament will closely monitor developments in the epidemic and promote vigilance. We must not forget that, in order to tackle the Ebola phenomenon correctly and effectively, we must continue to act on two separate levels, the African and the European, putting in place an extraordinary and coordinated effort, among all 28 Member States, also from an economic point of view.

name: Gabrielius Landsbergis (PPE)
text: Writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution. The deadly virus that has hit West Africa, although currently local, can also quickly reach Europe. Especially when we hear about one or other cases of "brought back" virus. The World Health Organisation acknowledges that the outbreak has been underestimated and predicts that the number of patients could climb 20,000 over the next three months.  I agree with the resolution on the need to strengthen scientific cooperation and technological assistance in areas affected by the outbreak. It is also possible to involve medics as widely as possible in educational and prevention work to help predict the signs of this insidious virus as early as possible.  I believe that one of the fundamental principles of action brought together by the international community is coordination in the field of medical research and production of vaccines, transparent and fair testing of vaccines.

name: Paloma López (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Sierra Leone, Guinea Conakry, Liberia and other countries in the African region are suffering from an Ebola epidemic that adds to their conditions of extreme poverty. The EU, the US and the international community have turned their backs on outbreaks for years, only when they have seen that they could reach our walls and could not stop it, have reacted, not to save Africans but to themselves. Large pharmaceutical companies are not interested in the diseases of the poor. This voracity of economic elites is as voracious as Ebola itself. I voted against this resolution because it is advocating to send civil and military aid. What these countries need are doctors, treatment units and medical equipment, not military ones.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. - The European Union must step up its efforts to combat Ebola. This is unequivocal.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe the Ebola outbreak in the west of Africa is very serious and it is only by working together that we will be able to combat it efficiently. Coordinated European action is vital not only in preventing the further spread of disease and death in the region, but also to prevent it from spreading to Europe and other regions.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of Parliament's motion for a resolution on the EU's response to the Ebola virus epidemic, because I am deeply concerned about the continuing worsening of the disease. Given that the Ebola virus crisis has become complex, with political, security, economic and social implications that will continue to affect the current health emergency, I call on the international community to do its utmost to accelerate and develop effective and safe therapies against Ebola and to support African partners and to cooperate closely with them in the fight against this deadly disease. Strongly in line with the European Commission, which has stepped up its response to the epidemic; announcing an additional package of EUR 140 million in funding for countries currently affected by the Ebola virus.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the Ebola epidemic, as it contains a necessary call for a more incisive and targeted phase of action against the spread of the disease to be inaugurated.  Any spread of the epidemic would pose a real threat, not only to the African community, but to global security as a whole.  I think it is right that we MEPs, motivated by the desire to ensure that the citizens of our countries continue to have a proper health situation, support the need to increase the degree of international responsiveness to a phenomenon which, if it continues to spread, could undermine common stability.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. – Initially, this pandemic was so underestimated that the spread of the Ebola virus in West Africa is now a serious global security challenge. In addition, according to the WHO, an increase to more than 20,000 patients is forecast for the next three months. In order to stem the threat of social and economic collapse in the countries concerned, access to existing treatments should be accelerated and the use of UN-led military resources should be considered. In addition to financial resources, appropriate operational capacities are required, in particular qualified personnel and logistical material. I could therefore only agree with this proposal. However, the long-term consequences of this pandemic must also be carefully calculated: the flow of refugees to Europe will increase considerably.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. - The resolution "welcomes and encourages" the mission of ASEOWA of the African Union with the help of the European Union to contain Ebola. It is obviously a matter of doing everything possible to stop this virus and thus protect the populations. Nevertheless, I wonder whether a joint military and civilian mission of AESOWA is appropriate, as is the case and which also includes the sending of American military personnel who are once again taking advantage of the situation. For these reasons I abstain.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. - Ebola virus disease, formerly known as hemorrhagic fever, is a serious, often deadly disease that affects humans. For this reason, the international community must play a more important role and African countries must take their share of responsibility, as the Ebola outbreak poses a challenge to global security and is not just a problem in West Africa, but a global problem. The EU needs to maintain a more effective stance in the difficult fight against this disease, which has killed thousands of African citizens.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The Ebola epidemic is the deadliest in the world to date. I would like to congratulate the existing medical staff and NGOs active on the ground in the 5 countries affected today (Guinea, Liberia, Nigeria, Sierra Leone and Senegal). WHO has declared this epidemic a "global public health emergency", which means that we are not facing an African crisis but a global crisis. The closure of the borders has made it an epidemic of fear, potentially creating a real food crisis. Immediate and coordinated action is essential in the face of the spread of the virus. If African countries are to take responsibility, the international community, the EU, the UN, the AU, must agree on the type of intervention to be put in place. That is why we are calling for a ministerial meeting of the Council of the EU, and a needs assessment for the Commission. This crisis demonstrates the need to urgently address the post-2015 agenda.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. – I support and even co-signed this resolution, which calls on EU Member States to coordinate flights and establish dedicated air bridges in order to move health personnel and equipment to the affected countries as well as to carry out infection control and provide fuller information to improve public awareness on the risks. The resolution calls upon the European Commission to intensify efforts and coordinate actions with the UN to fight the Ebola virus outbreak.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on the European Union's response to the Ebola crisis. Through this vote, we deplore the loss of life in the regions affected by the disease. The problem is not an African problem, but a global one. The international community must play a greater role and African states must take full responsibility. The resolution calls for a series of preventive measures and actions in Africa and Europe. It is vital to take action against the disease and its health and social consequences.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. – Initially underestimated, the spread of the Ebola virus in West Africa is now a serious global security challenge. In addition, according to the WHO, an increase to more than 20,000 patients is forecast for the next three months. In order to stem the threat of social and economic collapse in the countries concerned, access to existing treatments should be accelerated and the use of UN-led military resources should be considered. In addition to financial resources, appropriate operational capacities are required, in particular qualified personnel and logistical material. I agree with these demands and have therefore voted in a positive way.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which is a step forward in the fight against one of the most serious epidemics that Africa has experienced in recent decades, in particular in consolidating the support provided by the EU and its Member States in terms of medical expertise and equipment. The resolution calls for the sending of doctors to the affected countries, as well as better cooperation between African and European countries.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri (S&D)
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the EU's response to the Ebola epidemic. The Ebola epidemic is a challenge to global security and is not just a problem for Africa. The World Health Organization has announced that we are facing the largest epidemic ever recorded in terms of cases, victims and geographical extent and declared that the crisis is "a public health emergency of international importance". The epidemic has been underestimated and it is estimated that the number of patients affected could exceed 20,000 in the next three months. In order to deal with this threat, the international community is called upon to play a more active role. In particular, I call on the Commission and the Member States to step up their efforts and coordinate action with the United States and other international partners; to strengthen scientific cooperation and technological support in the areas affected by the epidemic in order to develop clinical, epidemiological and diagnostic infrastructures that rise to this challenge.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: Writing. - I agree that the international community has underestimated the Ebola virus outbreak, which now poses a global security challenge. The affected countries are at risk of collapse, and the possibility of using UN-flagged military assets and strengthening the fight against the virus should also be explored. Isolation and treatment of patients requires not only financial resources, but also operational capabilities, including skilled human resources and logistics equipment. MePs therefore call on the UN Security Council, together with the countries affected, to consider the possibility of using military and civil protection resources under the leadership of the Secretary-General of the World Organisation. Parliament calls on the Commission to assess the needs and plans for each country in order to deploy qualified medical staff, mobile laboratories, equipment, protective clothing and treatment centres accordingly. EU Member States should coordinate flights and establish dedicated air bridges, and the African Union should be encouraged to draw up an integrated action plan, as the Ebola crisis has become complex and has political, security, economic and social consequences. MePs call on the Member States and the Commission to coordinate and strengthen health research and the production of effective medicines and vaccines and to promote progress in clinical trials. At the same time, it is necessary to make a clear difference between the testing of the vaccine and the treatment of infected persons and to respect the relevant applicable rules of the World Health Organisation.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. - I support the Council and Commission report, as well as the European Union's response to the Ebola epidemic affecting the countries of West Africa. The number of deceased has passed 2100 and about 4000 potential cases have already been recorded. The situation is all the more alarming because there is no clinical treatment or vaccine that has been proven to work, which is why the mortality rate is 25-90%. Consequently, I urge close monitoring of the situation by the Centre for the Coordination of Emergency Action (ERCC), the health authorities of the Member States, the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC), the World Health Organisation (WHO) and all other relevant international institutions.  I welcome the readiness of the Commission, which has to date programmed €156 million to fight the epidemic, of which €5 million is directed to the newly established African Union (AU) Ebola epidemic support mission. Unfortunately, these significant funds have not put the epidemic under control either, which is certainly due to a lack of basic medical and security infrastructure that prevents health care and migration control in affected, often border areas.  For these reasons, I consider sending professional staff and developing primary medical infrastructure in west African countries a priority. It is our moral responsibility to continue to support affected countries while continuing to closely monitor the course of an epidemic that is a serious threat to our citizens, but also a problem that requires long-term international cooperation and humanitarian support.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. - Since March 2014, the Ebola epidemic continues its rapid progression on the African continent and the virus has already infected more than 4,000 people and caused more than 2,000 deaths.  I voted in favour of this resolution, which clearly demonstrates the European Union's support for health actors involved in the fight against this virus. More resources are needed and there is an urgent need for the European Commission and member states to step up their actions. These include helping to strengthen deficient health systems in affected countries, ensuring better information and prevention, and continuing the search for an effective vaccine.  It is also essential that these actions be carried out in cooperation with our international partners, the United Nations and associations. The Ebola epidemic is now a global security challenge.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's resolution on the Ebola epidemic, because the European Union must be aware of this catastrophe, which has been sidelined from our agenda for too long. I therefore deplore the european Union's lack of responsiveness, let alone when it affects the health of EU nationals. Thus, I am in favour of any action aimed at containing this epidemic.

Large pharmaceutical companies are not interested in the diseases of the poor. This voracity of economic elites is as voracious as Ebola itself. I voted against this resolution because it is advocating to send civil and military aid. What these countries need are doctors, treatment units and medical equipment, not military ones.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. - I see positively that the European Union has adopted a position on the occurrence of this deadly virus. A major outbreak of the disease in West African countries such as Guinea, Sierra Leone, Liberia and Nigeria confirms the need for the development of new drugs, possibly by increasing generic production. In particular, they must be affordable so that they can also be deployed effectively in developing countries where the virus has occurred.  The Countries of West Africa have a history of destabilisation and it is therefore necessary to join both humanitarian efforts and negotiations with a view to calming the situation in the region, especially in Liberia.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. - In the face of a historically unprecedented Ebola epidemic, the European Union must do everything possible to contain further spread in cooperation with the World Health Organisation (WHO). It is the obligation of each Member State to introduce maximum protection and infection prevention measures in addition to adequate humanitarian assistance, in particular as regards passenger control. I hereby welcome the European Commission's decision to provide €140 million in development assistance to countries currently affected by the Ebola virus, while stressing the importance of an effective allocation of funds. I also think efforts are needed to find funds to effectively prevent and contain the Ebola virus.  I take the opportunity to commend the courage and dedication of the humanitarian staff on the ground who put their lives at risk every day to help others. I am pleased that the European Union is actively monitoring developments in the affected countries through its experts on the ground who are making assessments and coordinating with other health organisations.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. - I supported the motion for a joint resolution on the EU's response to the Ebola outbreak, because daily the media brings appalling news about the spread of this deadly disease and people die every day as a result of this disease. The World Health Organisation has also acknowledged that this epidemic was underestimated in its early days and gives estimates of possible patients up to 20,000 people. Although deadly Ebola has affected African states, before it spreads to other continents, we must establish rigorous control mechanisms while helping the affected African states in a thorough information campaign, but also in humanitarian and professional medical assistance. This will certainly be helped by the EUR 147 million of funding allocated by the European Commission's Development Assistance Services to humanitarian aid and civil protection in order to prevent the spread of the virus, to provide the most necessary equipment for infected people and to send humanitarian experts.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. - I vote for a resolution by which the European Union is making its efforts in its entirety, together with UN coordinators, to assist Ebola virus sufferers in Guinea, Sierra Leone and Liberia. Namely, the virus is spreading at a rapid rate and if a quick and effective reaction is not taken to stop it, it is estimated that by the end of the year they could have up to 20,000 patients.  Unfortunately, international organisations have underestimated the danger of the Ebola virus and therefore a decisive response from the European Union is needed. I would like to stress that it is extremely important that as much humanitarian aid is sent as possible, as the medical system in infected countries collapses. Mobile hospitals and laboratories, medical equipment and most importantly doctors who are largely lacking should be provided.  Also, I would like to express a big thank you to the doctors who are now in the field and make all their efforts to help the sick, despite the inadequate conditions in which they work.  I believe more funding should be invested in scientific and medical research to find a vaccine against the Ebola virus. This is not just a West Africa problem, but the whole of Europe and the world. That is why it is important to support infected countries, to show them that we stand by them and that we will help them get through this situation.

name: Eleytherios Synadinos (NI)
text: Writing. - I am voting against because the response to the Ebola epidemic is the responsibility exclusively of the UN and the WHO, and I am also opposed to sending military forces under the auspices of the UN Secretary-General.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text. This is a major epidemic. In this regard, I believe that the Belgian government should take its share of responsibility and help NGOs deployed there. Thousands of volunteers are currently risking their lives for the safety of the rest of humanity.  Belgium cannot decently be among those who have chosen inaction. It has the tools to provide this much-needed support. Sending a B-Fast team is a serious possibility; their skills and experience would be of great benefit to organizations on the ground. The delivery of equipment using the F1630s that move weekly in the region would also be highly appreciated.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I strongly support this resolution because it is our responsability as well as that of the EU to act. This resolution stresses that the Ebola epidemic is taking a devastating toll in the now five affected countries: Guinea, Liberia, Nigeria, Sierra Leone, and northern Democratic Republic of the Congo and, according to the WHO, this is the largest recorded outbreak in terms of cases, deaths and geographical coverage and it continues to accelerate. I firmly believe that the international community must play a bigger role while African countries must also take their share of responsibility. The resolution calls on the countries with the resources to respond to disasters, and for additional medical, military and civilian capacities to be sent urgently to West Africa and to be deployed rapidly. In a globalised world, the European Union and the United Nations must agree on the type of intervention which will provide a response to a health emergency on a global scale.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Sierra Leone, Guinea Conakry, Liberia and other countries in the African region are suffering from an Ebola epidemic that adds to their conditions of extreme poverty. The EU, the US and the international community have turned their backs on outbreaks for years, only when they have seen that they could reach our walls and could not stop it, have reacted, not to save Africans but to themselves. Large pharmaceutical companies are not interested in the diseases of the poor. This voracity of economic elites is as voracious as Ebola itself. I voted against this resolution because it is advocating to send civil and military aid. What these countries need are doctors, treatment units and medical equipment, not military ones.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. – The widespread chaos caused by the Ebola epidemic constitutes a challenge to global security, and therefore requires a global answer to combat this dangerous situation. I therefore support today’s resolution calling for an EU emergency plan to fight the on-going Ebola epidemic in West Africa.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. - I voted in favour of the European Parliament's resolution on the EU's response to the Ebola epidemic.  The World Health Organization's latest death toll on this epidemic is nearly 2,630 deaths and 5,357 cases. An already dramatic, yet probably underestimated, balance. It is therefore crucial that the European Union and its Member States mobilise to contain this epidemic.  In particular, the resolution stresses that the international community must have a greater role in the fight against the epidemic and take responsibility for it.  In supporting this resolution, which calls on the European Commission to step up its support to the States concerned and also calls on Member States to draw up an emergency plan to deploy the necessary personnel and equipment to the countries affected by the epidemic, I wished to reiterate that this crisis is not just concerning West Africa but the entire international community and that it is time to mobilise.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - If this epidemic is not stopped, only about 2000 children in Liberia will be orphaned. In the most affected countries, the number of cases has grown more than in any other outbreak of this kind.  The material deficiencies are glaring. The lack of information leads to alarming situations. This is an unprecedented outbreak. The need for funding to respond to the outbreak has grown more than 10-fold in the last month.  The help of this resolution unfortunately has nothing altruistic or supportive.  The resolution welcomes the monetary aid given by the EU – which has been decreasing since 2011 – and the deployment of troops to the ground. These countries need doctors, treatment units, hospital beds and medical equipment. Not military.

name: Jarosław Leszek Wałęsa (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the resolution on the EU’s response to the Ebola outbreak ([2014/2842(RSP)], motions for resolutions RC-B8-0107/2014, B8-0107/2014, B8-0108/2014, B8-0114/2014, B8-0115/2014, B8-0119/2014, B8-0124/2014 and B8-0126/2014). In doing so I extend my deepest apologies to those family members who have lost a loved one to this tragic outbreak. In an attempt to prevent this virus from spreading into Europe I call on everyone to take the necessary precautions to protect themselves and all European citizens. We must support the medical community as they do whatever they can to prevent an outbreak on our continent. This would obviously mean funding and resources adequate for the task at hand. Therefore I will do my part by continuing to support this and other legislation that assists in protecting our citizens.

name: Glenis Willmott (S&D)
text: in writing. – I co-authored this resolution that calls for the international community to play a greater and more strategic role in combating the Ebola virus outbreak, and encourages the European Commission to continue to increase its financial commitment to humanitarian aid. The response from the EU and Member States has not been swift enough, and there is an urgent need to prevent the spread of the virus. The World Health Organisation has estimated that over 20 000 people could be infected by Ebola within a few months, and shortages of food and water are expected to continue. This resolution therefore calls for the Commission to begin country-by-country assessments of the Ebola risk, and help to coordinate the international response to this crisis. Labour MEPs have voted for this resolution because we believe the international response to Ebola has been inadequate so far, and a coordinated, well-funded, strategic response is overdue.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The help discussed and recommended here has nothing to be altruistic or supportive, but rather to protect the world's major powers against this type of disease.  The hardest hit countries - Sierra Leone, Congo, Liberia, Guinea and Nigeria - are countries that have suffered colonial rule for years, followed after imperialist rule. These are countries where the IMF, with its neoliberal revenues and ruinous loans, has been at the root of the lack of effective conditions to deal with this epidemic. According to the WHO Deputy Director, more health professionals are needed than any other aid, as for every 70-80 patients, about 200 health professionals are needed. While the EU's monetary aid, which has been decreasing since 2011, and the US, which has already announced the deployment of 3,000 military personnel on the ground, will send 65 doctors and 103 nurses to the field. These countries and their infected citizens need doctors, treatment units, hospital beds and medical equipment, not military personnel.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI). -
text: Madam President, I am pleased that we are finally interested in the plight of minorities and, in particular, Christians in the Middle East. But I regret that this interest is so late when the situation has only worsened since the American invasion of Iraq in 2003.  You are referring only to the so-called Islamic State. Islamist militias in Iraq and Syria are, however, just as violent and hateful as each other. How can one claim to fight Da'esh while supporting al-Qaeda's branch in Syria, the Al-Nusra Front. It is totally incoherent on the part of NATO member countries to tolerate Turkey continuing to arm, train, finance the so-called Islamic State and buy the oil it extracts, and finally accept that quests and recruitments are being held in the street. Beyond the usual gesticulations, it is time for European countries to take clear positions to fight all Islamist militias in cooperation with the Syrian and Iraqi governments.

name: Diane Dodds (NI). -
text: Madam President, we are all shocked by the barbaric killings we have witnessed recently in the Middle East and our thoughts and prayers are with the families who have been affected, and with the family of Alan Henning and indeed Alan Henning himself who faces a terrible threat in these days. Not only this but also the killing rampages against Christian communities in Syria and Iraq. It is imperative that the EU makes available effective means to help protect Christian members of minority faiths across the Middle East. It is fitting too that my thoughts should also turn to the recent passing of the Right Honourable Lord Bannside who represented my constituency in this Parliament between 1979 and 2004; he was an immense ambassador of the Christian cause as well as a fervent advocate for Northern Ireland. His work here led to European support for peace funding for my constituency. We in Northern Ireland will never see his like again; I dare say Europe will not either. Our thoughts and prayers are with his wife and family circle.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE). -
text: Madam President, I supported this resolution by signature and vote, because in the last few months we have witnessed serious human rights violations and bloodshed in the Middle East. We know that only in Iraq is the persecution of innocent populations, especially the Christian minority, tremendous and brutal. About 1.2 million people have been displaced and emergency humanitarian aid needs 1.5 million people. Forced convert to Islam or expulsion of those happier who have not been killed is a daily occurrence.  As Iraqi Chadean Patriarch Louis Sako pointed out, such Islam would be elected by all orthodox Muslims. Is there anything else we need to add to this to do everything we can to make sure that this kind of population war casualties stop in Iraq, Syria and the wider Middle East. In the face of this martyrdom, it becomes crystal clear once again that freedom of belief, freedom of thought and conscience is inseligible from man, and any deprivation of that right is a violation of basic human rights. Every regime, every ideology that takes that right away, even by force, is doomed.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE). -
text: Madam President, the situation in Iraq and Syria poses extremely serious geopolitical and security challenges to the region and to the West. Moreover, we have seen one of the worst humanitarian crises, with vulnerable groups such as religious and ethnic minorities, women and children disproportionately affected by the barbaric actions of Islamic State. Swift and coordinated action by the international community is of the utmost importance. It is important for religious leaders in the Middle East to denounce what Islamic State is doing in the strongest possible terms. Furthermore, I want to stress the importance of collaboration and dialogue between all groups in Iraq: I sincerely hope that the new Government led by Mr al-Abadi is a step in the right direction. In the long term, the Iraqi Government should work on reintroducing the concept of inclusive citizenship as the defining principle to accommodate all groups in Iraq and restore trust among them.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE). -
text: The original draft text of the resolution on the situation in Syria and Iraq made almost no mention of Christians, even though it is they who have become the target of violence and persecution by the terrorists of the so-called Islamic State. Finally, two paragraphs on the Christian minority in the region were incorporated into the joint draft text. Congratulations to the negotiators for their efforts and helpfulness. I am glad that this Parliament has finally been able to express solidarity with the members of Christian communities who are persecuted in their home countries and are in danger of disappearing. The Christian people of Iraq are now persecuted because of their religion and beliefs. They were deprived of their fundamental rights and forced to become refugees. I welcome the fact that we have been able to highlight their suffering together. This resolution may be the first step on the road to returning Iraqi Christians back to their homes.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted against this resolution because it is an attempt by the international community to put out fire with more fire, when those same countries are causing that fire in the Middle East. The European Parliament's resolution once again follows the US drums of war and welcomes the US's call for a nuclear war. U.S. in favor of an international coalition against the Islamic State. They now intend to bomb those they have encouraged in Syria, those who were once "rebels friends."  The solution to this fire in the region is not through bombing, but by the convening of an international conference with the participation of all parties that definitively end sectarian and violent policy.

name: Michèle Alliot-Marie (PPE)
text: In writing. - Religious minorities continue to be persecuted in Iraq and Syria, massacred, and driven from their historic place of life. It is our duty to support them and to fight terrorism and ISIL. The European Union must take firm and concrete measures to defend the Christians of the East, and all religious minorities. The European Parliament's resolution is balanced and condemns all human rights violations. It calls on Member States to take responsibility and combat all forms of discrimination.  That is why I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Andrus Ansip (ALDE)
text: Writing. - I supported the resolution on the situation in Iraq and Syria and the ophensiveness of ISIS.  I condemn the violent attacks by ISIS and other Sunni extremist groups in Iraq and Syria.  Mistakes made during the previous Iraqi government, when the representation of many population groups in state governance was not sufficient, created the ground for the emergence of ISIS. I hope that Hayder al-Ibad, appointed Prime Minister of Iraq, will succeed quickly in forming a government that represents democratically the interests of all groups of the country. Close cooperation between moderate political forces against common security threats is important.  It is also very important to respond quickly and decisively to the growing humanitarian crisis. I consider it important to continue to support neighbouring countries in Syria and Iraq, which are working hard to accept refugees.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. - I welcome the adopted resolution on the ISIS offensive because it not only strongly condemns the human rights violations caused by the extremist jihadist group Islamic State (ISIS), formerly Islamic State of Iraq and Syria (ISIS), but also calls for concrete action. These measures include not only the demand for humanitarian aid for the victims and refugees, e.B. safe refugee reception centres, but in particular concrete and decisive action. To this end, increased cooperation between all regional actors and governments to combat terrorist atrocities against Christians in Iraq and Syria is essential. For the most part, the oil fields are in the hands of IS forces and serve as a source of income to finance terrorist acts, which is why there is a specific demand that THE EU states do not participate in these oil deals from Syria and Iraq. Furthermore, those who commit ethnically motivated human rights violations must be prosecuted under international law, regardless of their nationality. The time for expressing regret should be over, now we need to act in concrete terms, because only this is a language that the terrorists understand. Only in this way can the current situation be defused and, in the near future, peace and security for ethnic and religious minorities in Iraq and Syria can be restored.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP usually opposes foreign intervention and still feels that British soldiers should not be deployed to Iraq and Syria at this stage. However ISIS is such a dangerous and vicious entity that we feel we should support moderate countries in the region in their fight against it. We also fear the lack of proper border controls may lead to attacks in Europe.  Amendment 5 Extremist Islam, and the current threat posed by ISIS is a global, is not just a Middle Eastern issue. The international community must therefore work together, under the umbrella of the United Nations to coordinate efforts against ISIS. This should be led by moderate Muslim countries, supported by the West.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. - The barbaric acts, inhumane massacres and human rights abuses perpetrated by the Islamic State, particularly against the civilian population and hostages, can only be condemned in the strongest possible terms. The European Union and its Member States must support international efforts to combat Islamic State terrorism and provide maximum humanitarian support to the civilian populations of Iraq and Syria hit by the abuses.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. The advance of ISIS (often called "Daesh" which means the same thing but testifies to a semantic logic) has already resulted in a large number of abuses and one could even speak of "crimes against humanity" (forced conversions, slavery, trafficking of women, torture, murders ...).  This translates into 1.8 million displaced persons and nearly 190,000 deaths in Syria since the beginning of the conflict, according to the UN.  In these countries, the areas under the control of ISIS, a faction of Al Qaeda, are in increasing concern, subject to a rigorist interpretation of Sharia law and the establishment of a caliphate that violates human rights and persecutes religious minorities, especially Christians. It is necessary to support them in order to enable them to live safely on their land and to guarantee the return of people hunted to their places of origin.  In the face of this situation, I voted in favour of this resolution in order to strongly condemn these abuses, to put an end to the illicit trade of the Islamic State which is financing its advance, to ensure the protection of persecuted populations, to facilitate access to humanitarian aid and to prevent European citizens from leaving the territory of the Union to fight alongside terrorists.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. - (IT) I find the positions supported in the resolution analysing the situation in Iraq, Syria and the ISIS offensive undeasurable and undead, which is why I did not vote in favour of it.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. - A week ago we were remembering the anniversary of the attack on the Twin Towers. In Europe, he was followed by those in Madrid on 11 March 2004 and by London in July 2005. Indonesia, Morocco, Turkey, Egypt, Jordan, Algeria or Yemen were also victims of this terrorist disaster. Jihadist madness has become globalized and now has in Iraq and Syria the most bloody examples of the current situation with the fearsome rise of the Islamic State. Minorities suffer terrible attacks, refugees are numbered by thousands, and the number of innocent victims continues to increase every day. Since the 2001 attack, the situation has far from improved. The decisions made in its day, with the invasion of Iraq, have brought only more instability, more violence and more casualties.  We must deal with this crisis from respect for international law. Fighting the Islamic State is a priority but not forgetting the importance of humanitarian aid and cooperation. The Alliance of Civilizations is now more necessary than ever for the sake of peace and reconciliation. I support this resolution and hope that the EU will have the means to act on its forecasts.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. - Negative vote: a very complex geopolitical situation which, while requiring immediate action to protect Christian minorities, on the other hand would need a long-term plan with the involvement (for example of Russia) of powers that are now excluded from diplomatic tables.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. - I voted in favour of the resolution on the situation in Iraq and Syria. We support the persecuted minorities in the conflict, especially the Christians of Iraq who are victims of religious intolerance. The so-called "Islamic State in Syria and Iraq" has no legitimacy and its actions, including the barbaric murder of journalists, were unanimously condemned as criminal. It should not be allowed to profit from its oil sales on the international market. The international community therefore supports the legitimate Iraqi authorities and supports the protection of civilians by the United Nations. Security measures will be taken to prevent support for the Islamist insurgency by foreign jihadists, including European citizens.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of this resolution to call on the EU to use all possible means to help Iraqi national and local authorities to fight the 'Islamic State', including adequate military assistance. The creation and territorial expansion of the 'Islamic caliphate' and the activities of other extremist groups in Iraq and Syria are a direct threat to the security of European countries. In order to stem the flow of financial and material resources to the 'Islamic State', I call for the ARMS embargo and the freezing of UN assets to be applied more effectively. I also think that the EU should impose sanctions against oil traders extracted in areas controlled by the 'Islamic State' and cut the financial flows that allow the organisation to do business and exploit tax havens.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. - (IT) The humanitarian situation in Iraq and Syria has deteriorated seriously with the occupation of the so-called "Islamic State", it is the result of a perverse calculation of Bashar al-Assad who is trying to become the only interlocutor for the international community, THESIS now asks, in fact, to cancel the Sykes-Picot agreements and the insixed and arbitrary partition of the Treaty of Sèvres that ignored tribal cultures , ethnic identities and theological divisions of Islam. We believe that a war solution to the conflict would be a flight forward to an even bloodier situation. Only the United Nations, even within its limits, has the authority to intervene and create a humanitarian corridor and prevent further massacres. We must have the courage to re-discuss new stable borders in the Middle East, allowing its peoples to determine themselves freely.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. - (IT) The advance of ISIS is deeply worrying, it is a direct threat to the security of the European Union and it must be stopped.   It is sadly known that the region in question is experiencing an unprecedented period of instability and violence, and we have seen with horror the horrific images of the murders of American journalists James Foley and Steven Sotloff and british aid worker David Heines.  I therefore welcome the fact that the EU strongly condemns terrorist acts, indiscriminate killings and human rights violations, including against Christians and other religious and ethnic minorities, committed by ISIS, and calls for urgent action at international level to seek a lasting political solution to this conflict. , and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. - As a result of the occupation of parts of its territory by the jihadist terrorist group Islamic State (IS), the humanitarian and security situation in Iraq and Syria has been deteriorating, with the Islamic State declaring on 24 June 2014 the establishment of a Caliphate or Islamic State in the territories it controls. In areas controlled by The Islamic State or associated groups, serious violations of human rights and international humanitarian law have been committed, including selective executions, abductions, the sale and slavery of women and children, recruitment of children for suicide bombings, physical and sexual abuse and torture, and the beheading of journalists James Foley and Steven Sotloff and aid worker David Haines. The promotion of democracy and respect for human rights are fundamental principles and objectives of the European Union for its relations with third countries. I support this resolution, in which the European Parliament strongly condemns indiscriminate killings and human rights violations, and stresses that in Syria and Iraq only a sustainable peace will be possible with accountability for crimes committed by all parties, and there can be no impunity for the perpetrators of these acts.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of this very important European Parliament resolution on the serious Iraqi and Syrian crisis generated by the serious offensive by IS. The EU once again strongly affirms the supremacy of democracy, human rights and fundamental freedoms, among which, without any doubt, there is the religious freedom that is guaranteed in Europe. The offensive against Christians and ethnic and religious minorities is unacceptable. I am convinced that the Member States, and the entire international community, must make every effort to support the Iraqi authorities in the fight against the caliphate, to protect all civilians, as well as to improve the coordination of the actions put in place to improve its effectiveness. Finally, it is necessary that the Member States do not underestimate the phenomenon of European fighters who decide to join IS and take the most appropriate measures without delay.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution as the EU and its Member States cannot stand still in the face of the persecution and ill-treatment of people on the basis of their religion, ethnicity, gender or any other ground.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. - (IT) Hoping for joint initiatives by the international community on the disarmament of the area in question, I can only vote in favour of this resolution in view of the critical humanitarian and security situation. The approval of this Resolution should facilitate access to humanitarian support and call on all parties to the conflict to ensure the protection of the civilian population and to respect their obligations under international humanitarian and human rights law and to provide humanitarian support and assistance to displaced persons.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted against this resolution because it is an attempt by the international community to put out fire with more fire, when those same countries are the when they are without fire in the Middle East. The European Parliament's resolution once again follows us's bonfire drums and welcomes the US call for an international coalition against the Islamic State. They now intend to bomb those they have encouraged in Syria, those who were once "rebels friends."  The solution to this fire in the region is not through bombing, but by the convening of an international conference with the participation of all parties that definitively end sectarian and violent policy.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. - The fight is not against Islam, but against terrorism. Crucifixions, massacres and persecution of minorities are brutal actions that have nothing to do with religion, nor can they be justified in its name. Action must be taken along three main lines: the blocking of funding that comes into the hands of ISIS members through, for example, the gains of the black market in oil that comes from reserves controlled by ISIS, through the Turkish network, and which also arrives in Europe. Closely monitor, through coordination between The European States, the return of the more than 1000 European citizens who have left to participate in the fight of the cd. "Caliphate." To create cooperation with the countries of the Middle East, the main protagonists of this struggle, which have denounced the actions of the ISIS terrorists, and who deplore the hypothesis that this war can be considered holy and conducted in the name of Allah. Europe must not give up its role of peace and mediation and find the courage to demonstrate concretely its disappointment at simplistic and often misleading and counterproductive solutions and analyses.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. – I am deeply concerned by the rapidly deteriorating security and humanitarian situation in Iraq and Syria resulting from the occupation of parts of their territories by IS, this being a direct threat to the security of the European countries. I strongly condemn the attacks perpetrated by IS against Iraqi and Syrian citizens, the serious violations of international human rights and humanitarian assistance committed in areas under the control of IS and associated groups, including targeted killings, forced conversions, abductions, selling of women, slavery of women and children, recruitment of children for suicide bombings, sexual and physical abuse, and torture. I strongly support that the Commission should engage with partners, including international organisations, to prepare a comprehensive programme to address the need to protect women and children affected by armed conflict. In the long term, I consider that a durable and inclusive political solution involving a peaceful transition to a genuinely representative government in Syria would help to neutralise the threat of IS and other extremist organisations. In this regard, the EU has to facilitate a regional dialogue on the problems facing the Middle East and include all significant parties.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. – I am voting in favour of this resolution as the unprecedented violence deployed by the Islamic State (IS) in Iraq and Syria is extremely worrying. Our group was deeply shocked by the mediatised executions of innocent individuals, be it Syrians and Iraqis in their hometowns or innocent foreigners. We believe the EU and its Member States must do everything necessary to help free all the other prisoners.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I welcome the vote of this resolution on the Islamic State offensive in Syria and Iraq and the persecution of minorities there. With this vote, the European Parliament reaffirms its strongest support for persecuted religious minorities, especially Eastern Christians. It was particularly necessary to recall the right of these Christian communities to continue to live in their lands of origin while being free to practice their religion. These multiple human rights violations against religious minorities, the atrocities such as the murders of journalists James Foley and Steven Sotloff and humanitarian worker David Haines are proof that the European Union must take a very strong stand against the barbaric actions perpetrated by the Islamic State.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. - We are voting against this plan because it welcomes US military intervention to combat ISIS, whereas in the past US representatives have had meetings with officials of that organisation and equipped it to overthrow Syria's legally elected leader. We believe that the U.S. is not the right force to bring peace to this region.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. - The Islamic State Group, against all un rules and laws, has taken possession of various regions of Syria and Iraq, violating the most elementary human rights and declaring the establishment of a caliphate in the territories it controls, not recognizing internationally accepted borders. Selective executions, forced conversions, abductions, the sale and slavery of women and children, physical and sexual abuse and torture; the murder of journalists and humanitarian workers and the destruction of monuments, mosques, shrines and churches must be strongly condemned. These practices have had direct repercussions on populations: 191,000 people lost their lives in Syria, 6.4 million people have moved to other Syrian regions and 3 million have taken refuge in other countries; the number of Christians in Iraq went from 1.2 million to 350,000 and in Syria there were 1.8 million Christians who are now reduced to about 500,000. The continuous attacks on civilian targets and the daily execution of people deserve full condemnation and solidarity with all families victims of this conflict.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We are looking at an attempt to make a clean line of the responsibilities of the US, Britain, France and the EU in the situation in Iraq and Syria. The intention is to take further the destabilization of these countries, maintaining the situation of permanent conflict between peoples, generating chaos to better control their natural resources. Those who warn hypocritically of the dangers of establishing an Islamic Caliphate in Iraq and Syria, considering that this poses a direct threat to the security of European countries, are the same ones who did not long ago advocate dwell (with weapons, training, funding) for these groups when they were fighting the Syrian government. Those who were allies yesterday (ISIS) became enemies, targeted to be deposed, a major threat to EU countries and the US. Calls are called for the formation of an international coalition, the Arab League is being asked to take the field, welcomes the decision of some EU countries to hand over arms to new allies within Iraq, a new aggression is being prepared on countries and peoples (Iraq and Syria) who are victims of a policy of dividing to govern, new arguments are sought to carry out what had not been achieved in Syria , overthrow the government, and to further entice internal divisions in Iraq. We voted against it.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. - I'm voting against it because it strengthens U.S. military intervention to fight ISIS. In the past there have been meetings with ISIS officials and they have been working with weapons to overthrow Syria's legally elected leader. The U.S. is not the right force to eliminate the war in Iraq and Syria.

name: Mariya Gabriel (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because it encourages the containment of the terrorist threat while supporting the action of the Iraqi government and involving regional and national actors. This resolution aims to support the unity and territorial integrity of Iraq, in order to ensure the stability and prosperity of the country and to avoid the fragmentation of the region. In addition, the fundamental human right to freedom of thought, conscience and religion is recalled. It also stresses the importance of sending an urgent fact-finding mission to Iraq to examine allegations of violations and abuses of international human rights law by the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant, with a view to ending impunity and establishing accountability. Finally, the resolution draws attention to the situation of women and the increase in cases of recruitment of children and young people in Iraq and Syria by terrorist groups. It calls on the Commission and Member States to adopt specific measures to prevent exploitation and all forms of abuse and violence against women.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. – In recent times, not a day has passed without hearing about the persecution of Christians, particularly in Iraq and Syria. There is terrible news in the media, which unfortunately often speaks of child sacrifices. We also know that thousands of children and women are currently living overnight in refugee camps, where it is becoming increasingly difficult to survive as the cold approachs. We must therefore do everything we can to protect these Christians from the atrocities that evoked the Dark Ages. Children and women deprived of their human rights must be protected from the horrors of wars and weapons anywhere in the world.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of the resolution on the situation in Iraq and Syria, the attack by the Islamic State on religious minorities, including Christians. I believe that the worst human tragedy of our time is taking place in the region, where an urgent international and European response must be given to a question that threatens millions of people. Addressing the Crisis in Iraq is therefore not a religious or ethnic issue; Europe must save lives! The text underlines that christian and other minorities have an inalienable right to live in their homeland, dignity, equality and security, and to exercise their religion freely.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. - The European Union cannot play a passive role in the face of violence in iraq, Syria and, on the whole, in the Middle East region. The persecution and murder of people because of their belief, thinking or sex cannot leave us impassive. We cannot allow the violation of the most fundamental human rights, such as the right to one's physical integrity. This repeated attack on the fundamental principles contained in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights must rebel against us. Just two years ago, the European Union was recognized as the Nobel Peace Prize, and this must give us the courage to fight for peace both in the countries of our area of influence and in countries where human rights, as well as people's lives, are most threatened by the shadow of permanent violence. For all this, in the vote of the Resolution on the situation in Iraq and Syria I have cast my yes vote.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP usually opposes foreign intervention and still feels that British soldiers should not be deployed to Iraq and Syria at this stage. However ISIS is such a dangerous and vicious entity that we feel we should support moderate countries in the region in their fight against it. We also fear the lack of proper border controls may lead to attacks in Europe.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. - Acts of barbarism, forced conversions, abductions, slavery, sexual abuse and torture constitute crimes perpetrated daily and with impunity by the Islamic State (IS) in Iraq and Syria. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution, which calls on the institutions and governments of the European Union to take imperative measures to help and protect religious and ethnic minorities, including Christians, and to provide humanitarian assistance to civilian victims. In addition, hundreds of European citizens have joined the insurgency's fighters. It is therefore urgent that the European Union and the international community take legal action against anyone suspected of involvement in acts of terrorism.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. - The European Parliament has chosen to respond by expressing its indignation at the suffering of the Iraqi and Syrian peoples, in particular the Christian populations and the Yezidi minority persecuted by isIS jihadists. In the face of barbarism, words are a weak comfort, but indifference would have been the manifestation of cruel casualness.  I share the pain of these displaced populations and those under the yoke of ISIS. Beyond the French military action which responds to a request from the Iraqi President and to which I wish a relay at European level, I am concerned about another phenomenon of magnitude that threatens the security of our territories, the return of jihadi fighters among whom 946 French. The threats posed by these radicalized individuals must be taken into account in defining our border management policies.  While this remains an eminently national issue, the abolition of internal borders and the de facto free movement of these people require enhanced cooperation from European police and judicial authorities. European action in this direction is therefore needed.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. - I voted No because basic human rights in Iraq and Syria are under threat. The unseated war being waged in these areas is a great danger to all ethnic and religious minorities and this is an additional motive for my support for this resolution.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. - I voted in favour of resolving the situation in Iraq and Syria. The text condemns the ongoing violence and persecution, particularly by ISIL terrorists, and calls for the support of the Iraqi government and the protection of civilian populations.  The resolution was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. - As co-signer of this resolution, I wished to stress the plight of Eastern Christians who are victims of the religious and cultural cleansing carried out by the Islamic State. It is our civilizational heritage, our values, our culture that we murder with them. It is a crime against humanity that we are witnessing, a crime against the diversity of the world, a crime against the identity of the Middle East but also of Europe. The EU must commit itself to allow Christians in Iraq and Syria to remain in their homeland or return safely, because condemning them to exile would be tantamount to recognising the end of their civilization. In the face of urgent need, the EU must act to: strengthen its humanitarian aid for persecuted communities; organize a massive military response to annihilate the Islamic State; support political transitions in Iraq and Syria, ensuring that Christians have better institutional representation on the Lebanese model; to stem the jihadist contagion by protecting vulnerable neighbouring countries such as Lebanon but also our own countries which are threatened by the return of European jihadists whose numbers are constantly growing. For these jihadists, we are the target to be slaughtered because, like the Christians of the East, we are the face of otherness. Let's face their relentless barbarity.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution. The crisis in Iraq and Syria caused by the Islamic State is one of the most severe in recent human history and can be called only by its true nature – a targeted genocide and religious cleansing against different minorities, religious and ethnic in Iraq and Syria, with the aim of eliminating everyone not eligible for the IS fighters.  Only joint international efforts can bring relief into this conflict and reduce the level of violence. The EPP Group has called for the establishing of special safe havens for refugees where they can be protected and provided with at least minimum means to live. I call again on the EU and its Member States to assist Iraqi and local authorities by all possible means, including military assistance, to contain and repel the terrorist and aggressive IS expansion. We also need to effectively end the terrorism-tourism where fighters depart from the EU countries to commit crimes against humanity and then return and spread hatred around our communities. The EU cannot feed this violence! It is our moral and human obligation to stop the massacres in Iraq and Syria and prevent them from spreading further in the region.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. – I supported the resolution calling for an international coordination of efforts to counter the menace of ISIS and to protect all civilian victims of the conflict, regardless of their ethnicity and religion. The threat of ISIS remains very serious and substantial. Its murderous onslaught against minorities and sectarian groups, women and children, journalists and aid workers has been deeply disturbing. Muslims everywhere are appalled that these crimes are being carried out in the name of their faith. ISIS’ false ideology and narrative must be therefore confronted and a broad coalition, including Arab countries, put in place to tackle the threat of ISIS.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. - (IT) First of all, I would like to begin my statement by expressing my support for all victims of religious intolerance and hatred. I express my solidarity with the members of christian communities persecuted in Iraq and Syria, and I am voting in favour of this resolution to call on the European Union to commit itself to supporting the Iraqi authorities in order to counter the consequences imposed by the Islamic State. I consider the indiscriminate killings and human rights violations perpetrated by terrorist organisations against ethnic and religious minorities and the most vulnerable populations to be shameful acts.

name: Jean Lambert (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution although I have reservations about the inclusion of the words ‘by all means’ when we are talking about how to combat this terrorist offensive. I do not believe that a large-scale, military intervention is wise or effective, but would not rule out smaller-scale assistance at the request of the Iraqis or others defending their peoples and country. I also believe a UN initiative is needed. However, the tactics of the self-styled IS (a name both condemned by many Moslems and arrogant in its claim) are designed to strike terror into the population and to remove any potential opposition or plurality. The resolution is clear in its abhorrence of IS and clear on the need to provide humanitarian assistance for those in the region and governments, the Kurdish regional authorities and settled populations under pressure due to the displacement of thousands, if not millions. It is clear on the need for the EU to do more in solidarity for refugees and it is clear on the need for an effective, inclusive government in Iraq and a political solution to the situation in Syria, which must include the region as a whole.

name: Gabrielius Landsbergis (PPE)
text: Writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution. Discrimination on any basis is difficult to perceive in the 21st century.  As noted in the document adopted by the EP, iraqi Christians have recently been persecuted for their religion and belief, their fundamental rights are being stripped, forced to leave their homes and become refugees, and the number of Christians in Iraq has decreased dramatically, according to estimates, up to four times. I also welcome the call in the resolution to draw attention to the problems of the situation of women and children in Iraq and Syria, to guarantee their freedom and respect for their fundamental rights. The international community cannot remain indifferent to any human rights violations, wherever they take place– in Syria, Iraq or here, in the EU's eastern neighbourhood.

name: Paloma López (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted against this resolution because it is an attempt by the international community to put out fire with more fire, when those same countries are the cause of that fire in the Middle East. The European Parliament's resolution once again follows the US drums of war and welcomes the US call for an international coalition against the Islamic State. They now intend to bomb those they have encouraged in Syria, those who were once "rebels friends."  The solution to this fire in the region is not through bombing, but by the convening of an international conference with the participation of all parties that definitively end sectarian and violent policy.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. - The situation of instability and conflict in Iraq and Syria, and the increasing deterioration of domestic security in both countries, have been decisive factors for the emergence and expansion of ISIS. This organization that has imposed strongly and by force occupying the territory of these countries is applying indiscriminate violence to civilians, committing massive human rights violations which we must condemn with the utmost firmness from this Parliament. The EU must improve coordination and promote dialogue in the region to curb the threat posed by ISIS and the challenges in the Middle East by promoting democracy, respect for human rights and the rule of law in the region. On Iraq, we must welcome the recent government of al-Abadi and take advantage of this window of opportunity to truly establish a representative and inclusive Executive to serve as an incentive to curb violence in the country. The situation in Syria is different: in the medium/long term, only a political solution agreed with all actors in society, enabling a peaceful transition to a truly pluralistic and representative government, will truly help to neutralize the impact of ISIS on the country.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. - The defence of national minorities is also a key aspect of the party's "Harmony" programme. The EU cannot allow the rights of national minorities to be respected in both Iraq and Syria.

name: Ramona Nicole Mănescu (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution in the light of the following considerations. I believe that the violation of fundamental PRINCIPLES and objectives of the EU, namely the right to freedom of religion and belief, should not be allowed or tolerated. It is necessary to draw attention to the fact that the activities of extremist groups in Iraq and Syria, including the expansion of the "Islamic caliphate" by the jihadist terrorist group Islamic State, IS, pose a direct threat to the security of countries in the region, and there is a real risk of expansion to the West. I welcome the mobilisation of the Emergency Response Coordination Centre and the activation of the EU Civil Protection Mechanism, as well as the EU's humanitarian assistance in Iraq and Syria. I believe it necessary for the EU to prepare a strategic plan for a rapid, sustainable and firm response that takes into account military, social and humanitarian aspects. I support the call on the EU to impose sanctions on all governments, public or private companies and other parties involved in the transport and recovery of oil extracted in IS-controlled areas, together with strict control over financial flows, to halt IS's economic activities and prevent the exploitation of tax havens by this group.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the Motion for a Resolution of the European Parliament on the situation in Iraq and Syria concerning the ISIS offensive in order to condemn loudly what is happening in the Middle East. With this vote, the European Parliament is taking a position of absolute condemnation of the persecution of Christians, civilians, religious ethnic minorities and all those episodes of violence that are afflicting the lives of the local populations. It also does not recognize the self-proclaimed authority of ISIS and rejects its leadership as illegitimate in support of the officially recognized Iraqi authorities. In conclusion, it urges all states to endorse UN Security Council Resolutions 2161 (2014) and 2170 (2014), which condemn any kind of trade, direct or indirect, with IS and associated groups.

name: Michał Marusik (NI)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. - Mr President, I believe that the European Parliament should call on the Commission and the Member States to take concrete action. The appropriate response to events in the Middle East should be, above all, a clear declaration of support (including military support) to the legitimate governments of Syria and Iraq in order to restore stability. This should be ed by concrete material assistance to the victims of persecution. I do not agree with putting a sign of equality between the legitimate Syrian government and the various militias, or even more so in blaming it for the crimes of these militias. Contrary to current political correctness, it must also be made clear that the victims of Middle Eastern persecution are primarily Christians and that the cause of persecution is their faith.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. - (IT) I welcomed the joint resolution on the situation in Iraq and Syria because, first of all, it conveys a message of extreme condemnation of the unacceptable acts of violence perpetrated by IS within the area comprising the two countries.  I believe it is necessary for the European Union, an example of civilisation and social development, not to miss an opportunity to declare itself an enemy of anyone who carries out repressive activities against the weakest. The advance of the terrorist organisation, followed by the deflagration of a real crisis within the area, must be countered, as suggested in the resolution, through a shared commitment, involving all the main players in the international community.  I particularly welcome the document's support for the establishment of an Iraqi government, which is truly representative and inclusive, and which adequately reflects the political, religious and ethnic diversity typical of the country.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution, as a swift and coordinated approach to the jihadists of ISIS must be a priority.
