These self-proclaimed warriors of God steal, expel, murder and rape hundreds of thousands of civilians in the Middle East. However, this motion for a resolution is a mere commitment, as we are looking in vain for concrete measures in this text. In terms of content, I fully agree with the call for compliance with UN Security Council Resolutions 2161 and 2170, since the illegal trade in oil with ISIS, or with oil fields occupied by ISIS, is not only an unprecedented double standard, but primarily finances terror against Christian and Muslim minorities. Furthermore, it is also absolutely true that ISIS terror will spread in Europe as well, as an estimated 2000 to 2500 'Europeans' have voluntarily joined ISIS and travelled to Syria and/or Iraq to take part in the massacres against the civilian population. The enormous potential for danger is the return of these jihadists to Europe. I fear, however, that rehabilitation and reintegration, as far as there has ever been integration, is doomed to failure.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. - This resolution is unconditional support for the coalition formed by the United States, without any mention of the responsibilities of this disaster. Responsibility for the situation is blamed on Syria when ISIL was established in Iraq in 2006 following the North American intervention. There are a few calls to protect the civilian population, but the account is not there. The European Parliament is disgraced by adopting the bellicose leaflets of the US military as a resolution. I'm voting against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. - The humanitarian and security situation in Iraq and Syria is particularly critical, but it has been getting worse as a result of the occupation of parts of its territory by al-Qaeda's dissident jihadist terrorist group, the Islamic State (IS) group. The transnational character of IS and its associated groups poses a threat to the entire region, and it is thus difficult to predict the fate of all those still besieged in areas controlled by IS forces. The various crimes against humanity that IS has perpetrated must be vehemently condemned and the EU and the world must respond swiftly to end these incidents, which have cost many Westerners their lives.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The current situation in Iraq and Syria is alarming. Human rights violations by the Islamic State (IS) terrorist group cannot go unpunished. Any use of Islam for terrorist purposes is intolerable to me. Systematic ethnic cleansing is taking place in this part of the Middle East. The fight against terrorism requires more than ever a firm and coordinated response from the international community. In this regard, I welcome the establishment of an international coalition under the aegis of NATO. But the EU also has a crucial role to play. Violence against religious and ethnic minorities in Iraq and Syria has led to the mass displacement of civilian populations. This exodus is not only generating a strengthened European humanitarian response, particularly with regard to the reception of refugees, but also a security response. Finally, EU Member States must put in place without delay a strategy to deter EU citizens wishing to join the ranks of IS, which takes into account both security imperatives and civil liberties.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. – I support this resolution, which calls on all parties to the conflict in Iraq to ensure the protection of the civilian population and for immediate support and humanitarian assistance for the displaced people in Iraq. This resolution encourages the European Commission to prepare a comprehensive programme in order to address the need to protect children and women affected by armed conflicts. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which strongly condemns the Islamic State offensive in Iraq and Syria and the abominable persecution of minorities. I called for a real mobilization of Europe and the Member States on this issue as early as June when the Islamic State seized Mosul. Through this vote, we condemn the cruel and cowardly executions of journalists, and denounce the caliphate established in the region. I am pleased that the resolution refers to the "Paris Appeal" of Muslim organizations in France who denounce the actions of the Islamic State.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: in writing. – We urgently need to find a way of identifying common denominators to solve the conflict. Regarding the inter-religious dialogue, at the theological level there is little dialogue. But on the other hand at the level of citizens, there is a strong need for it. There the governments of EU Member States should understand the conflict as a global issue in which Europe should take an important share of responsibility, most importantly in the protection of Christian minorities and overall promotion of human dignity. The conflict has a European dimension. Solidarity is needed and we will not be able to ‘do more Europe’ with less overall sense of our own identity. I absolutely support the proposal that we call for a stop to the flow of material and financial resources to Islamic State, and urge the UN to impose an arms embargo and asset freeze with more effective enforcement.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: in writing. – I support the European Parliament's resolution, which unequivocally condemns the barbaric practice of the so-called 'european union'. Islamic State in Iraq and Syria. The actions of this terrorist organisation are contrary to fundamental human values and at the same time pose an immeasurable security risk to the whole of Europe. We cannot take comfort in the fact that the battlefield is far from our countries, because last but not least, there are a large number of fighters with EU citizenship on this battlefield. In this context, I want to underline the need for European governments to respond forcefully to the existence of these Islamic State recruits from among European citizens. I also want to express my support for military assistance to the Government of Iraq and also to the Kurds, who are now a key counterweight to Islamic State terrorists.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's resolution on the persecution of minorities in Syria and Iraq because, in view of the atrocities witnessed by the European Union, we owe it to ourselves to support these populations and condemn their persecutors. Massacres committed by the Islamic State cannot go unpunished. In this sense, I agree with the European Parliament's initiative to denounce this situation. It is thereby vital to encourage any action promoting the stability of the area and the muzzling of terrorists.  It is all the more urgent to act because such a situation promotes the indoctrination of young Europeans to religious hatred and terrorism.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. - The images that have been pouring onto our television screens for several weeks are unbearable.  That is why I voted wholeheartedly in favour of a European position strongly condemning the attacks perpetrated by the Islamic State.  Iraq and Syria are experiencing an unprecedented political and humanitarian crisis: 1.4 million Iraqis and 6.4 million displaced Syrians, a growing number of refugees, populations calling for urgent humanitarian assistance. We must help them break this deadlock and put an end to the actions of extremist organisations reinforced by 10,000 foreigners, including European citizens, including Belgian citizens. How long will we allow these terrorists to violate with impunity the fundamental principles of human rights and humanitarian law: murders, abductions, slavery, sexual and physical assaults, acts of torture...? How many innocent dead, including women and children, will it take?  These Islamists are now acting like barbarians, without faith or law.  The people and governments of Syria and Iraq need the international community to contain and repel, by all means, the offensive expansion of IS.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. - I am deeply shocked by the events that are taking place in Iraq and Syria.  I supported this resolution so that the European Union could step up its work to help national and local authorities in Iraq fight extremists.  It is essential that a solution is found to fight against rebel and jihadist groups and to reach a political solution. Attacks on civilians must stop and perpetrators of barbaric acts must be severely punished.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted against this resolution because it is an attempt by the international community to put out fire with more fire, when those same countries are the when they are without fire in the Middle East. The European Parliament's resolution once again follows us's bonfire drums and welcomes the US call for an international coalition against the Islamic State. They now intend to bomb those they have encouraged in Syria, those who were once "rebels friends."  The solution to this fire in the region is not through bombing, but by the convening of an international conference with the participation of all parties that definitively end sectarian and violent policy.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution on the situation in Iraq and the ISIS offensive including the persecution of minorities.  In the resolution we not only strongly condemn attacks against civilian targets and the use of execution and sexual violence in the conflict but also call for a sustainable political solution involving all the components of Iraqi society and addressing their legitimate grievances.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. - At yesterday's debate on this motion for a resolution, my colleagues and I wore T-shirts with an 'N' sign in Arabic, a symbol used by Islamic State militants to identify who belongs to 'Nazarene', christians. Islamic fundamentalists refer to their homes with it, giving them a choice: either leave their homes within 24 hours or convert to a radical form of Islam, or pay tax on the "right to be a Christian." Refusing means risking "death with a sword." Many ended up being victims of senseless and brutal murder, including old men, women and children. With our slight gesture, we expressed our solidarity not only with all persecuted Christians, but also with all other religious and national minorities in these countries tested. We must take into account the atrocities and murders of hundreds of Jezidis, Shiite soldiers and members of other minorities. I am pleased that the EU, in its resolution today, which I unequivocally supported, has been very clear in favour of the rights of all these persecuted people, highlighting the need to protect civilians, the need for immediate and effective assistance to refugees, and at the same time calling for ways to dialogue with each other. At the same time, it stressed the obligation to hold to account and to bring before the International Criminal Court all those suspected of committing these horrific crimes against humanity, so that the perpetrators do not go unpunished.

name: Barbara Spinelli (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The conflicts and chaos that reign in Syria, Iraq and Libya have not fallen from the sky: in Iraq as in Libya, we are witnessing the consequences of wars that have literally led to failed states, despite the misleading initial intentions.  I want to fight for a European policy that becomes autonomous of the United States: that takes care of its own interests and questions the choices of the last thirteen years.  Migratory flows and mass leaks of peoples are an emergency for which we are partly responsible and which we must therefore tackle together as a Union, and I therefore regret the total absence of proposals for aid from the Union or the States in the resolution. Politics cannot be summed up in calling on the international community to provide military protection and assisting the Iraqi and local authorities with military aid and at the same time promoting a Fortress Europe manned by border control and patrol agencies such as Frontex.  For these reasons, I voted against this resolution.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. - The current situation in Iraq and Syria is a serious case of undermining basic human rights and numerous human lives, as well as the territorial integrity of these countries.  I strongly condemn acts of terrorism by ISIS and other militant groups against the Iraqi and Syrian populations, in particular the persecution of religious minorities. Such radical ideology has particularly affected religious minorities, especially Christians there, but also moderate Muslims, as well as other minority groups such as the Jazida. All of them are threatened with total persecution or extermination.  I am in favour of a coalition of countries united in the fight against ISIS, for decisive action to protect human rights, to prevent persecution and killing of populations, and I call on the international community to monitor the activities of these residents in case of their return from the point of view of the security of European countries. In my view, the fight against terrorism requires decisive joint action by international and regional organisations to successfully prevent, disable and stop terrorism.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. - We are voting against this plan because it welcomes US military intervention to fight ISIS, whereas in the past representatives of that country have had formal meetings with officials of that organisation equipping it with the aim of overthrowing Syria's legally elected leader. We believe that the United States is not the right force to enforce peace in this region.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted for this text, which was thought by our colleague Mr Bostinaru. The extreme and unprecedented violence deployed in Iraq and Syria by the Islamic State (IS) is extremely worrying. The executions of James Foley and Steven Sotloff have deeply shocked our Group. We believe that the EU and its Member States must do whatever is necessary to contribute to the release of all other prisoners. In addition, we are also concerned about the large number of European jihadists involved. EU countries must find a common solution to bring them to justice. In the meantime, it is important to remember that IS is a minority group of fundamentalists. Muslim and Arab countries are our allies in the fight against these extremists.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted against this resolution because it is an attempt by the international community to put out fire with more fire, when those same countries are the when they are without fire in the Middle East. The European Parliament's resolution once again follows us's bonfire drums and welcomes the US call for an international coalition against the Islamic State. They now intend to bomb those they have encouraged in Syria, those who were once "rebels friends."  The solution to this fire in the region is not through bombing, but by the convening of an international conference with the participation of all parties that definitively end sectarian and violent policy.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. – I supported today’s resolution that strongly condemns the Islamic State. The indiscriminate killings, forced conversions, abductions and other grievous actions undertaken by the Islamic State represent a considerable threat to the stability and security not only of the Middle East but of the wider region.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. - I voted against this resolution on the current situation in Iraq and Syria, which, as too often, ignores the causes of the problem and proposes simplistic and war-going solutions.  Let us begin by recalling that those who call themselves Islamic "State", now the richest terrorist group in the world, would not have been able to prosper without the financial support of wealthy private donors from the Gulf countries whose governments were turning a blind eye - which this resolution is careful not to emphasize. In addition, the resolution "welcomes the US call for an international coalition against IS" and "calls on all EU member states to assist the Iraqi authorities [...] including military assistance."  This persistence in not taking stock of all military interventions with the United States at its head, not to see that there are multiple hotbeds of crisis, can only contribute to the chaos that reigns in the region.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - According to this resolution, it is clear that the attempt is to make a clear plank of the responsibilities of the US, Britain, France and the EU in the current situation in Iraq and Syria. It is clear the goal of taking even further the destabilization of these countries, generating chaos to better control their natural resources.  This resolution calls for the formation of an international coalition, calls on the Arab League to take the field, welcomes the decision of some EU countries to hand over arms to new allies within Iraq and prepares a new aggression against countries and peoples (Iraq and Syria) who are victims of a policy of dividing to govern. Finally, it seeks new arguments to carry out what had not been achieved in Syria - to overthrow the government - and to further aquefy internal divisions in Iraq.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. - I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution, as a swift and coordinated approach to the jihadists of ISIS must be a priority. These self-proclaimed warriors of God steal, expel, murder and rape hundreds of thousands of civilians in the Middle East. However, this motion for a resolution is a mere commitment, as we are looking in vain for concrete measures in this text. In terms of content, I fully agree with the call for compliance with UN Security Council Resolutions 2161 and 2170, since the illegal trade in oil with ISIS, or with oil fields occupied by ISIS, is not only an unprecedented double standard, but primarily finances terror against Christian and Muslim minorities. Furthermore, it is also absolutely true that ISIS terror will spread in Europe as well, as an estimated 2000 to 2500 'Europeans' have voluntarily joined ISIS and travelled to Syria and/or Iraq to take part in the massacres against the civilian population. The enormous potential for danger is the return of these jihadists to Europe. I fear, however, that rehabilitation and reintegration, as far as there has ever been integration, is doomed to failure.

name: Jarosław Leszek Wałęsa (PPE)
text: in writing. – I have lent my support to the resolution on the Situation in Iraq and Syria and the ISIS offensive including the persecution of minorities (Motions for resolutions [2014/2843(RSP)] RC-B8-0109/2014, B8-0109/2014, B8-0110/2014, B8-0121/2014, B8-0130/2014, B8-0134/2014, B8-0137/2014 and B8-0138/2014). I firmly believe that we must stand with our allies in an effort to minimise and/or stop terrorist groups from expanding and killing innocent people. This also extends to cover the violation of rights of minorities and their ability to prosper. It is quite evident that we live in a time where safety is not always assured, but we must take the appropriate action to protect ourselves and our loved ones. The continued violation and persecution of minority groups has grown vastly over the past decade and it is clearly a time to put an end to the chaos,

name: Glenis Willmott (S&D)
text: in writing. – This resolution calls for all parties to the conflicts in Iraq and Syria to ensure the protection of the civilian population, and to remember their obligations under international humanitarian law. The resolution also calls for the international community to assist the Iraqi authorities in protecting vulnerable minority groups, and particularly women, in the areas threatened by ISIL. The resolution also reiterates concern about the number of foreign fighters, including citizens of EU Member States, who have joined the ISIL insurgency. Labour MEPs voted for this motion, which was also co-authored by my colleague Richard Howitt, because we believe that the actions of ISIL threaten to destabilise the region, and that the protection of innocent civilians and vulnerable or minority groups is absolutely essential.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. - I supported the resolution criticising the persecution of minorities in Iraq and Syria. These are countries where Christians have been persecuted for a long time, but this year the situation has deteriorated dramatically. As a newly elected Member, I appreciate all the activities of the European Parliament, which adopts resolutions on the protection of religious minorities, provides material assistance or invites representatives of all religions to Strasbourg or Brussels. Agility is supposed to be a signal not only to the governments of the incriminating states, but also to European diplomacy, which has not yet acted decisively enough. I believe that the new Commission will be more effective in tackling religious freedom.  However, we should be aware that the recent expulsion of Chaldean Catholics from their native Mosul, where they have lived for almost 2000 years, does not just speak of religious freedom in the region. These refugees have been taken from basic human rights, the universal rights of all human beings. I am therefore surprised by the attitude of some Member States that refuse to make an official position on the situation. Unequivocal condemnation of genocide, financial assistance to refugee camps or the granting of asylum is the minimum we can do at the moment.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Reading this resolution, it is clear that what is on the move is the attempt to make a clear plank of the responsibilities of the US, Britain, France and the EU in the current situation in Iraq and Syria, with the aim of further destabilising these countries, generating chaos to better control their natural resources. Those who warn hypocritically of the dangers of establishing an Islamic Caliphate in Iraq and Syria are the same ones who have not long advocated selflessly supporting (with weapons, training, funding) for these groups when they were fighting the Syrian government. Those who were allies yesterday (ISIS) became (in appearance) enemies, a major threat to EU countries and the US. This resolution calls for the formation of an international coalition, the Arab League is being asked to take the field, the decision of some EU countries to surrender arms to new allies within Iraq is being welcomed, a new aggression is being prepared against countries and peoples (Iraq and Syria) who are victims of a policy of dividing to rule, new arguments are being sought to carry out what had not been achieved in Syria - to overthrow the government - and to further cask internal divisions in Iraq.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (NI). -
text: Madam President, I myself voted for this resolution because it takes into account the impact on the catastrophic situation in Libya and also highlights problems that we are experiencing but which had to be said, namely the movement of arms, the presence of terrorist groups and the massive arrival of migrants on Italian shores.  However, we would have liked to have been highlighted the role of France, my country, and NATO, which plunged Libya into this hell, and that it is also stressed that Libya is above all the victim of this risky diplomacy - we cannot say more - of Europe and the West and that, in the current situation, there is no lasting solution.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted against it since it was obvious that it was the military intervention in Libya in 2011 headed by France, the United Kingdom, the United States and Canada under NATO umbrellas that has led Libya to the current failed state situation. It was the military intervervention that led to the deaths of innocent civilians and severe destruction, which have led to the destabilization of the Libyan state and the ongoing civil war. These countries took responsibility for protecting but it was actually a responsibility to protect oil. We are defending a solution in which it is the neighbouring countries, the Arab League and the African Union that promote a process for the immediate end of hostilities and dialogue between the conflicting militias, an initiative promoted by Algeria, and we reject further NATO intervention.

name: Andrus Ansip (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I supported the resolution on the situation in Libya. Libya is at the moment a so called ʽfailed stateʼ and this is a considerable problem for the EU: from uncontrolled immigration to military actions and a favourable ground for all kinds of radicalism. Therefore it is important that at this moment we concentrate our attention on the creation of stable and suitable intra-state actors with whom it is possible to communicate and to plan assistance to bring this country back to a controlled state.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. - Libya is now in chaos and the first victims are civilians. No effort should be spared by the international community to stop the cycle of violence and achieve a ceasefire between the various belligerents. Libya must rebuild itself on the basis of a rule of law, respecting democratic values and human rights. Violated human rights and international humanitarian law must be brought to justice.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. The situation in Libya since the "Arab Spring" and the fall of dictator Gaddafi remains very degraded. Benghazi is hit almost daily by deadly clashes and many Libyans and foreigners leave the country (150,000 between mid-May and the end of August according to the UN).  Moreover, the democratic situation in the country is catastrophic. Parliament, which was the result of the elections last June and was recognized by the international community, is currently withdrawn to Tobruk for security reasons. On the other hand, in Tripoli, the General National Congress (GNC) considers that the current government is not legitimate and Libya is therefore likely to end up with 2 parliaments and 2 governments.  Libya's return to stability will also prevent the mass arrival of asylum seekers and immigrants on the Maltese and Italian coasts.  The priority therefore remains the restoration of the political and military situation and it is essential that the EU supports the mediation efforts currently being carried out on the ground by the United Nations. For these reasons, I have spoken in favour of this resolution.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. - (IT) Although I agree with many of the passages contained in this resolution, I believe that Libya is going through an extremely complex and not at all stabilized socio-political phase, for these reasons I believe that a more wait-and-see position with a view to concrete results in the country is more desirable, I have therefore expressed my abstention.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. - Abstention: although the text had interesting ideas, it was not convincing. The so-called Arab Spring has brought out predictable tensions and conflicts which are now difficult to resolve.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. - I voted in favour of the resolution on the situation in Libya. The violence caused by the conflict has forced thousands of refugees to flee the country, causing a catastrophic and difficult-to-manage humanitarian situation, particularly with the massive influx of migrants and refugees into Italy and Malta. This motion recognizes the House of Representatives elected in June 2014 as the legitimate representative of the Libyan people in its political transition since the Gaddafi regime. The European Union wants to encourage stability and democracy, so that Libyan citizens can live safely in respect of international law and human rights. The proliferation of weapons in the country is a threat to the stability of the region and to international security, as well as the presence of al-Qaeda-linked terrorist groups that must be combated.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of this resolution in order to condemn the violence in the country, particularly in the vicinity of the cities of Tripoli and Benghazi, due to the continuing fighting between the armed groups and their incitement to violence.  I call on the Commission and the European External Action Service (EEAS) to coordinate Member States' actions in Libya and to focus their assistance on consolidating the state and institutions and, together with Member States, the United Nations, NATO and regional partners, to assist the creation of effective security forces (armed forces and police forces), under national command and control , able to guarantee peace and order in the country. Finally, I call on the interim Libyan Government and the elected House of Representatives to address all parties, with a view to reaching an inclusive agreement and avoiding decisions that could exacerbate divisions instead of building bridges.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. - We often believe we're making up for our mistakes by repeating them. Operation Odissey Dawn demonstrated the failure of the strategy of some states that claimed to cultivate democracy in the country simply by shooting down Gaddafi with massive bombing.  A rule of law cannot spontaneously mature from chaos: 140 tribes and clans that have always been rivals to each other, 42 years of dictatorship, two parliaments, two governments, territorial militias of various natures ... and the first victims are Libyan citizens. The rest of the bill is paid by Europeans bordering the Mediterranean: 140,000 desperate migrants this year alone, including 118,000 in Italy alone, 2,500 dead since the beginning of 2014, 2,200 since June. The EU continues to prevaricate. Europe must truly be united not only in diversity, but above all in these adversities. Let us prove it with concrete facts!

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. - The deterioration of the Libyan situation poses pressing humanitarian and security problems both on Libyan territory and for neighbouring countries and the whole of Europe. The resolution recalls the "unprecedented number" of asylum seeker migrants who, starting from Libya, arrive on Italian or Maltese coasts or die in the Mediterranean. And it is clear in this regard that political instability has contributed to increasing the flight of Libyan citizens, especially to Malta and Italy; the latter on the front line of managing continuous migratory flows and saving refugees at sea. The resolution's appeal to the Union and its Member States to support Italy in the migration emergency demonstrates the awareness of the enormous effort supported by my country. The very high number of refugees is not the only problem that the Union and the States have a responsibility to address, since it is essential that they take on the serious political, institutional and humanitarian crisis (with disturbing scenarios, increasing violence, massive violations of rights and war crimes) as a whole. The resolution moves in the right direction through the call for the European Commission and other international bodies to support the creation of effective security forces and, among other things, to accompany the country in the reform of the judicial system. For these reasons, I voted in favour of

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. - (IT) The situation in Libya is alarming: on Europe's doorstep there is a complex and unpredictable scenario that cannot be underestimated, especially in terms of the terrorist threat. Furthermore, this situation has dramatic consequences for the European Union, including the immigration emergency. The latter particularly affects our country and my concern about it is deep.  As expressed in the resolution, the European Union and its Member States must support Libya on the one hand in resolving the root of the problem, promoting an end to hostilities and the restoration of human rights violated for the well-being of the Libyan people, and, on the other hand, helping and supporting our country in dealing with migratory flows from Libya, and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. - Libya faces an escalation of fighting between armed groups, including attacks on civilians and private property, involving gross violation of human rights and humanitarian law, including arbitrary detentions, abductions, extrajudicial executions, torture and violence against journalists, officials, politicians and human rights defenders. Recent fighting has led to a widespread deterioration in living conditions in Libya, with thousands of migrants and refugees fleeing violence in Libya killed as they seek to cross the Mediterranean to Europe, causing a serious refugee crisis in Italy and Malta. I support this EP resolution condemning the escalation of violence, in particular that directed against the population and civil institutions, and calls on all parties to the conflict to immediately put an end to all acts of violence and to reach a ceasefire agreement, enabling the creation of a State based on respect for human rights , democracy and the rule of law. On the other hand, it is advocated that those responsible for violations of human rights and international humanitarian law be properly prosecuted.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of this very important European Parliament resolution on the situation in Libya.  The EU once again strongly affirms the supremacy of democracy, human rights and fundamental freedoms. The growing violence must be strongly condemned. In addition, an effective EU response is needed for the constant and continuous arrival on the Italian and Maltese coasts of asylum seekers and irregular migrants. We can no longer stand by and wait for a firm decision to be made. European policy in this field absolutely must provide decisive answers, and it must also stimulate solidarity between the Member States, which is a key principle of the process of European integration. Finally, we applaud the women in Libya who have played and play a key role in the transition and can still make a valuable contribution to the decision-making process.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. – The EU has an important role to play in assisting the Libyan people to follow a process of democratisation. It is of great concern to know that human rights are being violated in a gross manner and it would be crass not to act. This resolution signifies Parliamentʼs concern regarding the worrying situation in Libya. Instability in Libya also hampers border security and continues to slow down much needed cooperation between the EU, its Member States and Libya to tackle migration.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. - In order to condemn the increasing violence, in particular against the civilian population and civil institutions, to call on all warring parties to cease all violence immediately and to reach agreement on a ceasefire in such a way as to put an end to the growing suffering of the population. I hope that this resolution will be able to initiate an inclusive national political dialogue with a view to creating a state based on respect for human rights, democracy and legality. I fully supported this resolution, so that those responsible for violations of human rights and international humanitarian law are also held to account.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted against it since it was obvious that it was the military intervention in Libya in 2011 headed by France, the United Kingdom, the United States and Canada under NATO umbrellas that has led Libya to the current failed state situation. It was the military intervervention that led to the deaths of innocent civilians and severe destruction, which have led to the destabilization of the Libyan state and the ongoing civil war. These countries took responsibility for protecting but it was actually a responsibility to protect oil. We are defending a solution in which it is the neighbouring countries, the Arab League and the African Union that promote a process for the immediate end of hostilities and dialogue between the conflicting militias, an initiative promoted by Algeria, and we reject further NATO intervention.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. - (IT) Once again we are witnessing a brutal military escalation which, on the one hand, continues to make us feel, as European citizens, absolutely powerless and inept and, on the other, shows us the atrocities of its consequences which invariably end up directly involving our coasts and our countries. It is not acceptable to continue to cry out anger and sorrow at the human tragedies that are repeated in our seas every day, and to do absolutely nothing concrete to put an end to them. It is not enough to prepare everything in our power to do - and I say this as an Italian citizen - to give a dignified welcome to those fleeing situations that are absolutely unimaginable to us. It is not enough, but we must continue to do so, giving as Europeans all the necessary support to those states that are at the forefront of reception more than others. However, Europe's task must be to go to the source, to go and undermine at source the trafficking and activities, mostly criminal, that foment these barbarism. Maximum control over the channels (oil, weapons, drugs) that allow the financing of associations that oppose legitimate authorities, questioning their law and undermining the processes of democratisation.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution as I agree that the instability in Libya is conducive to a scenario where more criminal gangs can engage in human trafficking. The present inability of the Libyan authorities to uphold the rule of law means that there is less control over these criminal organisations, which can therefore extend their operations. The violence may also result in more Libyans wanting to flee their country. These are to be added to the tens of thousands of other migrants from the region who are already in Libya trying to earn some money to make the crossing. The result of this situation is hundreds of deaths in the Mediterranean and harsh pressure on countries like Malta and Italy. I believe that the EU should not accept this criminality and should work with the United Nations in order to end this conflict.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. In Libya, the security, political and humanitarian situation has deteriorated very seriously. That is why I supported the European Parliament's call for all stakeholders to end violence, engage in a national dialogue in order to build a democratic state based on respect for human rights and the rule of law. With this vote, I also wanted to draw attention to the double threat posed by the Libyan crisis on our continent: on the one hand, the increase in migratory pressure at the Union's external borders, and on the other the presence of terrorist groups linked to Al-Qaeda on its territory.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. - We are voting against this project on the ground that it is against FRONTEX and is calling for its abolition. At the same time, it calls for the financing of migrants from Libya with EU funds.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. - Clashes in Libya have intensified in recent months, destabilising the country and its democratic transition, leading to an increase in the number of civilian, internally displaced persons and refugees: 100 000 Libyans have left their homes and 150,000 have left the country. There are daily human rights violations, with dozens of civilians being abducted solely on the basis of their tribe, family or religion; arbitrary arrests, abductions, extrajudicial executions, torture and violence against journalists, officials, politicians and human rights defenders. It is therefore important that the European Union's contribution is not only focused on border security, because it is not in line with the needs of the country or with the challenges it has to face. I would remind you that more than 1,600 people have died trying to reach Europe through Italy and Malta, most of them Libyans. Of the 109 000 people who arrived in Italy, 98 000 were from Libya, a situation deeply worrying and should lead the European Union to follow up on the priorities identified in the Mediterranean Task Group.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Time has given reason to the warnings and denunciations we have made in due course about the aggression to Libya.  NATO, the US and the EU have promoted interference and war in Libya. The majority of this Parliament was not concerned, then, about the consequences of this option. When they instigated the internal conflict to try to justify the violation of their sovereignty and independence by attacking the country in tow the imposition of a hypocritical no-fly zone – to which, it is good to remind you, of the Portuguese parties represented in the European Parliament only the CFP opposed, along with many other forces represented in the GUE/NGL – they did so, they said, to defend freedom, democracy, human rights. How cynicism, how much hypocrisy. It's pretty good in sight of the result. On its horizon was one of the largest oil reserves in the world, the largest in Africa. To achieve their goals, they set up, financed, opened the country's doors to the entrance of mercenaries and groups such as al-Qaeda, to stir divisions between clans and tribes that lived in peaceful coexistence. They are the same who are now alarmed by the insecurity and instability created. The answer: more of the same, with the interference of the European External Action Service, a broader CSDP mission and the militarisation of the EU's presence in Libya.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. - I am voting against asking for the funding of Libyan migrants with EU funds.

name: Mariya Gabriel (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because it first of all recalls the essential principles which must guide the search for a solution and the action of the Union: respect for the rule of law, democracy and legitimate institutions, including the House of Representatives. The aid of the Union and the international community must be directed towards strengthening the state and its sovereignty over the whole territory, including border control. Secondly, the resolution rightly welcomes Egypt's efforts and the importance of a regional dialogue, including with the Arab League, for a lasting solution to the Libyan crisis. We also insist on better coordination among the various special envoys of international organisations and, in this sense, the appointment of the EU Special Representative for the Southern Mediterranean region as the new Special Representative of the UN Secretary-General in Libya can be useful. Finally, Parliament calls here to anticipate and manage the migration implications of this crisis: the EU and all its Member States must respond in a coordinated way to the influx of refugees.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: In writing. I welcome the adoption on 18 September 2014 of the resolution on the situation in Libya. The return to lasting security and political stability inevitably requires the establishment of an inclusive national dialogue between the Libyan parties and the restoration of the credibility of the political process. It is with this in mind that we call on all national actors to recognise the legitimacy of the only Parliament that resulted from the elections of 25 June. We thereby call on the Commission and the EEAS to concentrate their support on strengthening the state and institutions. Mediation efforts by neighbouring countries or the United Nations and their new Special Representative should also be encouraged. Parliament is also concerned about the impact of the deteriorating governance in Libya on regional and European security. In the chaos that continues to kill hundreds and displaced people every day, a significant number of migrants fall prey to smugglers and traffickers, with the tragic end that we unfortunately too often experience. It is time for the European Union to develop a genuine migration policy, notably by strengthening synergies between the EU's internal and external policies.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. - I voted for the resolution because there is complete chaos in Libya and with this resolution the European Parliament has taken clear positions on the situation in Libya and called for their resolution.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. - I voted in favour of the resolution on Libya which supports the Libyan central government and calls for an end to violence between the different factions and the protection of the civilian population. I welcome the adoption of this resolution.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. - I am a co-signer of this resolution justified by the sharp deterioration of the security, political and humanitarian situation in Libya in recent weeks. Every day, Libya descends into chaos a little more because of the clash between rival militias, some linked to extremely dangerous Islamist armed groups. At the political level, it is essential to avoid the emergence of two competing parliaments because of the non-recognition of the Tobruk Parliament by the General National Congress. The EU must therefore support UN initiatives to foster constructive dialogue between the various parties and support the strengthening of the Libyan state as part of the post-Gaddafi democratic transition process. It must also contribute to the reform of the security sector in Libya to combat terrorism and take the necessary measures on the migration issue in cooperation with Libya and the actors in the region. As desired at the Cairo Conference on 25 August 2014, it is essential to involve neighbouring countries to ensure stability in Libya.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. – I supported the resolution, as I am very concerned about the humanitarian crisis in Libya and extremist groups gaining a territorial foothold. The situation needs to be urgently addressed and the arms embargo to the country enforced. The EU must co-operate to support Libya in securing a ceasefire between the warring parties and putting the country on the path to peace. A partnership with regional players should be also actively promoted to help bring governance and help rid Libya of violence, terrorism and crime.

name: Gabrielius Landsbergis (PPE)
text: Writing. - Today's situation in Libya is extremely unstable. Since 2011, when Libyan citizens took to the streets, the country's economic, political, social situation has been difficult to date by kidnapping foreign nationals, human rights defenders and journalists. The system of electricity, water, fuel, food supply, and the elections that islamists do not recognise as an elected parliament, has formed their own government and parliament.  Particular concern is the activities of terrorist organisations, arms smuggling, which causes instability not only in the country but also in the region. The European Union, like no other, feels the consequences of this war: refugees fleeing in extremely poor, inhumane conditions are landing off the coasts of Malta or Italy. As European citizens, we must support and assist regions suffering from aggression and hostilities, realising that Europe does not end up on the borders of the continent and that the EU is at the borders of the Member States.

name: Paloma López (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted against it since it was obvious that it was the military intervention in Libya in 2011 headed by France, the United Kingdom, the United States and Canada under NATO umbrellas that has led Libya to the current failed state situation. It was the military intervervention that led to the deaths of innocent civilians and severe destruction, which have led to the destabilization of the Libyan state and the ongoing civil war. These countries took responsibility for protecting but it was actually a responsibility to protect oil. We are defending a solution in which it is the neighbouring countries, the Arab League and the African Union that promote a process for the immediate end of hostilities and dialogue between the conflicting militias, an initiative promoted by Algeria, and we reject further NATO intervention.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. - I announce my vote in favour of the motion for a Resolution on the situation in Libya because of the need to raise its voice and call for measures to address the extreme instability in libya. After last June's elections, Libya now has two parliaments and two governments that are contesting the power of this stateless country that has lived in economic and social chaos for more than three years. Local armed groups have increased their violence, especially in Tripoli and Benghazi, killing thousands of civilians. Add to this a dramatic humanitarian situation, with thousands of displaced persons and refugees leaving Libya to reach the shores of Malta or Italy risking their lives and causing numerous human tragedies over the shipwrecks of their boats. I therefore support the motion for a Resolution to call for a ceasefire between the parties, a greater dialogue that leads to a political solution to give full legitimacy to the new democratically elected Government, to prevent further humanitarian tragedies in the Mediterranean and to end impunity for those who have violated and continue to attack human rights in Libya.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. - Unfortunately, this country is still very far from genuine democracy and a harmonized civil society.

name: Ramona Nicole Mănescu (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution. I believe that it is necessary to ask all parties to the conflict to make every effort to put an end to the fire, to put an end to the suffering of the population and to allow society to evolve. The EU needs to give priority to supporting reform in the Libyan legal system, as well as other areas essential for the existence and development of a democratic state. The proliferation of weapons and ammunition, explosives and arms trafficking in Libya poses a risk to stability in the country and its population. I welcome the EU's strong support and commitment to the democratic aspirations of the Libyan people, especially in the context of the current crisis, and I support the EU's call for more active involvement in supporting Libya's democratic stability and transition.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. - (IT) The decision to vote in favour of the motion for a resolution on the situation in Libya stems, first of all, from the awareness that the desire for greater stability within Europe's borders cannot ignore a careful interest in the political and social situation within neighbouring countries. The integrity of our Member States is often compromised as a result of the turmoil within neighbouring regions.  That is why I think it is right that, as called for in the text, the EU should participate even more in the stabilisation process in Libya, which is essentially linked to a path of democratic transition.  In particular, I agree with the call for a national political dialogue aimed at creating a Libyan state based on respect for human rights, democracy and legality.  I also welcome the call, towards the EU, and its Member States, to give concrete support to Italy in its management of migratory flows from North Africa and, in particular, from Libya.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. - Libya is engaged in fighting between militias. Many civilians suffer abuses simply because of their tribal affiliation or for religious reasons. But as is often the case, this text does not seek to establish any responsibility in the manufacture of this chaos.  What about NATO's intervention that overstepped the UN mandate (to protect people) by bringing down the regime, moreover without having any strategy for the future?  As for the proposals, they boil down to condemnations, vows and formulas full of good feelings, without any kind of concrete solution. The text calls on the parliament elected in June to assume its role, in particular to endow the country with a constitution, without specifying that this parliament, which had long since exerted any influence on the country, recently took refuge on a ferry in the harbour of Tobruk... In these circumstances, the mere mention of NATO as a "partner" to help Libyan leaders build state security forces capable of restoring security leads me to vote against this text, whose drafters are pitiful copyists of North American propaganda.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. - Since the fall of the Gaddafi regime, Libya has no longer found stability. Libya faces an escalation of fighting between armed groups, including attacks on civilians and private property, involving massive human rights violations.  I have to condemn the escalation of violence, in particular that directed against the population and civil institutions, the parties to the conflict must immediately put an end to all acts of violence and agree on a ceasefire in order to halt the escalation of suffering of the population and initiate an inclusive national political dialogue, to create a State based on respect for human rights , democracy and the rule of law. It is in order to achieve this objective that the EU must make every effort.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I condemn in the strongest terms the escalation of violence in Libya and call on all parties to come to the table to conclude a ceasefire. Political divisions remain deep, the sense of mistrust is palpable, and given the proliferation of weapons outside the effective control of the authorities, the security situation remains extremely fragile. I support the work of the United Nations (UNMIL) through its support mission in Libya, in order to promote Libyan national political dialogue. The Commission and the EEAS should ensure that member states are coordinated to act in parallel with the UN and NATO. The priority is the creation of effective security forces and a reform of the judicial system. Finally, there is an urgent need for the EU to provide a coordinated response to the growing migratory pressure from the countries of the South, particularly Libya. The aim is to put in place a genuine common European immigration policy which would also be a response to what some call the 'globalisation of indifference'.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution, which calls on all Libyan parties to agree to an immediate ceasefire ending the fighting, and to engage in an inclusive political dialogue. This resolution is deeply concerned by the unprecedented arrival of asylum seekers and irregular migrants to Italian and Maltese shores and calls on the EU to follow up the priorities identified in the Mediterranean Task Force and launch a political dialogue on migration issues with the Libyan Government.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution which condemns the increase in violence against civilians and legitimate institutions in Libya. Through this vote, the European Parliament calls for the restoration of the rule of law in the country and the presentation to the competent courts of all persons guilty of crimes and war crimes. The current situation in Libya has a significant impact on Europe and particularly on migratory pressure. Europe and the Member States must play an important role in restoring peace to ensure security in the country and to stop migration at our borders as soon as possible.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The resolution on the situation in Libya is biased on a crucial point: it makes no mention of the interventions of NATO and the EU countries which have undoubtedly led to the current destabilization of the country and its fracturing along ethnic lines. Although the resolution presents an important point on irregular immigration and asylum seekers, which is of course a point on which the EU must play a key role, the resolution seems to me to obscure Europe's responsibility in the country's situation, and does not deal with the root of the problem with sufficient force. I therefore voted against this text.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. - As co-signatories of the resolution on behalf of the EPP Group, I supported the European Parliament's resolution on the situation in Libya, as it calls on the parties in Libya to reach an agreement on an immediate ceasefire, a cessation of fighting and inclusion in a comprehensive national dialogue. The current situation not only threatens Libya, but also poses a threat to neighbours and European countries due to migrants, weapons and ammunition coming into the hands of terrorists. Political dialogue needs to be initiated and activities that could sharpen existing divisions and undermine the democratic transition should not be undertaken. I would like to stress the commitment expressed by the EU towards libya's transition and the importance of continuing the EU's participation in building a democratic Libya.  I also welcome the efforts of the United Nations Support Mission in Libya (UNSMIL) and hope that this mission will contribute to the development of a national dialogue. In addition to these efforts, I welcome the extension of existing international sanctions on Libya through UN Security Council Resolution 2174.  In order to ensure the security of the region, the engagement of all actors is important in order to stabilise the Libyan government and institutions and introduce the rule of law. As there are an increasing number of civilian casualties and human rights violations, I hereby call on the Libyan parties to cease fire and engage in the entire national dialogue in order to avoid additional casualties and achieve peace.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's resolution on the worsening situation in Libya. It is the forth as far as the European Parliament points to the atrocities taking place there in order to arouse the interest of all the actors of the international community and to encourage any initiative to promote peace in that country.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. - The current situation in Libya is worrying. Despite the June 2014 parliamentary elections and the formation of a government, the situation in Libya remains politically, economically and securityally critical.  I supported this resolution so that the European Union should strengthen its commitment to stability and the transition to democracy in Libya. The use of violence against civilians is unacceptable and a ceasefire between the various parties must be established as soon as possible. It is also important that the European Union act in coordination with the international community, including UNSMIL and the recently appointed UNITED Nations Special Envoy to Libya, Bernardino Leon.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted against it since it was obvious that it was the military intervention in Libya in 2011 headed by France, the United Kingdom, the United States and Canada under NATO umbrellas that has led Libya to the current failed state situation. It was the military intervervention that led to the deaths of innocent civilians and severe destruction, which have led to the destabilization of the Libyan state and the ongoing civil war. These countries took responsibility for protecting but it was actually a responsibility to protect oil. We are defending a solution in which it is the neighbouring countries, the Arab League and the African Union that promote a process for the immediate end of hostilities and dialogue between the conflicting militias, an initiative promoted by Algeria, and we reject further NATO intervention.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. – In the resolution on the situation in Libya the European Parliament demonstrates its wish to be more involved in supporting Libya’s stability and transition to democracy.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing. -  Situácia v Líbyi je momentálne zložitá. Rôzne skupiny bojujú medzi sebou, pričom ničia životy civilistov. Podporil som uznesenie, pretože vyzýva EÚ, aby aj naďalej ponúkala humanitárnu, finančnú a politickú pomoc v krízových oblastiach, v severnej Afrike a na Blízkom východ, no s cieľom riešiť základné príčiny migrácie a humanitárnych problémov. The situation in Libya is at this moment very difficult. Different groups are fighting to each other which destroy the life of civilians. I supported the resolution as it calls for the EU to continue to offer humanitarian, financial and political assistance in crisis areas in North Africa and the Middle East in order to tackle the root causes of migration and humanitarian pressures.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. - We are voting against this project because it is against FRONTEX and is calling for its abolition, while calling for the funding of migrants coming from Libya with European Union funds.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. - The EU must work with the UN Special Envoy to help Libya establish a ceasefire between the fighting parties, and to set the country on the path to peace. The international community must focus on assisting Libya in setting up state institutions, including national security forces.  Indeed, the lack of security jeopardizes any prospect of democratic transition and can only exacerbate the suffering of the population. EU security is also at stake. The EU must actively promote a partnership with regional actors, namely Egypt and Tunisia, to help establish governance, eliminate violence, terrorism and crime, and achieve the expectations of the February Revolution.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I am happy to support such a resolution in order to condemn the increasing violence, in particular against the civilian population and civilian institutions. I call on all parties to the conflict to immediately cease all violence and agree to a ceasefire in order to end the escalating suffering of the population and to engage in an inclusive national political dialogue to build a State based on the respect of human rights, democracy and the rule of law. I call on those responsible for all violations of human rights and international humanitarian law to be held accountable. I want to express my deep concern and full solidarity with the suffering Libyan civilian population and institutions.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted against it since it was obvious that it was the military intervention in Libya in 2011 headed by France, the United Kingdom, the United States and Canada under NATO umbrellas that has led Libya to the current failed state situation. It was the military intervervention that led to the deaths of innocent civilians and severe destruction, which have led to the destabilization of the Libyan state and the ongoing civil war. These countries took responsibility for protecting but it was actually a responsibility to protect oil. We are defending a solution in which it is the neighbouring countries, the Arab League and the African Union that promote a process for the immediate end of hostilities and dialogue between the conflicting militias, an initiative promoted by Algeria, and we reject further NATO intervention.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - NATO, the US and its EU allies were not concerned about the economic, civil and humanitarian consequences when they instigated internal conflict to seek to justify the violation of their sovereignty and independence by attacking the country in the trailer for the imposition of a hypocritical no-fly zone.  His interest was obviously centered on one of the largest oil reserves in the world, the largest in Africa. They set up and financed groups of mercenaries and other groups such as al-Qaeda, coming from various countries to rock, to stir divisions between clans and tribes that lived in peaceful coexistence.  The response of right-wing forces and social democracy is hypocritically alarmed by the general insecurity experienced and the continued arrival of immigrants on the shores of EU countries, whom they continue to criminalise and let die at sea or on land.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - It was not to further improve the living conditions of these people that NATO, the US and its EU and region allies promoted interference and aggression to Libya. They did not worry about the consequences when they instigated the internal conflict to seek to justify the violation of their sovereignty and independence by attacking the country in tow the imposition of a hypocritical no-fly zone. On its horizon was one of the largest oil reserves in the world, the largest in Africa, that alone mattered. To achieve their goals, they set up, financed and opened the country's doors to the entrance of mercenaries and other groups such as al-Qaeda, coming from various countries to balcanize, stir divisions between clans and tribes that lived in peaceful coexistence. The result is in sight. Right-wing and social-democracy forces are hypocritically alarmed by the general insecurity experienced and the continued arrival of immigrants on the shores of EU countries, whom they continue to criminalise and let die at sea or on land.  But its response is more of the same, with the interference of the European External Action Service, a broader CSDP mission and the militarisation of the EU's presence in Libya.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL). -
text: Madam President, I voted against the joint resolution on Palestine because I believe it sends a message to Israel that it can continue to carry out its genocide campaign against the people of Palestine with impunity. I think people across Europe are going to be disappointed to learn that this House, including MEPs from Ireland, voted against resolutions today that would, for example, have called for the release of 34 legally elected Palestinian representatives; they would have called for an international committee to be constituted to investigate the war crimes committed during the most recent Israeli aggression; they would have called on the EU to implement its own Article 2 of the EU-Israel Association Agreement by freezing the agreement as long as Israel continues its violation of human rights; and would have demanded reparations from Israel for projects that the EU itself funded and that Israel destroyed in its most recent attack on Gaza. There has been lots of talk, in this World War I centenary year, of the European Union being a symbol of peace. The actions of this House today, by contrast, make the European Parliament a symbol of international inaction against the illegal war being waged against the Palestinian people.

name: Diane Dodds (NI). -
text: Madam President, I feel that there are several aspects that must represent the core of this Parliament’s response to the current situation in this region. Firstly, we need to stand behind Israel’s sovereign right to defend its borders and people from terrorism, but we are also mindful of the immense suffering hard-felt by the people of Gaza as a direct result of this operation and we need to act to help.  Secondly, we must recognise the impact that Operation Protective Edge is having on the safety of Jewish communities across the EU. In the United Kingdom alone there were approximately 240 reports of anti-Semitic incidents in July as the fighting escalated. These types of hate crimes are completely unacceptable and as MEPs and as a Parliament it is absolutely vital that we send a message across Europe that religious tolerance has never been more important.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE). -
text: Madam President, the European Parliament must condemn without mitigation what is happening and has happened in Gaza. We are facing a genuine state crime perpetrated in this besieged prison called Gaza, whose population is with impunity massacred. The European Union cannot continue with this unbearable position equidistant from what is going on, and I have to say that the resolution adopted today is not acceptable because of its timidity and equidistance and that is why we voted against it. We call on the European Union to demand israel: first, the end of the blockade and occupation; second, the end of illegal settlements and the illegal occupation of land, which affects so many peasants; third, immediate access to humanitarian aid to Gaza; fourth, the release of members of the Palestinian Legislative Council and political prisoners; fifth, it is high time for an international committee to investigate Israeli leaders for genuine war crimes; sixth, the European Union must now activate Article 2 of the Association Agreement to suspend it and also suspend research funds going to Israeli projects. Gentlemen, I conclude by saying that the peace process is absolutely dead because of the Israeli position of violence and that we must therefore apply all diplomatic rules in order to end this siege and this massacre that the Gazati and the Palestinians are suffering.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution because it denounces Israeli military aggression against Gaza, violations of international and humanitarian law, the use of prohibited weapons, new weapons, drones and weapons whose use is prohibited in densely populated areas. This resolution calls for an end to Israel's occupation of the West Bank, Gaza and East Jerusalem.  The text reiterates support for the recognition of a viable, independent and contiguous Palestinian state with East Jerusalem as its capital, based on the 1967 borders and at peace with Israel. And the resolution calls for the implementation of Article 2 of the EU-Israel Association Agreement and the paralysing the implementation of that Agreement as long as Israel's human rights violations continue.

name: Michèle Alliot-Marie (PPE)
text: In writing. - The resolution on the Gaza war and the situation between Israel and Palestine welcomes the ceasefire under the mediation of Egypt, concluded last August.  It is essential that both sides continue to engage in dialogue for this ceasefire to be lasting, and for a lasting resolution of the conflict.  The European Union recalls the 1967 borders and the creation of two states, of which Jerusalem would be the common capital.  The European Union must strengthen its support and diplomatic, humanitarian and political assistance for a viable long-term solution in the Middle East.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Amendment 8: This amendment called for the release of over 7 000 prisoners - how are we supposed to know the nature of the offences committed? The large number of prisoners to be released would result in such individuals continuing their violent activities. Given the delicate ceasefire in Israel and Gaza, as well as the wider region, this would be an unnecessary risk.  Amendment 13 The EU has a long running hypocrisy in its policies related to produce on land controlled by other countries. Whilst this amendment called for produce on ‘occupied’ land in Israel to be banned from European markets, the EU continues to ignore produce imported into the market by Morocco, but originating in the territory it occupies in Western Sahara.  Amendment 16 This amendment called for an end to EU funds under the Horizon 2020 programme in Israel. Whilst I do not necessarily support punitive measures against Israel at a time when diplomacy is vital, I do not believe UK taxpayers’ money should be going to Israel or any other country for that matter under Horizon 2020.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. - (IT) I believe that the resolution analysing the EU's role in the Israeli-Palestinian crisis after the war in Gaza is too unbalanced in favour only of Palestine, which is therefore unbalanced, which is why I did not intend to support it with my vote.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. - The recent war between Israel and Palestine brought significant loss of life and material life. However, I believe that we must put aside the statistics and move on to concrete action to reach peace. I think this conflict has no real winners. Hostilities of late have weakened Israel's economy. The figures show a reduction in consumption, especially in the south of the country, and tourism, which accounts for 7% of GDP, has been hit hard, taking into account the peak period in midsummer. At the same time, the Hamas group claims its so-called victory simply because it still exists today, believing that the victims and material damage justify its actions. Unfortunately, it is the civilian population who are suffering to the fullest and want to stabilise the situation. The European Union must play a more active role in resolving the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. I voted in favour of this resolution because I am convinced that we have the capacity to intervene with diplomatic actions that restore the necessary balance in the region.  I would like to remind you here that funding through the PEACE III Programme for Peace and Reconciliation in Northern Ireland has contributed significantly to the creation of a stable climate in the region.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. - 'No' vote: too unbalanced a document in favour of one side. This is not the right way to facilitate the resolution of conlites.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. - It must be a priority to ensure full and unconditional access for humanitarian aid to the people of the Gaza Strip. I therefore call on the international community to step up its efforts in this regard further and to respond urgently to emergency requests for funding.  In particular, the EU must develop options for effective and comprehensive action in the following areas: full access and full movement through all gaza ports of entry, humanitarian aid and post-war reconstruction, as well as rehabilitation through the efforts of international donors, including the possible organisation of a donors' conference. I call on the EU to live up to its historical responsibilities as a genuine political player in the Middle East, including through a European peace plan and initiative for a comprehensive solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict to be presented and negotiated at an international peace conference.  I would like to stress once again that the EU, as an important trading partner and donor in the region, has at its disposal a wide range of instruments, particularly in the area of trade policy, with which to encourage both sides to take peace negotiations seriously and achieve tangible results in this regard, and I call for this lever to be used more effectively in the union's bilateral relations with Israel and with the Palestinian Authority.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. – With Regard to Amendment 8: This amendment called for the release of over 7 000 prisoners. Many of these individuals will have had convictions for violence, terrorism and extremism. The large number of prisoners to be released would result in such individuals continuing their violent activities. Given the delicate ceasefire in Israel and Gaza, as well as the wider region, this would lead to greater instability.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. - Military operations in the Gaza Strip in recent years have always turned into a massacre that has affected both Israeli and Palestinian soldiers and civilians.  We do not support factions, we do not support governments in this tragedy, we support the civilian population, the ordinary people who suffer and whose lives are hearted by foolish choices of opposing extremism. The priorities in the Gaza Strip are the open-airing of the airport and the construction of a port, the reconstruction of essential infrastructure and the stabilisation of a territorial context that urgently needs stability and peace in order to revive a social fabric destroyed by both internal and external tensions.  The monitoring of illicit arms trafficking is a necessary corollary to the future solidity of these projects, we want Europe to play its part by expanding and revitalising the EUBAM mission and not just expressing good intentions.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the resolution. Following the latest Gaza conflict, which has resulted in loss of life and unacceptable suffering for the civilian population on both sides involved, I agree with the absolute need, highlighted in the text, to continue a constructive dialogue, which is currently under way between the Israeli Government and the Palestinian National Consensus Government. It is in the common interest of the European Union and the Member States that there is no conflict in regions close to us, and it is unacceptable that the people on both sides should have to pay for the terrible consequences of such conflicts.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. - The most recent conflict in Gaza has caused the loss of lives and unacceptable suffering of the civilian population of the two parties involved. On August 26, under the aegis of Egypt, a ceasefire was reached between the parties, which ended seven weeks of conflict in Gaza. According to the ceasefire reached, humanitarian aid should be allowed access to the Gaza Strip through Israel, the Rafah pass must be opened and the fishing zone should be extended to six miles off the coast of Gaza. If the truce is maintained, the parties are expected to begin talks by the end of September 2014. I strongly condemn the violation of human rights and international humanitarian law and i support the recognition of criminal acts. I welcome egypt's egypt-mediated ceasefire and support for the EU to participate in the emergency humanitarian aid effort and reconstruction of Gaza, as well as at the international donor conference on 12 October 2014. I stress that providing full and unhindered access to humanitarian aid for the people of the Gaza Strip must be an immediate priority.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on Israel and Palestine after the war in Gaza. It is certainly a good thing that the dialogue between the Israeli Government and the Palestinian Consensus Government has been resumed, and we all hope that it will be able to continue and that the Palestinian Government will be able to assume full authority in the Gaza Strip so that a climate of peace can continue and does not fall back into anarchy. At the same time, another important hope is that the neighbouring countries, Egypt and Jordan, can both continue their efforts and make their contribution so that lasting peace can be built in the Middle East.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
