text: in writing. – War does not only turn into harsh memories for those involved and cause human tragedies for those living through it; it wreaks havoc across generations, leading to instability within the societies involved. As a Union which cherishes peace and human life, the EU and its Member States cannot shirk the role they can play in alleviating victims’ suffering and in playing a role in promoting peace in this region.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. - (IT) In view of the importance of ensuring full and unconditional access to humanitarian aid for the people of the Gaza Strip, I welcome this resolution in order to urge the international community to further intensify its efforts in this regard and to respond urgently to emergency requests for additional funding for UNRWA. In order to call on all stakeholders in the region to ensure that humanitarian aid reaches without delay those in need of basic goods and services in Gaza, with particular attention to the supply of water and electricity as well as the specific needs of children. I am concerned about the alleged cases of deliberate blocking of humanitarian aid supplies to Gaza, while noting that EU financial and humanitarian assistance must be fully allocated to the Palestinian population and must never be used, directly or indirectly, for terrorist activities. With the aim of ensuring a comprehensive and sustainable solution for the security, well-being and prosperity of both Palestinians and Israelis and of noting that the EU is committed to developing effective and comprehensive actions in the areas of movement and access, capacity building, verification and monitoring of humanitarian aid and post-war reconstruction.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution because it denounces Israeli military aggression against Gaza, violations of international and humanitarian law, the use of prohibited weapons, new weapons, drones and weapons whose use is prohibited in densely populated areas. This resolution calls for an end to Israel's occupation of the West Bank, Gaza and East Jerusalem.  The text reiterates support for the recognition of a viable, independent and contiguous Palestinian state with East Jerusalem as its capital, based on the 1967 borders and at peace with Israel. And the resolution calls for the implementation of Article 2 of the EU-Israel Association Agreement and the paralysing the implementation of that Agreement as long as Israel's human rights violations continue.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. - After so much effort, Egypt has managed to mediate an agreement that led to a ceasefire between Israel and Palestine after seven weeks of hostilities. Although the 1949 Geneva Conventions governing the right to war make a clear distinction between military and civilian objectives, there have been many casualties among the latter, while more than 500 Palestinian children lost their lives during the fighting. All this has led to a serious humanitarian crisis in Gaza.  Europe can do so much in the reconstruction and economic recovery phase of Gaza, in the devolution of humanitarian aid and in monitoring that this aid reaches those who really need it, through a transparent and coordinated process. With this in mind, active participation in the International Donors' Conference scheduled for 12 October 2014 in Cairo will be important. Europe must play a more active political role in this context and act as a mediator for a lasting solution. The role of the High Representative will be crucial in mediation. The S&D Group visited the territories of Israel and Palestine to open a political dialogue with all interested parties. It is important to support President Mahmoud Abbas as a man of peace and dialogue.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution as the situation in Gaza and in the wider Palestinian territories and Israel is unacceptable. We need to relaunch the peace process towards a solution. The Gaza war has caused 2 138 Palestinian deaths – 490 of them children – and 70 Israeli deaths in 50 days. It is unacceptable to have 36 Palestinian Members of Parliament in jail – some without charge or trial. The European Parliament must speak out on this very important issue. We recognise those in Israel that are working for peace and reconciliation with Palestine, and we believe in the legitimate right of Israel to live in security. However, this cannot be used as a pretext to commit a humanitarian massacre like the one in Gaza.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. With this vote on the situation in Israel and Palestine, we recall that the European Union's priority following the ceasefire is to respond to the humanitarian crisis there. An adequate supply of water is urgent. The European Union cannot simply welcome the ceasefire agreement reached through Egypt's mediation. It must also engage to participate in the reconstruction process.

name: Georgios Epitideios (NI)
text: Writing. - I believe that the transformation of the Palestinian State into an international protectorate in no way guarantees peace, prosperity and, above all, the national independence of the Palestinian Nation. It also does not promote the reconciliation of the Palestinians with each other but, on the contrary, strengthens civil strife. That is why we are voting against the motion for a resolution.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. - During the months of July and August there were weeks of constant clashes between Israel and Palestine. This escalation of the conflict caused nearly 3,000 fatalities and the displacement of nearly 64,000 refugees, the total destruction of more than 1700 homes and major damage to more than 40,000. The destruction of these homes, hospitals and health care facilities coupled with the considerable number of victims and refugees has led to a major humanitarian crisis. The signing of the ceasefire on 26 August must be welcomed. However, the international community cannot be desented in this deep humanitarian crisis that has caused this conflict. In this regard, this resolution promoted by the European Parliament urges the EU to participate effectively in the work of urgent humanitarian aid and in the reconstruction of Gaza and to participate decisively in the International Donor Conference to be held in Cairo on 12 October.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. - In the most recent Israeli-Palestinian conflict, more than 2000 Palestinians were killed, a third of whom were children, 10,000 were injured while 66 Israeli soldiers and six civilians lost their lives and 500 were wounded. More than 1,700 homes were destroyed, 40,000 damaged and 17 hospitals and clinics, 136 schools, 60 mosques and 13 cemeteries were destroyed. Entire neighborhoods and basic infrastructure have been razed to the ground in Gaza.  Experts estimated $8 billion at the cost of rebuilding Gaza and the Palestinian government requested $550 million for food aid and access to clean water, health care and education. Europe's participation in the international donor conference is crucial, and this financial assistance should fully benefit the Palestinian people as effectively as possible and not in terrorist activities. Europe must strive for full and unhindered access to humanitarian aid by the people of the Gaza Strip and all actors in the region, in particular as regards electricity and water supply services and the basic needs of children.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Another resolution of unacceptable content, which excused Israel's aggression against Palestine. The repetition of the cynical and shameful artifice of making believe that the aggressor is the victim and that the victim is the aggressor. Israel's criminal action against the Palestinian people has no other objective than to try to impose and enshrine the acceptance of the effective occupation of Palestine and the capitulation and abdication of the national rights of the Palestinian people. We regret – but this is not surprising – that the majority of this Parliament does not denounce or strongly condemn the criminal military offensive against the Gaza Strip and its people.  We regret the lead in the proposals put forward by our Group to substantially increase the amount allocated to UNRWA and the Palestinian Authority to deal with the immense humanitarian and disaster disaster in Gaza.  We regret that you oppose the immediate end of the Gaza siege, immediate and unbarrierd access to humanitarian aid, especially to cover urgent medical needs. That opposes the supply of electricity from any source as well as water supply. Wanting to be neutral in a situation of state terrorism by an occupying power is the same as being a collaborator and accomplice to this aggression.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. – I believe that the transformation of the Palestinian State into an international protectorate in no way ensures peace, prosperity and, above all, the national independence of the Palestinian Nation. It also does not promote the reconciliation of the Palestinians with each other but, on the contrary, strengthens civil strife. That is why we are voting against the motion for a resolution.

name: Mariya Gabriel (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because it underlines above all the role of the EU and the international community in not letting the status quo take over. Waiting is the game of extremists, in a context where each crisis anticipates the next. A lasting solution is needed, allowing both the reconstruction of Gaza, the resumption of dialogue between the Palestinians on the one hand, and between Israel and the Palestinian national consensus government on the other, as well as a stabilization of the region. As the resolution states, the EU and Member States must take a more active role in reviving the Israeli-Palestinian peace process and support the efforts of the Egyptian ombudsman. The EU must also anticipate the spread of terrorist groups in the West Bank and the destabilization of the region, and to do so, work more with Jordan and Egypt. Finally, with this resolution we recall our support for a two-state solution on the basis of the 1967 borders as a pragmatic and realistic solution.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. – This amendment called for the release of over 7 000 prisoners. Many of these individuals will have had convictions for violence, terrorism and extremism. The large number of prisoners to be released would result in such individuals continuing their violent activities. Given the delicate ceasefire in Israel and Gaza, as well as the wider region, this would lead to greater instability.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. - Fine Gael MEPs voted in favour of the Joint motion for a resolution on Israel-Palestine after the Gaza war and the role of the EU (RC-B8-0117/2014), which was co-signed by five political groups, as it appropriately supports a lasting ceasefire in the region, condemns violations of human rights and international humanitarian law and supports efforts to provide additional humanitarian funding.  Fine Gael MEPs recognise that the blockade of Gaza must be ended and that unobstructed access to humanitarian aid must be allowed. We are categorical in condemning the disproportionate use of military force by Israel as well as the firing of rockets by Hamas and other militants into Israel. We believe that all citizens, Palestinian or Israeli, have the right to live in peace and security and we encourage both sides to engage in genuine negotiations to end violence and ensure that a lasting ceasefire is instituted. Written Explanation of vote signed by Brian Hayes, Seán Kelly, Mairead McGuinness and Deirdre Clune.

name: Eduard-Raul Hellvig (PPE)
text: in writing. - The ceasefire agreement in the Gaza Strip must be strengthened through a sustained and effective dialogue between Israel and the Palestinian authorities, so as to prevent a re-emergence of the armed conflict, to ensure the necessary conditions for access to humanitarian aid so necessary for the civilian population and to create the premises for the start of the reconstruction of destroyed homes, hospitals and schools. The EU has a duty to become more actively involved in relaunching the Israeli-Palestinian peace process, and I regret, in this respect, that the relatively recent ambitious initiative of US Secretary of State John Kerry has not been more actively supported by European diplomacy. I support the resolution that advocates both intra-Palestinian reconciliation between Hamas and the Palestinian Authority and new efforts to resolve this historic conflict peacefully. All the more so since we cannot lose sight of the broader regional framework, over which the growing threat of extremist groups, which tend to draw a terror axis from Nigeria to Iraq, crosses the Sahel, Libya, Gaza and Syria.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - With regard to Amendment No 14 calling for "freezing" of the EU-Israel partnership agreement: Article 2 of the EU-Israel Association Treaty states that respect for human rights should guide the internal and foreign policy of the associated countries as a fundamental pillar. Israel's action systematically violates human rights as recognized by numerous international actors, which would justify the immediate freezing of the agreement. Not doing so means, on the part of the European Union, covering up these violations and becoming complicit with them, sending a clear message to Israel that it will not force it to abide by international law. The European Union must put the defence of human rights before its commercial interests.  With regard to the final vote against the Joint Resolution: The Joint Resolution once again does not include concrete demands on Israel, when there are many areas where pressure could be taken to promote the fulfilment of human rights and a fair exit from the conflict. For this reason we believe that the Resolution suffers from a dangerous, unacceptable equidistance at a time when Israel's action is extremely aggressive against a Palestinian population that resists heroically. We cannot support a resolution on this issue which assumes this ambivalent position.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. - I voted for the resolution because I support peace in the Middle East. Calling on Israel and Palestine to jointly address the problem is a way to achieve peace, and in this the European Union needs to be a credible mediator with its views.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. - I voted in favour of the resolution on the conflict in Gaza, which welcomes the ceasefire agreement reached through Egyptian mediation and calls for the rapid reconstruction of Gaza. The resolution was adopted by a large majority. I welcome the result of this vote.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I welcome the european Parliament's support for this joint resolution on the situation in Israel and Palestine after the Gaza war, in which MEPs welcome the ceasefire agreement reached on 26 August 2014 through Egypt's mediation and call for the rapid deployment of emergency humanitarian aid in the Gaza Strip. Recalling their commitment to a two-state solution, MEPs also call on all parties to continue their efforts to find a political solution to the conflict and to promote the conditions for a lasting peace. With this in mind, the resolution calls on the European Union to help rebuild Gaza and to participate in the International Donor Conference to be held on 12 October 2014.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. – I strongly supported the resolution calling for the EU to play a more active role in the efforts to find a permanent solution in this long on-going conflict. The loss of human life and damage to property in this conflict has been shocking. The EU must therefore participate effectively in the urgent humanitarian aid effort and in the reconstruction of Gaza. We should demand that Israel open Gaza’s borders and immediately halt and withdraw from all illegal settlements, which are undermining the two-state solution. The EU, as a major trade partner and donor in the region, should more effectively use the leverage of its instruments, particularly in the field of trade policy, to resume credible peace talks and achieve tangible results in this process.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. - (IT) First of all, I would like to say a thought to the Palestinian and Israeli victims caused by the violent conflict on Gaza territory. I call on the European Union to play a more active political role in achieving a just and lasting peace between Israelis and Palestinians. Europe can and must play a more active role in contributing to the strengthening of long-term and sustainable global security, to the well-being and prosperity of the peoples involved; I welcome the EU's willingness to develop solutions for effective and comprehensive action in the areas of freedom of access and movement, humanitarian assistance and post-conflict reconstruction.

name: Jean Lambert (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – I voted against this resolution as, while the basis of it was reasonable, it added nothing of real strength to the resolution of a few weeks ago. I supported many of the amendments tabled by GUE, as I feel the EU must be clear in its condemnation of the continued building of settlements in Palestinian territory, the recent ‘land grab’ after the tragic deaths of four youths and the ongoing ‘siege’ of Gaza. When I visited the area some years ago, I was told Israel can choose to create a real economy or a tunnel economy – they chose the latter, which has given control of the territory to the very people Israel wishes to remove. Yes, the rocket attacks into Israel must stop: I could not vote for the GUE resolution although I agreed with much of the text because it reflected only part of what is happening. But I feel that the EP has to recognise that, until there are real consequences for the Israeli Government’s ongoing creation of ‘facts on the ground’, nothing very much will change.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. - The joint resolution proposed to us is too timid in its condemnation of Israel's illegal actions and marks a retreat from the European Parliament's positions on the settlement of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. This text puts the two belligerents on an equal footing, while everything from the loss of life to the material destruction to the causes of this conflict, points to a blatant imbalance in favour of Israel. The absence of a clear condemnation of the massive Israeli bombings, the collective punishment it inflicts on an entire people, the continuation of the siege of the Gaza Strip, its responsibilities in the rotting of the situation and its continuation in parallel with settlement in the West Bank, cannot be condoned. That is why, in the absence of sufficient support for our amendments which were to correct these voluntary errors, I preferred not to give my support to a text which absolves Israel of its responsibilities and refuses any questioning of European diplomacy in relation to the multiple abuses and violations of international law perpetrated by Israel.

name: Paloma López (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this Resolution because it denounces Israeli military aggression against Gaza, violations of international and humanitarian law, the use of prohibited weapons, new weapons, drones and weapons whose use is prohibited in densely populated areas. This Resolution calls for an end to Israel's occupation of the West Bank, Gaza and East Jerusalem.  The text reiterates support for the recognition of a viable, independent and contiguous Palestinian state with East Jerusalem as its capital, based on the 1967 borders and at peace with Israel. And the Resolution calls for the implementation of Article 2 of the EU-Israel Association Agreement and to paralyze israel's implementation of that agreement as long as human rights violations continue.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. - I support the motion for a Resolution on Israel and Palestine after the Gaza War and the EU's role in the dramatic to unacceptable situation of the Palestinian population after the last war in Gaza. It left more than 2,000 Palestinians dead (most of them civilians, including 503 children) and 72 Israelis killed, as well as 10,000 wounded and 63,000 Palestinian displaced persons inside Gaza. Dozens of houses, hospitals, schools and water tanks have been destroyed, leaving thousands of Palestinians in a humanitarian emergency, without access to food, water or basic services. This motion for a Resolution aims to boost and make more visible the role of the EU, and member states, in this conflict that has been causing blood, suffering and hatred between Israel and Palestine for too many years, and calls on the parties to apply the ceasefire conditions of 26 August 2014. The Spanish Socialists stand out and want the EU to support more strongly the peacemaking role of Mahmud Abbas with the aim of unlocking the process and being able to return to peace negotiations that lead to a just and lasting solution.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. - The S&D Group's position was to vote 'no' in general, and I (as a member of the Socialists and Democrats) followed the discipline of the faction.

name: Ramona Nicole Mănescu (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution. I welcome the ceasefire agreement and Egypt's important role in the mediation process. I support the call for the EU to effectively participate in the reconstruction of Gaza and the urgent humanitarian effort. It is important that key actors in the region, in particular Egypt and Jordan, are encouraged to continue to work to calm the situation. I also support the call on the institutions of the European Union to encourage trade, cultural, scientific, economic and energy and water relations between Israel and its neighbours. I welcome the EU's readiness to contribute to an effective and sustainable solution that strengthens the security, well-being and prosperity of Palestinians and Israelis alike, and I believe that active political involvement of Member States is necessary in order to try to achieve a lasting peace between Israelis and Palestinians.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. - (IT) I offered my support for the motion for a resolution on Israel and Palestine following the Gaza war, because, firstly, it strongly supports any attempt to reach a lasting and fully respected ceasefire agreement between the two parties.  I think it is good that, through this document, the European Parliament is expressing, on the one hand, the need to offer real support to the political parties, movements and citizens of Israel who have opposed Israeli aggression and, on the other, the need to support, through concrete humanitarian missions, the reconstruction of gaza territory, following a 50-day military siege.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. I was unfortunately unable to agree to the European Parliament resolution of 18 September 2014 'on Israel and Palestine after the Gaza conflict and on the role of the EU'. The decision is a step in the right direction, but in my opinion it is too vague and is a mere declaration of intent. Since we, and especially the inhabitants of the crisis region, need a well-thought-out and, above all, sensible solution to this conflict, I could only reject this resolution, which was quickly formulated and without substance. The resolution of this crisis is essential for the creation of peace throughout the Middle East. That is why a good approach must also have a preventive component and thus start at the root of the conflict.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. - Under the guise of consensus putting all entities using violence on the same level, the text takes sides with the Israeli far-right government against which absolutely no sanctions are proposed. None of the EU's very important means of pressure on Israel are used to force its government to stop the massacre. I vote against this resolution that is grossly aligned, hypocritical and unfair. The drafters of this document would have had better time to draw inspiration from the courageous Israeli dissidents from the army and the services who denounce the role of their government instead of playing the Pontius Pilate.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. - The recent conflict in Gaza has caused the loss of life and unacceptable suffering of the civilian population of the two parties involved. Thus, the ceasefire sponsored by Egypt is welcome.  However, I cannot fail to condemn Hamas's aggressive stance and the constant terrorist attacks against Israel. It is certain that Israel could be more measured in responding to these attacks, but Hamas must be condemned for the way it endangers the people of the Gaza Strip by maintaining the constant attacks and using it as a base to attack Israel.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The suffering suffered by the Israeli and Palestinian civilian populations after 50 days of intensive fighting is intolerable. I commend UNRWA's remarkable work in dealing with one of the most serious humanitarian crises In Gaza in decades. Efforts must continue to allow humanitarian aid to flow freely through Gaza and to ensure that people have access to municipal water again. I welcome the role of mediator played by the Egyptian authorities in securing this ceasefire, which raises hope because it provides for the opening of crossing points between Israel and the Gaza Strip and an easing of the blockade imposed by Israel since 2006. The focus now is on creating the conditions for a lasting ceasefire that will eventually lead to the creation of two independent states. This requires the inclusion of different regional and international actors. This would be an opportunity for the EU to reactivate and review the mandate of its EUBAM Rafah and EUPOL COOPS missions.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour on the resolution on Israel and Palestine after the Gaza war and the role of the European Union. The resolution stresses the importance of the European Union developing options for effective and comprehensive action in the following areas: movement and access, capacity building, verification and monitoring, humanitarian relief and post-conflict reconstruction.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted against the various individual resolutions but in favour of the joint resolution. The latter calls for reconciliation between the Palestinians, Hamas and the Palestinian Authority, so that they can work together to rebuild Gaza. A peaceful, political and lasting solution must be found without further delay. The European Union must contribute to a long-term and sustainable global crisis that strengthens the security, well-being and prosperity of both Palestinians and Israelis. It is imperative that the Palestinian Authority, the European Union, Egypt and Jordan take joint action to ensure that terrorist groups in Gaza and the West Bank cannot rearm, resume rocket-making and tunnel construction.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Despite some positive points, the amendments that our group has proposed to make the resolution relevant, such as the end of the blockade of Gaza, the cessation of Israeli settlement, the holding of an investigation into Israeli war crimes, or the request for international protection for Gaza, have not been adopted, and I have therefore voted against this text which is content with pious wishes and hollow statements.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri (S&D)
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on Israel-Palestine after the Gaza War and the role of the EU. The 'Margin of Protection' military attack launched by Israel last July left 2 150 Palestinians dead, including 503 children, 260 women, 95 elderly people and 14 journalists, and more than 12 500 injured. 450 000 people were internally displaced and 1 400 children lost both parents. In the face of such a humanitarian catastrophe, the European Union's attitude towards Israel must be intransigent.  Our task is to work to ensure peace and coexistence. The EU has the necessary strength, if it wishes, to 'force' peace. He then exercises his role to the full.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI)
text: Writing. – All the resolutions on the situation in Gaza and the role of the EU, tabled by the political groups, conceal the role of the EU which supports, together with the US and NATO, Israeli barbarism and encourages Israeli crimes by multiform upgrading its relations with Israel, the policy of equalising the perpetrator with the victim. They are confounding the people, making the EU a factor that can contribute to the struggle of the Palestinian people, while it is well known that it stands up to it, embellishing the role and character of this imperialist union of capital, which is an opponent of the peoples. Indeed, the joint resolution adopted, like the previous one, during the Israeli criminal attack on the Palestinians, puts the Palestinian people in the place of the accused by incriminating them for their resistance, justifies Israeli atrocities and openly supports Israeli aggression. The Communist Party stands firmly in solidarity in the struggle of the Palestinian people to immediately end the Israeli occupation and the creation of an independent Palestinian state, with East Jerusalem as its capital, on the edge of 1967, which in order to be victorious needs to know its enemies, to orient itself against imperialism and the exploitative capitalist system.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. - As co-signatories of the resolution on behalf of the EPP Group, I supported the European Parliament's resolution on Israel and Palestine after the Gaza war and the role of the EU. The Gaza war has resulted in more than 2,000 deaths on both sides and extensive material damage to civilian facilities and infrastructure. Due to the terrifying loss of human lives, I welcome the ceasefire of 26 August and hope that this agreement will be the basis for progress in peace talks to be held in Cairo at the end of September with Egypt's support. I support the efforts of the Security Council and the UN to reach a consensus and resolution that would be an international framework for normalising the situation in the Gaza Strip. I believe that a lasting ceasefire and normalisation of the situation are the basis for the consolidation of the Palestinian Authority as well as the continuation of the reconstruction of the belt and the further flow of humanitarian aid. I would like to stress the importance of EU BAM Rafah and EUPOL COPPS, but also call for a stronger EU presence and role, in particular as regards the flow of continued humanitarian aid and the reconstruction of destroyed infrastructure and civilian facilities.  I call for continued dialogue, normalisation of relations and demilitarisation of the Gaza Strip, and I hope that the foundations for long-term security and peace have been achieved.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. - I voted in favour of the resolution on the events in Gaza, on which it is imperative to shed all light and condemn the violence. The European Union must give itself the stature of an international player, at the height of its status as the world's leading donor to Palestine.

name: Christine Revault D'Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D)
text: In writing. - The European Parliament has just adopted a resolution on the situation in Israel and the Palestinian Territories after the Gaza war. MEPs unanimously condemn the violations of human rights and humanitarian law committed during this conflict which has caused intolerable suffering to the civilian population and a serious humanitarian crisis. Immediately, following the signing of the ceasefire on 26 August 2014, priority must be given to the reconstruction and rehabilitation of Gaza, as well as the delivery of humanitarian aid. The EU must participate in this emergency humanitarian effort, but also play a more active role in achieving a lasting peace between Israelis and Palestinians. Moving towards peace does not mean returning to the status quo before conflict. Working for peace involves lifting the blockade of Gaza, disarming the Gaza Strip and halting settlement. Parliament also affirms its support for Mahmoud Abbas' policy of reconciliation among Palestinians, a necessary condition for appeasement and dialogue. It is time to open a new chapter of peace to allow the two-state solution to finally become a reality.

name: Teresa Rodriguez-Rubio (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Article 2 of the EU-Israel Association Treaty states that respect for human rights, which should guide the internal and external policy of partner countries, is a fundamental pillar. Israel's action systematically violates human rights as recognized by numerous international actors, which would justify the immediate freezing of the agreement. Not doing so means, on the part of the European Union, covering up these violations and becoming complicit with them, sending a clear message to Israel that it will not force it to abide by international law. The European Union must put the defence of human rights before its commercial interests.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - With regard to Amendment No 14 calling for "freezing" of the EU-Israel Association Agreement: Article 2 of the EU-Israel Association Treaty states that respect for human rights should guide the internal and foreign policy of the associated countries as a fundamental pillar. Israel's action systematically violates human rights as recognized by numerous international actors, which would justify the immediate freezing of the agreement. Not doing so means, on the part of the European Union, covering up these violations and becoming complicit with them, sending a clear message to Israel that it will not force it to abide by international law. The European Union must put the defence of human rights before its commercial interests.  With regard to the final vote against the Joint Resolution: The Joint Resolution once again does not include concrete demands on Israel, when there are many areas where pressure could be taken to promote the fulfilment of human rights and a fair exit from the conflict. For this reason we believe that the Resolution suffers from a dangerous, unacceptable equidistance at a time when Israel's action is extremely aggressive against a Palestinian population that resists heroically. We cannot support a resolution on this issue which assumes this ambivalent position.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this Resolution because it denounces Israeli military aggression against Gaza, violations of international and humanitarian law, the use of prohibited weapons, new weapons, drones and weapons whose use is prohibited in densely populated areas. This Resolution calls for an end to Israel's occupation of the West Bank, Gaza and East Jerusalem.  The text reiterates support for the recognition of a viable, independent and contiguous Palestinian state with East Jerusalem as its capital, based on the 1967 borders and at peace with Israel. And the Resolution calls for the implementation of Article 2 of the EU-Israel Association Agreement and to paralyze israel's implementation of that agreement as long as human rights violations continue.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing. - Hlasoval som za vyhlásenie, pretože toto vyhlásenie víta dialóg medzi vládou Izraela a palestínskou vládou národného porozumenia a vyzýva obe krajiny, aby v ňom pokračovali. Verím, že mier môže nastať iba po skutočnom zblížení. Mali by sme mať na pamäti, že žiaden zákon nezmierni nenávisť. Rovnako, vyhlásenie hovorí o tom, že bez rekonštrukcie a ekonomickej obnovy nemôže v pásme Gazy nastať dlhodobá stabilita pričom tomuto bráni nedostatok pohybu ľudí. Vyhlásenie tiež vyzýva k rekonštrukcii a rehabilitácii Gazy.  The reasons why I voted in favour for this resolution are: First of all because the statement welcomes the on-going dialogue between the Israeli Government and the Palestinian National Consensus Government and urges both parties to continue with that. I believe that peace can only be there when real reconciliation happens. We should keep in mind that hatred cannot be diminished by law. Furthermore, the statement says that there will be no long-term stability in Gaza without reconstruction and economic revival, which is undermined by the lack of free movement of people and goods; and calls for a rapid reconstruction and rehabilitation of Gaza.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: in writing. - I do not consider the joint resolution presented to be fully balanced. It is, of course, necessary to ensure that the conflict, which has left many lives lost on both sides, is ended as quickly as possible. However, I believe that there is a very difficult path towards this objective, during which the situation in the whole context must be carefully assessed. I am of the opinion that the text of the resolution does not take sufficient account of all the circumstances of the current reality in Israel and the Gaza Strip. The text does not mention, for example, the fact that egypt-brokered peace talks ended in August this year as a result of the resumption of Hamas rocket attacks on Israel. I believe that rocket attacks by militant organisations in the Gaza Strip against civilians in Israel must be consistently condemned. For this reason, I abstained when discussing this point.

name: Bart Staes (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. - I voted against the joint motion for a resolution on Israel and Palestine after the Gaza War and the role of the EU. This is a weak, biased and factually incorrect text. There is uncertainty about the EU's role in this conflict. It is not even suggested that the EU should play a more active role. There is no reference in the text to the disproportionality in the use of force and the fallen victims between Israel and Palestine. Nothing is said about the failed peace talks (April 2014) and the deliberate sabotage of the peace process by Israel. Nor is there any reference to Israel's shortcomings in the armistice: cross-border traffic is further curtailed, the fishing zone is not expanded, there is no regular opening of the Rafah border crossing. Nothing is said about Egypt's dubious role and the conclusion that the second round of talks in Cairo may not take place. Nor is it referred to the responsibility of the UN. What is bad is that there is no reference or condemnation of yet another land grab in the West Bank, the largest in the past 30 years. There are many factual errors in the resolution, read paragraphs 2 and 5. This is a mess.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. - I am voting against the motion for a resolution because the independence of the Palestinian State and peace in the Gaza region is not linked to the creation of an international protectorate. The plan will result in increased tensions and civil disputes.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. – The recent war between Israel and Palestinian militants in the Gaza strip has been the third of its kind in the past six years, and possibly the most gruelling of all. Although it lasted for 50 days, it claimed the lives of more than 2000 Palestinian, mostly children, and 70 Israelis. In reaction to the 4500 rockets and mortars fired at Israel by Palestinian militants, the 5226 air strikes carried out by the Israeli air force left Gaza in ruins and in humanitarian need. The ongoing cycle of violence must be broken. Although Israel has the legitimate right to defend itself against militant attacks, the death of children and innocents is simply unacceptable. The only way to break this vicious circle is to find a sustainable agreement that will address all the root causes of the conflict. Such agreement should restore fundamental freedoms to the people in Gaza and at the same time provide security for Israel. The EU has a prominent role to play in the resumption of the Middle East peace process, with the objective of a two-state solution. I strongly urge the Union to take a more active role in the efforts aimed at achieving a just and lasting peace.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. - A political stalemate coupled with a desperate humanitarian situation has settled in Palestine. This situation is unacceptable and the European Parliament must decide on this very important issue.  We are aware of the good work being done in Israel by many civil organizations and political parties working for peace and reconciliation with Palestine, and we are convinced of Israel's legitimate right to live in security. However, this cannot be the only argument to be taken into account in this conflict, and it cannot be used as a pretext to commit a humanitarian massacre, as in Gaza. This is the worst political and humanitarian situation I have seen in Palestine in the last 20 years.  The people of Palestine live under the daily threat of death and destruction, and Palestinian political leaders are exhausted and running out of patience. In these circumstances, the Socialist Group and the European Union have a responsibility and a role to play. They must help both sides return to the peace process. The only way to do this is to support Mahmoud Abbas' efforts and strengthen his position, as he is the best peace ambassador in the Middle East.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this Resolution because it denounces Israeli military aggression against Gaza, violations of international and humanitarian law, the use of prohibited weapons, new weapons, drones and weapons whose use is prohibited in densely populated areas. This Resolution calls for an end to Israel's occupation of the West Bank, Gaza and East Jerusalem.  The text reiterates support for the recognition of a viable, independent and contiguous Palestinian state with East Jerusalem as its capital, based on the 1967 borders and at peace with Israel. And the Resolution calls for the implementation of Article 2 of the EU-Israel Association Agreement and to paralyze israel's implementation of that agreement as long as human rights violations continue.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. – The need to allow humanitarian aid to civilians in the Gaza strip is essential to establishing a lasting peace in the region. For this reason I supported the resolution calling on Israel and Hamas to allow humanitarian aid into the Gaza Strip immediately.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. - I voted in favour of the resolution tabled by my GUE-NGL group but against the resolution put forward by the EPP, S-D, ECR and ALDE groups. Our resolution called for the release of Palestinian political prisoners, a ban on the export of European weapons to Israel and a considerable increase in the resources allocated to UNRWA (United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees in the Near East). A very large majority of members of this Parliament even voted against calling on Israel to repay projects financed by the EU and destroyed by its army, member states to implement guidelines on the import ban on products from the colonies, or the establishment of a commission of inquiry into human rights violations committed during the last conflict. The resolution finally adopted by the European Parliament does not say a word about the blockade imposed by Israel on Gaza, making it a veritable open-air prison; not a word about the expansion of illegal settlements; nor a word of the war crimes committed by the Israeli army.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This Resolution of Parliament excuses Israel's aggression against Palestine and it is unacceptable, cynical and shameful to turn the aggressor into the victim and the victim into the aggressor. It is necessary and mandatory for the majority of this Parliament to denounce and strongly condemn the criminal military offensive against the Gaza Strip and its people.  The amount allocated to UNRWA and the Palestinian Authority to deal with the immense humanitarian and material disaster in Gaza needs to be substantially increased.  This opposition to the end of the siege of Gaza and against immediate and unsecured access to humanitarian aid is shameful, especially to cover urgent medical needs.  Wanting to be neutral in a situation of state terrorism by an occupying power is the same as being a collaborator and accomplice to this aggression.

name: Glenis Willmott (S&D)
text: in writing. – This resolution calls for the EU to participate in the rebuilding of Gaza and provision of urgent humanitarian aid to the population of the Gaza strip after the recent Gaza war ended with a ceasefire in August. The role of Egypt in brokering the ceasefire was commendable, and the involvement of other key regional actors should be encouraged. The resolution also states that the current situation in Gaza is unsustainable, and reiterates support for a two-state solution and the removal of the blockade in Gaza. Labour MEPs supported this resolution because we believe that the EU should play a key role in rebuilding Gaza and providing aid, and that the two-state solution is the only way to ensure lasting peace and security for the Israeli and Palestinian people.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour because it calls for the annulment of the act of ratification of the Economic Partnership Agreement with Fiji. Fiji's current self-proclaimed military government is not entitled to take decisions on the implementation and ratification of the Agreement, so the Decision of 17 July 2014 must be considered null and void. I believe that the Commission should suspend any decision providing for Fiji's reintegration into Annex I to the Market Access Regulation as a result of the application of the provisional ECA until the announced elections have been successfully held in accordance with international standards. Similarly, the Commission should not propose a new delegated act in this regard until after a transitional period to properly assess the stability and irreversibility of the democratic reform process.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. — (IT) I find the resolution subject to the vote unbalanced, which is why I did not vote in favour of it.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution because it is important to ensure respect for human rights, democracy and the rule of law in the region. In addition, the safeguarding of human rights is an essential element of the Cotonou Agreement, which governs relations between the African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) countries and the European Union (EU). As regards relations between the region and the EU, it should be stressed that the Cotonou Agreement remains the basis for the EU's partnership with acp countries. The European Parliament is therefore of the opinion that the current, arbitraryly pro-Fiji military government does not have the legitimate power to take any decision on the application and ratification of the Interim Economic Partnership Agreement and that the decision of 17 July 2014 must accordingly be considered null and void. The President of the European Parliament shall inform the Commission that the delegated regulation cannot enter into force for these reasons.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. - (IT) I am voting against the proposal, which I believe is instrumental, by the GUE and Green Political Groups which raise (pursuant to Rule 105(IV) of the Rules of Procedure) an objection to a delegated act of the European Commission re-inserting fiji in Annex I to Regulation 1528 of 2007 on the trade preferences of the African, Caribbean and Pacific countries.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. - On Wednesday, September 17, 2014, Fijian voters went to the polls to elect a democratic Parliament, being able to choose from 262 candidates from as many as seven different parties. In the light of the democratic elections that have already taken place, I voted against this resolution because I do not believe that there is a good reason to exclude Fiji from the interim economic partnership agreement.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. - (IT) I am voting in favour of this resolution because I do not think it is appropriate to make agreements with self-proclaimed military governments. Despite the fact that the Fijian Government has ratified the Interim Economic Partnership Agreement, I consider its validity to be illegitimate until the elections are held in accordance with democratic principles.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour because it calls for the annulment of the act of ratification of the Economic Partnership Agreement with Fiji. Fiji's current self-proclaimed military government is not entitled to take decisions on the implementation and ratification of the Agreement, so the decision of 17 July 2014 should be considered null and void. I believe that the Commission should suspend any decision providing for Fiji's reintegration into Annex I to the Market Access Regulation as a result of the application of the provisional ECA until the announced elections have been successfully held in accordance with international standards. Similarly, the Commission should not propose a new delegated act in this regard until after a transitional period to properly assess the stability and irreversibility of the democratic reform process.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. - Fiji's request cannot be considered and cannot enter into force, because the country has not yet demonstrated the conditions for the return of democracy, as several international bodies report when referring to attempts to silence journalists before the elections scheduled for September, for example. In addition, the self-proclaimed Government of Fiji has no legitimacy to take any decision on this matter. The Commission should therefore not take any decision until the announced elections are properly held, following international directives and, even after that, a transitional period is needed to assess the situation of stability and recovery of mandatory democratic standards in all countries.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The resolution tabled by our Group opposes the Commission's delegated act, which aims at the reintegration of eight ACP countries in Annex I to Regulation (EC) No 1528/2007 (Market Access Regulation). This Regulation provides that countries that have negotiated but not yet ratified the Economic Partnership Agreements (EPAs) benefit from a duty-free and quota-free import regime. The Commission, in to force the signature by african countries of the EPAs, amended the Regulation so that they are expelled from the Annex of beneficiary countries if by 1 October 2014 they do not conclude the agreements and the Commission may adopt delegated acts to reinstate them.  We have always demonstrated our opposition to epas. What the EU wants with these agreements is to ensure the opening up of markets to its major economic and financial groups, sell goods and services, exploit raw materials and impose an export-driven production model in their interests. Furthermore, opposition to the delegated act concerning Fiji is justified by the political situation in the country, which has been under military dictatorship since the 2006 coup. The current government has no legitimacy to make the decision to ratify the EPA.

name: Ashley Fox (ECR)
text: in writing. - Mr President, I have voted against the proposal to remove Fiji from the beneficiaries of duty-free quota-free access to the EU market, because of the disastrous impact it would have on the sugar, agriculture and processed agricultural product sectors of the Fijian economy. Many Fijian workers who rely on these export sectors could lose their jobs and livelihoods as a result, with no certainty that the aims of the proposed rejection would have any concrete political impact. Additionally, the new EPA contains a strong human rights clause, with the possibility of suspension of preferences should Fiji not respect its commitments. Therefore, the Greens and GUE are, by arguing that the EPA should not be implemented, making the chances of democratic transition more unlikely by removing possible EU leverage.

name: Agnes Jongerius (S&D)
text: Written. - Our delegation has just abstained from voting on the Report on Fiji. We agree that the situation in Fiji is worrying. Since the 2006 coup, the population has suffered greatly from repressive measures. Human rights are systematically violated, especially freedoms of expression, assembly and association are under great pressure. As a result, workers find it difficult to organise themselves in a trade union and it is extremely complicated to form a political party. Taking these circumstances into account, we think it would be the wrong signal if the EU were to conclude an EPA with Fiji.  On the other hand, it is important that the EU is consistent in its policy on international trade and strengthening human rights in the world. The EU must be a reliable partner that treats equal countries equally. In this case, Fiji is being punished for violating human rights, whereas previously EPO's have been concluded with countries where the situation is far from ideal. That is why we are calling for not only Fiji, but all the countries with which the EU is negotiating, as well as the countries with which EPAs have already been concluded, to be scrutinised with regard to the human rights situation.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. - I voted against the resolution to exclude Fiji from the group of ACP states (Africa, Caribbean, Pacific) enjoying trade advantages in their trade with the EU. Fiji had made progress in negotiating an association agreement with the EU, making them eligible for these transitional trade benefits. I welcome the rejection of this resolution.

name: Paloma López (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour because it calls for the annulment of the act of ratification of the Economic Partnership Agreement with Fiji. Fiji's current self-proclaimed military government is not entitled to take decisions on the implementation and ratification of the Agreement, so the decision of 17 July 2014 should be considered null and void. text: Written. - Our delegation has just abstained from voting on the Report on Fiji. We agree that the situation in Fiji is worrying. name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This resolution opposes the Commission's delegated act, which aims at the reintegration of eight ACP countries in Annex I to Regulation (EC) No 1528/2007 (Market Access Regulation). That regulation provides that countries which have negotiated but not yet ratified the Economic Partnership Agreements (EPAs) benefit from a duty-free and quota-free import regime. We have always demonstrated our opposition to epas. What the EU wants with these agreements is to ensure the opening up of markets to its large financial groups, sell goods and services, exploit raw materials and impose an export-driven production model in their interests. On the other hand, we oppose the delegated act to Fiji because of the political situation in the country, which has been under military dictatorship since the 2006 military coup. Given that there are elections scheduled for 17 September, any negotiations between the EU and this country should only be held a posteriori.
